headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: UBS To Help PetroChina Raise $6 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: UBS has been hired to help China’s largest oil and gas group, PetroChina, raise up to $6 billion in what will be one of the biggest listings on the country’s mainland market. The Financial Times said that the deal highlights UBS’s determination to grab a big slice of the Chinese public offerings market.

headline: CNBC Jettisons ‘On The Money,’ Shifts Kudlow and Ratigan
abstract: “On the Money,” the two-year-old CNBC program that sought to hook young investors with a hip and almost flip approach to the day’s business news, is being put on hiatus, effective Oct. 10, an NBC official said this afternoon on condition of anonymity.

headline: The Bugs in Virgin America’s New High-Tech Flights
abstract: The airplane crash was only the in-flight entertainment system, but it was still unsettling.

headline: Image and Reality in the Search Wars
abstract: Microsoft and Yahoo have improved their search engines. But it will take both technology and marketing to convince Google users to switch.

headline: iPhone+AT&T Bill=Uh-Oh
abstract: AT&T is clueless about how to treat customers and the iPhone bill proves it.

headline: After Several Tries, London’s Shell-Mex House Is Sold
abstract: After 16 months of wrangling, Shell-Mex House, a landmark on London’s Strand, has been sold to Westbrook, the American fund manager, for 494 million pounds ($997 million).

headline: S.E.C. Chief Seeks New Clout for Board Overseeing States
abstract: In corporate America, flouting the rules of the Financial Accounting Standards Board can lead to a tangle with the S.E.C. But that threat does not exist for governments and their related agencies.

headline: Archstone Says Deal May Be Delayed
abstract: The giant apartment landlord Archstone-Smith said Monday that the closing date of its purchase by a group led by Tishman Speyer and Lehman Brothers could be pushed back to the fourth quarter.

headline: MooBella Scoops Up $25 Million in First Round
abstract: MooBella has completed a first round of institutional financing and picked up $25 million in the process. The company makes a self-contained ice cream vending system that creates fresh, hard-packed ice cream in less than one minute. A commercial rollout is expected at the end of this year.

headline: SLM Shareholders Approve Buyout
abstract: The SLM Corporation, commonly known as Sallie Mae, said on Wednesday its shareholders had approved the $25 billion acquisition of the student lender by a group of private equity firms and banks. The company in April accepted the cash leveraged buyout proposal, worth $60 per share, from J.C. Flowers, Friedman Fleischer & Lowe, Bank of America and J.P. Morgan Chase.

headline: Nick to Kids: Stop Watching (For Now)
abstract: Turn on Nickelodeon on Saturday afternoon, and you won’t see episodes of “SpongeBob SquarePants.”

headline: Transcontinental Signs Deal for Canadian Printer
abstract: Canadian media and printing company Transcontinental looks to expand its presence in Ontario after making a $130-million bid to take over PLM Group, Canada’s fourth-largest printer.

headline: ACS Investor Sends Board a Bitter Missive
abstract: Whatever happened to the $6.1 billion management-led buyout of Affiliated Computer Services? Amid the flurry of other buyouts and then the credit market’s stumble, it’s a deal many have forgotten. Since Cerberus Capital Management and Darwin Deason, ACS’s chairman, announced their bid in March, negotiations between the buyers and the technology services provider have been more tortoise than hare.

headline: S.E.C. Sues Ex-Nortel Officers in Accounting Case
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued four former finance officers at Nortel Networks on Wednesday, saying they had helped the former chief executive, Frank A. Dunn, manipulate reserves to enhance earnings.

headline: Nordstrom Unloads Faconnable
abstract: Nordstrom  said Thursday that it had agreed to sell its Faconnable brand to the M1 Group, a family-owned company based in Lebanon, for $210 million to focus on its main business, high-end department stores. As part of the agreement with M1, Nordstrom said it would continue to buy Faconnable merchandise for at least the next three years and will still offer the label in its stores.

headline: Some on Forbes 400 Are Criminally Rich
abstract: It seems that crime does pay — but only for a select few.

headline: Is Merger Advice Worth the Price?
Revisiting the Idea of the Public Law Firm
abstract: When the Blackstone Group went public earlier this year, the move represented a break with the tradition of private equity firms being, well, private. Now, some are wondering if another industry which has long eschewed the public markets may be ready to throw off the private mantle.

headline: Borse Dubai’s OMX Acquisition Violated Market Rules
abstract: Borse Dubai, locked in a takeover battle with the Nasdaq Stock Market for Nordic exchange operator OMX, violated stock-market practice when it announced its pursuit last month, the Swedish Securities Council said.

headline: Apollo Aims to Go Public Through the Back Door
abstract: Apollo Management, the giant buyout firm led by Leon Black, plans to join the private equity firms going public, but by going through a back door.

headline: Quick Bits: AT&T Sorry About Censorship, Fraudsters Invade Second Life
abstract: In the news today: Google and Microsoft battle with online storage, Universal Music tries to assert control, Comcast offers free Web video, and more.

headline: Impac Ceases Almost All Loans, Cuts Dividends
abstract: Impac Mortgage Holdings, a California home lender that suspended some operations last month, plans to cease almost all lending and omit dividends for the rest of 2007 after “disruptions” caused by rising defaults.

headline: Barclays Hires Veteran to Head Hong Kong Coverage
abstract: Barclays has hired 23-year investment banking veteran Aaron Tan from Calyon Securities as managing director and head of Hong Kong coverage. The move, according to Finance Asia, is an attempt by Barclays to expand its investment banking business in the territory.

headline: E.U. Says Spain Broke Merger Rules on Endesa Deal
abstract: The European Commission was back on the warpath Friday, firing off salvos against member states’ interference with Brussels’ merger-vetting powers.

headline: Tracking the Google Founders’ Plane
abstract: Google’s billionaire founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin are intensely private about their private jet, which recently secured landing rights at Moffett Field. And tracking the reconditioned Boeing 767-200 is not easy.

headline: Metrolight Basks in $9 Million Round of Funding
abstract: Metrolight, a maker of energy-saving lighting equipment, said it received a $9 million investment from a group led by Virgin Fuels, an investment vehicle of Sir Richard Branson, and Gemini Israel Funds.

headline: Regulators Form Unit to Tackle Insider Trading
abstract: Those plotting an insider-trading ring, beware.

headline: Globespan Closes $350 Million Fund
abstract: Globespan Capital Partners announced the closing of its fifth fund with commitments of $380 million on Monday. The closing of Globespan Capital Partners V gives the bicoastal venture firm $1.1 billion under management that it will deploy in communications, Internet infrastructure, enterprise software and storage systems and clean tech.

headline: Kraft Said to Be Shopping Post Cereal Business
abstract: Kraft Foods is in the early stages of looking for a buyer for its Post cereals business, maker of the Grape Nuts and Shredded Wheat brands, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Goldman Fund Is Said to Rebound
abstract: Goldman Sachs‘s Global Equity Opportunities hedge fund rose 12 percent last week after the securities firm shored up the money-losing pool with $3 billion of cash, investors told Bloomberg News.

headline: Apollo Raises Huntsman Bid
abstract: Apollo Management raised its offer for the chemical maker Huntsman by 75 cents, to $28 a share, or $6.5 billion, on Sunday, MarketWatch reported citing The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Sun Valley: What Murdoch Said, and What He Didn’t
abstract: DealBook suggested in an earlier post that Rupert Murdoch was feeling sanguine about his prospects of clinching Dow Jones — well, we actually said he looked sanguine — but his comments to Seth Sutel of the Associated Press suggest that he may be a bit frustrated with the Bancroft family’s back-and-forthing. “They keep changing their mind,” he told the AP, walking away from the lunch outside the Inn.

headline: Clearing Out My Closet
abstract: Odds and ends, but still pretty cool.

headline: Carrefour to Spin Off European Real Estate Arm
abstract: French supermarket giant Carrefour on Thursday responded to its fiercest critics — including some of its own shareholders — by announcing a plan to spin off its European real estate into a separately listed company.

headline: The Cloud Over the British iPhone
abstract: Apple will offer the iPhone in Britain with free access to 7,500 WiFi hot spots to compensate for a weak data network.

headline: Arclight Unloads Lodi Gas Storage
abstract: An oil pipeline operator, Buckeye Partners, is buying Lodi Gas Storage from a private equity firm, ArcLight Capital Partners, for $440 million, Lodi said Tuesday.

headline: 2nd-Quarter Proves Heady for V.C. Funding
abstract: Venture capital investment has reached its highest level since 2001, according to a report scheduled to be released Tuesday.

headline: In London, Carbon Trading Is the New Big Thing
abstract: Seeking to match a desire to make money with his environmental instincts, Louis Redshaw, a former electricity trader, met with five investment banks in 2004 to propose the trading of carbon dioxide. Only one, Barclays Capital, was interested.

headline: It Was Sony in the Dining Room With a Candlestick
abstract: With Grand Theft Auto IV delay, conspiracy theories abound. Maybe its publisher, Take-Two Interactive, is afraid of Microsoft’s Halo 3. Or maybe it is the flaws of Sony’s PS3.

headline: As the Market Wobbles, VMware Is Bullish on Its Offering This Week
abstract: EMC plans to raise $1.1 billion this week in an offering for its VMware unit. Analysts say VMware’s technology is wanted by big corporations, ahead of competitors, and trouble for Microsoft.

headline: KKR Sees Challenges If Downturn Continues
abstract: Henry Kravis is staying the course — at least for now.

headline: Premieres Help Fox Win Among 18 to 49 Year Olds
abstract: “With debuts of two new shows, Fox edged into first place Wednesday in the ratings among adults 18 to 49,” Benjamin Toff writes in today’s Times. “Fox’s new 9 p.m. offering, ‘Kitchen Nightmares,’ with the chef Gordon Ramsay (‘Hell’s Kitchen’), earned the night’s top ratings in that demographic, although it attracted just 6.6 million total viewers, Nielsen estimated. Earlier, the 8 p.m. hour proved especially competitive. Fox’s new comedy ‘Back to You,’ with Kelsey Grammer and Patricia Heaton, made a strong debut in the first half hour (9.4 million), followed by a slower start for Season 2 of ‘Til Death’ at 8:30 (7.8 million).”

headline: How Low Can Blackstone Go?
abstract: If Henry Kravis is still considering an initial public offering for his giant private equity firm, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, he might want to mull these grim numbers.

headline: Rimrock Energy Receives $250 Million in Financing
abstract: Rimrock Energy, a private oil and gas company, said on Wednesday that it had received financing commitments worth $250 million from Bear Stearns Merchant Banking and Natural Gas Partners.

headline: Blackstone Tries Indian Garment Maker on for Size
abstract: Blackstone Group will spend around $165 million to buy as much 70.1 percent of Indian garment maker Gokaldas Exports, the first of a number of deals in the region the New York private equity firm has promised.

headline: He Didn’t Want To Be That Kind of Friend
abstract: An acquaintance unfriends Saul Hansell on Facebook and asks him to meet on more neutral ground: LinkedIn. What is friendship in the modern world.

headline: Citigroup Tries to Lure Vultures to First Data Debt, Report Says
abstract: In its effort to unload debt related to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘s buyout of First Data Group, Citigroup is reportedly looking for help from an unusual source: vulture investors.

headline: Hearing Scheduled for Bell Canada Buyout
abstract: Canada’s federal broadcast regulator is preparing to hold public hearings early next year into the proposed 35 billion Canadian dollar ($34.9 billion) takeover of BCE, a move that could extend the closing of the deal until April, according to The Globe and Mail.

headline: For Financial One, a Groundbreaking but Low-Priced I.P.O.
abstract: A leasing company in Taiwan, Financial One, has priced its initial public offering at $168.75 million, the bottom of the indicated range. The company is only the second ever to list in Singapore, which may be a factor in the low number of orders.

headline: Hermès Tempts the Men of Wall Street
abstract: Hermès, the 170-year-old luxury goods company from Paris, opened the store, its second in New York, on June 21, with a special focus on the men who work in the surrounding banks and financial institutions and on the area’s growing residential population, the majority of which is male.

headline: China Sells
abstract: Why Is China Selling U.S. Treasuries?

headline: German Prosecutors Investigate IKB Officials
abstract: German state prosecutors on Friday said they were investigating whether officials at the state-controlled bank IKB may have committed breach of trust or violated German securities law. A spokesman for the prosecutors’ office would not identify targets of the investigation, but said they included “former officials” at the bank, which reported major losses related to subprime mortgages in the United States.

headline: A Different Road to Buyout Financing?
abstract: The recent collapse of the debt markets has left many wondering what’s next for private equity. As banks have become more unwilling to commit to the financing of deals, after faced with the prospect of holding unsaleable debt on their books, some analysts have speculated that the buyout boom is over.

headline: Kazakhstan’s Alliance Bank to Gain L.S.E. Listing
abstract: Alliance Bank, Kazakhstan’s largest retail lender, has priced a secondary stock offering at $14 to $17.30 per global depository receipt that will mark its opening on the London Stock Exchange, The Financial Times reported. With 50.28 million depository receipts scheduled to be sold, the offering is valued at between $704 million and $870 million.

headline: For UBS, Hotel Deals Bring Big Tips
abstract: Hilton Hotels, the deal-prone lodging giant, has been an enriching client for UBS.

headline: RCM Takes Computer Task Bid Public
abstract: RCM Technologies, which provides specialty professional staffing, made public Wednesday its $105 million offer for Computer Task Group after it was rebuffed twice by the board.

headline: Pret A Manger Said to Draw Buyout Interest
abstract: Pret A Manger, a British sandwich chain, may drop plans for an initial public offering now that several private equity firms have expressed interest in a deal, Reuters said, citing a report in the Financial Mail.

headline: Is Deal Jumping Another Sign of a Buyout Top?
abstract: As Wall Street feverishly takes the pulse of the buyout boom, Time magazine points out what it considers to be another possible trouble sign. Flush with cash and facing a narrowing a debt window, private equity firms are increasingly choosing to crash into each others’ deals.

headline: Contempt at Universal
abstract: Issuing illegal shares by the billions

headline: Brookfield Plans Infrastructure Spin-Off
abstract: Canada’s Brookfield Asset Management plans to spin off a 60 percent stake in its infrastructure operations to its shareholders in a deal worth about $600 million, the company said Tuesday.

headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: Nortel Is Ready to Make Deals
abstract: Nortel Networks is in takeover mode, chief executive Mike Zafirovski told Reuters on Thursday, confirming what Wall Street has been saying for a while about the maker of telecommunications equipment.

headline: Overstock and NovaStar, a Clarification
abstract: Patrick Byrne, the chief executive of Overstock.com, is not happy about this sentence in my Friday column on NovaStar:

headline: So Many Deals, So Much Debt
abstract: Harry Macklowe, the New York developer, was flying high in February when he decided to buy a portfolio of prime Midtown Manhattan office towers for nearly $7 billion, using only $50 million of his own money. His 2003 purchase of the General Motors Building on 59th Street and Fifth Avenue for $1.4 billion, though derided at the time as reckless, had been vindicated as the value of the building soared, enhancing Mr. Macklowe’s reputation as a visionary tycoon.

headline: Engineers as Counterspies: How the Greek Cellphone System Was Bugged
abstract: The July issue of IEEE Spectruman article on cellphone technology that reads like a spy thriller. Because it is. A look at how the cellphone of the Greek prime minister was bugged and questions about whether that could happen in the United States.

headline: Abu Dhabi Offers $5 Billion for Canada’s PrimeWest
abstract: Abu Dhabi National Energy has offered to buy PrimeWest Energy Trust for 5 billion Canadian dollars ($5 billion), its third and largest acquisition in Alberta since May.

headline: European Regulators Approve Gerber Deal
abstract: Nestle  won approval Friday from European regulators to buy Gerber Products, giving the world’s biggest food and drink company the largest share of the global baby food market.

headline: Tribune: Not Such a Done Deal?
abstract: Sam Zell’s agreement to take Tribune Company private is valued $34 a share. The media company’s stock, which reached a high of $33.20 in late May, was trading around $30.37 Thursday.

headline: Vodafone in Talks for $10 Billion Stake in Vodacom
abstract: Vodafone is in talks to buy control of its South African mobile phone joint venture Vodacom in a deal that could be worth up to $10 billion.

headline: Acer Strikes $710 Million Deal for Gateway
abstract: Acer agreed to acquire Gateway for $710 million to overtake Lenovo Group as the world’s third-biggest maker of personal computers.

headline: Buyout Loans: Who’s Holding the Bag?
abstract: Just a few weeks ago, selling the debt used to fund leveraged buyouts was a piece of cake. Now, it borders on the impossible. As a result, many of the investment banks that agreed to finance these deals are on the hook to make the loans themselves — at least until buyers and sellers can settle on a price and the debt can be resold.

headline: 3 Reporters Sue H.P. in Spying Case
abstract: Three reporters for CNET Networks sued the computer and printer maker Hewlett-Packard on Wednesday, accusing the company of violating their privacy in its hunt for the source of boardroom leaks.

headline: BofA Seeks Dismissal of ABN Lawsuit
abstract: Bank of America said on Thursday it asked a Manhattan federal judge to dismiss its lawsuit against ABN Amro seeking to block the Dutch bank from trying to sell its LaSalle Bank unit to other buyers.

headline: Topps Takes Another Time-Out on Deal Vote
abstract: Topps said on Tuesday that it would postpone a shareholder vote on a proposed sale to two private equity firms a second time, to Aug. 30. The company also said that it had appointed Biagio Vignolo as its interim chief financial officer, succeeding Catherine Jessup, who has already announced her resignation.

headline: 2 Massachusetts Brokerages Settle with S.E.C.
abstract: Two Massachusetts brokerage firms each agreed to pay $250,000 and to be censured to settle allegations by the Securities and Exchange Commission that they failed to supervise former representative Bradford J. Bleidt, who pleaded guilty in 2005 to charges he cheated investors out of millions of dollars.

headline: Canada Said to Mull Australian Media Rules
abstract: In the aftermath of three major takeovers in Canada’s broadcasting sector, the nation’s regulators appear poised to consider revamping the rules on media consolidation, using a system pioneered last year by the Australian government, The Globe and Mail reported.

headline: Australian Firms Extend $1.35 Billion Bid for Gateway Casinos
abstract: Australian firms Publishing & Broadcasting and Macquarie Bank extended their C$1.365 billion ($1.35 billion) takeover offer for Canada’s Gateway Casinos business Thursday for a third time.

headline: Gemstar-TV Guide to Look at Options, Including Sale
abstract: Gemstar-TV Guide International, which publishes TV Guide magazine, said Monday that it had hired UBS to explore strategic alternatives, including the sale of the company.

headline: Clear Channel’s F.C.C. Review Nears End, Report Says
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission has nearly completed its review of the $26 billion buyout of radio and outdoor advertising company Clear Channel Communications by Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital, according to The Deal.com.

headline: Allen to Sell DreamWorks Stake
abstract: The billionaire Paul Allen is selling the majority of his stake in DreamWorks Animation SKG and stepping down from the board of the animation company he helped bankroll in its infancy.

headline: V.C.s Bring Amyris Half the Way There
abstract: Amyris Biotechnologies, a developer of a process to make biofuels using engineered microbes, said Wednesday it had closed part of its $70 million second round of funding.

headline: Boston Scientific Reverses on Endosurgery Offering
abstract: The medical device maker Boston Scientific said Thursday that it had decided against selling a minority stake in its endosurgery group to the public, a move that it had explored to raise as much as $1 billion in cash and help pay off debt from a $27 billion acquisition.

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Pleads Guilty to Insider Trading
abstract: Eugene Plotkin, a former associate at Goldman Sachs charged in an insider trading scheme that took in more than $6.7 million, said he would plead guilty.

headline: Bausch & Lomb Allows Rival to Discuss Bid
abstract: Bausch & Lomb said on Monday that it would give Advanced Medical Optics limited permission to discuss its $4.2 billion bid with certain shareholders, although it was sticking with its $3.67 billion buyout deal with a private equity firm, Warburg Pincus.

headline: Boston Stock Exchange Closes Bank-Backed Equity Unit
abstract: The Boston Stock Exchange shuttered the electronic equities market it created two years ago with backing from some of Wall Street’s biggest brokerage firms after failing to draw business from competitors.

headline: The Morality of Blocking Ads
abstract: Most sites are ignoring a new Firefox add-in that can block Web ads. The Daily Kos, however, is asking users of the product to buy subscriptions.

headline: American Home Mortgage Says It Will Close
abstract: American Home Mortgage Investment, the troubled mortgage lender based in Melville, N.Y., will close Friday, making it the latest company to fail this year as loans made to home buyers, some even with solid credit histories, go bad.

headline: Spotting Potential Deals Amid the Fashions
abstract: As willowy models (and a few Brazilian street dancers) strutted on the catwalks as part of New York’s Fashion Week, one Wall Street analyst was suggesting that the latest designer clothes aren’t the only thing that could be for sale soon.

headline: Family Feud at Viacom: Is It in Play?
abstract: The possibility that Shari Redstone, the daughter of Viacom chairman Sumner Redstone, could leave the media conglomerate’s board has reignited speculation about whether the company might be in play.

headline: Canada’s Coventree Hit by Credit Woes
abstract: The global credit crunch claimed a Canadian victim Monday, as the stock of a financing company, the Coventree Capital Group, plummetted on news that investors have turned their backs on its $15 billion portfolio of loans.

headline: Eurazeo Weaves $3.4 Billion Deal for Elis
abstract: Eurazeo, the French private equity firm, agreed Wednesday to buy a textile rental and cleaning service company, Elis GIE for 2.28 billion euros ($3.14 billion) from PAI Partners.

headline: Arrow Shareholder Reverses Position on Teleflex Deal
abstract: In an about-face, a major shareholder in Arrow International said Friday that it would support the proposed $2 billion acquisition by Teleflex, according to a regulatory filing.

headline: If Dow Jones Is Not Sold
abstract: Whither Dow Jones if Murdoch Walks?

headline: Adviser Firm on Pensions Is Rebuked
abstract: Federal securities regulators have issued a cease-and-desist order against a large pension consulting firm, Callan Associates, for failing to tell its clients that it had an outside business relationship that could affect the investment advice it gave.

headline: Morgan Stanley Settles E-Mail Charges
abstract: Morgan Stanley will pay $12.5 million to resolve charges it failed in arbitration cases to provide e-mails that it said were destroyed in the September 11, 2001, attacks, when in fact it had saved the e-mails on backup files.

headline: Clips: FCC Fight, “60 Minutes” Podcasts, Video Overload
Ackman’s Win-Win Bet on Target
abstract: Investors are often counseled, but often forget, that they should protect their downsides as they seek profits. According to Breakingviews, Pershing Square Capital‘s William Ackman has done just that as he pursues a shakeup of Target, which reported healthy earnings growth for tis second quarter.

headline: Nintendo Throws Down Again (Not The Way You Think)
abstract: Nintendo’s surge continues – not just in game hardware but also in software. Of the top 10 video games for the first half of the year, seven were for Nintendo platforms.

headline: Citigroup Tower in London Sells for $2 Billion
abstract: The Royal Bank of Scotland has sold its tower block at 25 Canada Square in London’s Canary Wharf for 1 billion pounds ($2 billion) to a joint venture between Quinlan Private and PropInvest. Citigroup, which is currently housed in the tower, has leased it for 20 more years and will pay 46.5 million pounds a year in rent, says The Telegraph.

headline: Rebuffing Investor, HSBC Says No Japan M&A in the Works
abstract: HSBC is not considering acquisitions in Japan and will instead focus on growth by itself as it rolls out retail banking in the world’s second-largest economy, HSBC Chairman Stephen Green said on Thursday.

headline: Spain’s Cellerix Raises $38 Million
abstract: Pharmaceutical company Cellerix said Thursday that it has closed a 27.2 million euro ($38.31 million) Series B financing round, which it claims is the largest ever funding for a Spanish biotech company.

headline: Buyout Firms and the Fee Factor
abstract: Why have private equity firms been winning so many auctions? Peter J. Solomon, whose eponymous boutique investment bank focuses on the retail industry, suggests that the playing field has been tilted in their favor by the bankers that companies hire to run the sale process.

headline: Thornburg Sells $20.5 Billion in Mortgage-Backed Securities
abstract: Thornburg Mortgage, which forced to stop taking home-loan applications earlier this month because of a cash crunch, said it sold $20.5 billion of mortgage-backed securities as part of a plan to return to “business as usual.”

headline: Bain to Buy 3Com in $2.2 Billion Deal
abstract: 3Com, the telecommunications equipment maker, said early Friday it would sell itself to Bain Capital Partners for $2.2 billion in cash. The transaction is the largest private-equity deal to be announced since the credit markets seized up in April.

headline: Chinese Blogger Arrested Over Stock Tips
abstract: A popular Chinese blogger has been arrested in conjunction with stock tips he made via an unauthorized online investment consulting business, although no charges have yet been filed.

headline: Message from Time Warner: AOL Is Staying Put
abstract: Anyone hoping for a sign — even a hint — that Time Warner is considering a big, transformative deal probably went away disappointed after Wednesday’s earnings conference call.

headline: Facebook Backer: Suitors Far Too Low
abstract: Facebook has been rumored to be for sale for a long time, yet no deal has been signed. Why? According to one of the social networking site’s backers, it’s because potential suitors are lowballing offers.

headline: Biovail Re-Hires Law Firm
abstract: The troubled Canadian drug maker Biovail Pharmaceuticals brought back a law firm it recently fired to help it fend off charges that it improperly used documents in a legal battle it’s waging against hedge funds and Wall Street analysts.

headline: After Gateway Deal, Eyes Turn to Lenovo
abstract: As executives at Gateway and Acer carried on about the many benefits of their $710 million merger announced Monday, TheStreet.com speculated that Acer’s nemesis, Lenovo, might make a counteroffer for Gateway.

headline: Lululemon Shares Jump in Debut
abstract: Lululemon Athletica‘s stock rallied as much as 50 percent Friday, despite an overall market sell-off, after the yoga-clothing maker increased the size of its initial public offering and raised the price.

headline: After 2 Years, Portus Investors to Get Checks
abstract: Investors in defunct hedge fund Portus Alternative Asset Management will get some of their money back this fall, after a judge cleared the way Friday for the first payouts from the fund’s receiver.

headline: Moving on to Silverstone
abstract: As Formula One probably says goodbye to Magny-Cours, many people are leaving the track with a sense of relief that it is over. It has been a weekend of truly mixed emotions. The highs of great results from Robert Kubica, a return for Ferrari to top form, a Kimi Raikkonen lifting himself out of the doldrums to victory again. But on the other side, another horrendous reminder of how close the circuit is to racing calamity, with the terrible GP2 accident yesterday, from which, fortunately, the driver escaped with only bruising, and like Kubica before him, a small concussion. But the Formula One paddock learned this morning of tragic news. Three people were killed and two were seriously injured in a helicopter accident last night, as they flew from the circuit to a hotel in a nearby town. The injured people were connected to the Bridgestone tire manufacturer, but the identity of the victims has not yet been made public, although it involves at least two Formula One paddock people.

headline: Danone Offers $16.8 Billion for Royal Numico
abstract: Danone, the French food conglomerate, said Monday it was offering $16.8 billion to buy Dutch baby food company Royal Numico, which is recommending that shareholders accept the deal. The announcement came less than a week after Kraft said it would pay $7.2 billion for Danone’s cookie division.

headline: Bear Stearns Fund Reduces Debt by Half
abstract: Bear Stearns’ High-Grade Structured Credit Strategies Enhanced Leverage Fund has cut its debt in half to $600 million after selling off assets, Bloomberg News reported on Wednesday. The fund owed creditors $1.2 billion as of June 26 but the ailing securities firm filed the new numbers in a regulatory filing Tuesday.

headline: Lehman’s Hunt for Weapons of Wealth Destruction
abstract: Jami Miscik isn’t just the global head of sovereign risk for Lehman Brothers. In the words of Fortune magazine’s Patricia Sellers, she is also the securities firm’s “uber-analyst and seer.” Her long profile of Ms. Miscik describes her as an astute assessor of geopolitics and their effect on Lehman’s investment strategies.

headline: What’s in Google’s Name?
abstract: One man sues Google because his Social Security number turned upside down and scrambled spells the name Google. Another argues Google stole its name from the Gogo tribe of Tanzania. There may be 1 followed by 100 zeros more allegations.

headline: Virgin Mobile Plans to Dial Up $375 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: Virgin Mobile USA, the wireless telecom company, expects to raise $375.6 million after expenses from its planned initial public offering, according to a regulatory filing.

headline: Buffett May Increase Railroad Stake to 25%
abstract: Billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett may increase his stake a second time in Burlington Northern Santa Fe, the railroad company, to 25 percent, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: A Bank Founder’s (Involuntary) Last Day
abstract: There are no grand sendoffs planned. No speeches, either. In fact, Vernon W. Hill II, who founded Commerce Bank 34 years ago, is not even planning to go to the office on Tuesday.

headline: Advanced Medical Walks Away from Bausch Bid
abstract: Advanced Medical Optics on Wednesday withdrew its $4.23 billion unsolicited takeover bid for its rival eye-care company Bausch & Lomb, saying Bausch had put up unrealistic hurdles to a potential deal.

headline: Engineers Fight Patent Reform, Not Patent Trolls
abstract: The IEEE sends a strong letter to legislators opposing patent reform

headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: Backdating Conviction Rattles Silicon Valley
abstract: Brocade Communications Systems‘ former chief executive, Gregory L. Reyes, was found guilty of conspiracy and fraud Tuesday in the first criminal options-backdating case to go to trial.

headline: Before the Credit Crunch, a Timely Warning
abstract: In a June 18 commentary, Steven Rattner predicted that the market for high-yield corporate debt, the lifeblood of the leveraged buyout industry, was headed for a correction.

headline: H&R Block Directors to Stand Re-election Annually
abstract: H&R Block, facing a proxy battle from the activist investor Richard C. Breeden, said Monday that its board had voted to require all directors to stand for election annually rather than every three years.

headline: National Penn to Buy KNBT Bancorp
abstract: A busy spell for banking acquisitions in the Philadelphia region continued Friday as National Penn Bancshares said it had agreed to buy KNBT Bancorp in a stock deal worth $420 million based on the closing share price.

headline: Nestle Swallows Swiss Water Firm
abstract: Nestle pushed its rapid expansion in the bottled water business forward on Tuesday by agreeing to take over a Swiss bottler, Henniez , in a deal valued at 155 million Swiss francs ($128.3 million).

headline: EMI Chief Leaves After Private Equity Takeover
abstract: Eric Nicoli stepped down as chief executive of the EMI Group Wednesdayahead of private investors’ purchase of the music corporation, which had tried unsuccessfully throughout his eight-year tenure to merge with rivals.

headline: German Bank Said to Have $3 Billion in Subprime
abstract: Landesbank Sachsen Girozentrale, the German state-owned bank getting emergency funding, has about 3 billion euros ($4 billion) in investments linked to U.S. subprime mortgages, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Braddock Financial to Liquidate Hedge Fund
abstract: Heavy redemptions from investors concerned about their holdings of subprime mortgage securities claimed the Galena Street Fund of Braddock Financial as the latest hedge fund victim.

headline: BEA Systems Stock Up on Deal Chatter
abstract: Shares of the software maker BEA Systems rose more than 3 percent Monday following three upgrades from analysts, reviving speculation that the business-software maker may be an acquisition target.

headline: Protesters Prepare Unwarm Welcome for Carlyle Chief
A Sad Tale of Wall Street’s Orphans
abstract: The life of a sell-side research analyst has not been easy lately. Many Wall Street firms, unsure how to make this business profitable in the post-Spitzer regulatory era, have been cutting jobs in their research arms. In June, Prudential Financial decided to shut down its research unit entirely.

headline: New York’s Shrinking Exchange Floor
abstract: Behind the marble facade of its neoclassical fortress on Wall Street, the New York Stock Exchange has been the hub of financial activity in Lower Manhattan for more than a century.

headline: V.C.’s Prescribe $26 Million for Sermo.com
abstract: Sermo.com, where physicians can tap “the wisdom of crowds” to help them diagnose and treat intractable illnesses, has gotten a $26.7 million infusion of cash, the company said Wednesday. Baltimore-based asset manager Legg Mason led the latest round and was joined by the New York City investment bank Allen & Co.

headline: 1,000 Points of Darkness
abstract: What’s 1,000 Dow points? A Sign of Panic.

headline: Toshiba Sells Tokyo Building for $1.4 Billion
abstract: Toshiba said on Wednesday it would sell a landmark building in Tokyo’s Ginza district for 161 billion yen ($1.4 billion) to Tokyu Land.

headline: British Lender Gets Bailout; Is Buyout Next?
abstract: Is Northern Rock headed for the block?

headline: Banks Urge U.S. to Adopt the Trading of Emissions
abstract: A group representing some of the world’s leading banks will urge the United States and other industrial nations this week to move quickly to introduce a lightly regulated system for trading carbon emissions permits.

headline: NYSE Euronext to Investigate ABN Amro Trades
abstract: NYSE Euronext is looking into trading of ABN Amro securities that took place around the time of the bank’s March announcement of discussions of a sale to Barclays PLC, Reuters reported Tuesday citing an article in The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Emap Said to Receive Offer from Apax
abstract: An informal takeover approach by Apax Partners is in part responsible for Emap‘s decision to announce Friday that it is considering a sale or breakup of the company, The Guardian reported. The British private equity group has reportedly made an informal approach to buy Emap’s business-to-business division for 1.3 billion pounds ($2.6 billion).

headline: Lloyds Sells Abbey Life to Deutsche Bank
abstract: Lloyds TSB said on Tuesday that it had sold its Abbey Life insurance unit to Deutsche Bank for 977 million pounds ($2 billion) in cash, divesting itself of what it said was not a core strategic asset.

headline: Conrad Black Asks Judge to Overturn Guilty Verdict
abstract: Conrad Black, the former chairman of Hollinger International, who was convicted of fraud and obstruction of justice for stealing millions from the company, asked a federal judge to order his acquittal or give him a new trial. In papers filed today with Judge Amy St. Eve of United States District Court in Chicago, Mr. Black’s attorneys argued that evidence prosecutors presented to the jury during his 15-week trial doesn’t support last month’s guilty verdict.

headline: Coles Board Approves $14 Billion Takeover Offer
abstract: Shares of the Coles Group, Australia’s second-largest retailer, climbed 4.6 percent in afternoon trading Wednesday after the company’s board endorsed a takeover bid worth 18 billion Australian dollars ($14.82 billion) from Wesfarmers.

headline: Virgin Radio I.P.O. May Not Happen This Year, Report Says
abstract: The planned initial public offering of Virgin Radio by its owner, SMG, is unlikely to proceed this year, Dow Jones Newswires reported.

headline: We Need More Lawyers
abstract: Why we needed more lawyers.

headline: Hedge Fund Manager Pleads Guilty in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A hedge fund manager who was among more than a dozen people accused of participating in an insider trading ring pleaded guilty Tuesday to profiting from inside tips that prosecutors say were leaked by a former executive at UBS Securities.

headline: After Microsoft, Hunting the Next Big Thing
abstract: Would-be inventors, take note: Nathan Myhrvold, a former chief technology officer at Microsoft, is behind a fund that has raised $355 million in what seems to be an effort to back new technologies in their infancy. Mr. Myhrvold knows a thing or two about getting in early: He was part of Microsoft’s original brain trust and once led its research arm.

headline: S.E.C. Is Said to Check on Banks’ Subprime Assets
abstract: Securities regulators are checking the books at top Wall Street brokerage firms and banks to make sure they are not hiding losses in the subprime-mortgage meltdown, The Wall Street Journal reported Friday.

headline: Yahoo Picks Up BuzzTracker
abstract: Yahoo, looking to attract visitors and advertisers to its online news pages, purchased BuzzTracker, a site that ranks stories based on their popularity among bloggers.

headline: Conrad Black Jury Deadlocks
abstract: The jury in the racketeering and fraud trial of Conrad Black, the fallen former head of Hollinger, sent a note to the judge Tuesday saying they are unable to reach a verdict and asking for advice. The note read to the court by U.S. District Judge Amy St. Eve said: ”We have discussed and deliberated on all the evidence and are still unable to reach a unanimous verdict on one or more counts. Please advise.”

headline: Microsoft Loses European Appeal
abstract: In a stinging rebuke to the world’s largest software maker, the second-highest European court rejected Monday a request by Microsoft to overturn a 2004 European Commission antitrust ruling that the company had abused its dominance in computer operating systems.

headline: Goldman Won’t Bail Out Alpha Hedge Fund
abstract: Goldman Sachs will not bail out its embattled flagship Global Alpha hedge fund, nor will it close the fund, according to press reports.

headline: Northern Rock Plummets On Rumors of Lowball Bid
abstract: Northern Rock shares fell as much as 20 percent Wednesday morning as rumors swept the market that the ailing British lender is set to be acquired for a knock-down price.

headline: “Kid Nation” Hits Few Spots
abstract: Savannah, Leila, Randy and Zach in "Kid Nation" on the CBS Television Network. The controversial CBS reality series, "Kid Nation," may be set in Bonanza City, N.M., but the commercial revenue could not have been a bonanza for the network. Reflecting the debate about the content of the series, which depicts children fending for themselves in a […]

headline: Latest Round in Everlast Fight May Start This Week
abstract: A potential fight is brewing over Everlast Worldwide as a New York investor group faces off against a British sports retailer in a bid for control of the company.

headline: Pearson Said to Be In Talks to Sell FT Deutschland
abstract: Pearson, the British owner of The Financial Times, is in talks to shed another one of its newspaper investments with a deal to sell a 50 percent stake in The Financial Times Deutschland in Germany, according to news reports.

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland Takes Stake in Sempra’s Commodities Unit
abstract: Sempra Energy, the San Diego utility company, said Monday that Royal Bank of Scotland would pay $1.3 billion for a majority stake in its commodities business.

headline: Law Firms From U.S. Invade Paris
abstract: Driven by the boom in corporate law accompanying waves of mergers and acquisitions, American law firms have been marching into European territory, in particular in France, The New York Times reports.

headline: Subprime Woes Rock Australian Hedge Fund
abstract: Australian hedge fund manager Basis Capital may be the latest to take a hit linked to the subprime mortgage crisis. The group is currently in talks with creditors after banks seized and began to sell some of its investments, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Can Zwinky Save Ask?
abstract: Ask.com’s ads are not attracting new uses. But IAC is making lots of money with Zwinky, a service that lets people create online avatars.

headline: Blackstone’s Falling Stock Sparks Anger in China
abstract: The first purchase by the Chinese government’s new overseas investment fund, a $3 billion stake in the Blackstone Group, has produced an unusual public reaction within China, The New York Times reports. Since Blackstone went public on June 22, the company’s shares have fallen steeply, pushing down the value of the Chinese government’s investment by more than $425 million in just six weeks.

headline: Capital One to Buy NetSpend for $700 Million
abstract: Capital One Financial, a credit card issuer and banking company, said on Tuesday it agreed to buy NetSpend Holdings, a marketer of prepaid debit cards, for $700 million in cash. The transaction is not expected to have a material impact on Capital One’s earnings per share until 2009.

headline: Journal Editor Interviews Self on Murdoch
abstract: Paul E. Steiger, former managing editor of The Wall Street Journal and now editor at large of the paper, was a keynote speaker at the annual convention of the Asian American Journalists Association in Miami and had intended to discuss the future of journalism.

headline: A Goldilocks Scenario in Merrill’s H.Q. Search
abstract: Merrill Lynch has found three possible locations in the city for its new headquarters, though none of them is ideal, according to The New York Post.

headline: What Barclays Wants from Bear Stearns
abstract: Barclays is considering its options for recovering $400 million it invested in the a now worthless Bear Stearns hedge fund. Those options are either a negotiated settlement or litigation, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Fluorescents Are So Over
abstract: The home will be the last major frontier in solid state lighting’s conquest of incandescent light.

headline: Mortgage Lender Alliance Bancorp to Liquidate
abstract: The Alliance Bancorp, a residential mortgage lender based in Brisbane, Calif., has filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy and will liquidate its assets. The company listed assets and debts of more than $100 million each in its bankruptcy petition, which was filed Friday in Delaware.

headline: Investors Pulled $32 Billion from Hedge Funds in July
abstract: For hedge funds, July, it seems, was the cruelest month. Until the August figures are released.

headline: European Energy Firms Clash Over Deal Talks
abstract: The two largest Central European energy companies are headed for a clash after the chief executive of one, OMV of Austria, said Thursday that he was determined to merge with the other, MOL of Hungary, which was taking extraordinary moves to defend itself.

headline: San Francisco’s Wi-Fi Fog
abstract: The EarthLink-Google plan for free Wi-Fi in San Francisco appears to be derailed — for now.

headline: In Hedge Fund I.P.O.’s, Shades of Pets.com? Not Really.
abstract: In 2005, about the time hedge funds started sprouting like weeds, investors, money managers and the media started to question whether there might be a hedge fund bubble. With hedge funds lining up to go public, the questioning has turned up a notch.

headline: Analyst Sees Gloomy Outlook for Cadbury Deal
abstract: It increasingly looks like Nelson Peltz chose a bad time to show off his shareholder activist shenanigans by taking a stake in Cadbury Schweppes and pressing the company to sell its American beverage unit.

headline: Lehman Cuts Estimates on Rivals
abstract: Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch and Bear Stearns, four of the five largest securities firms, will earn less than expected through next year after a rout in subprime mortgages, according to a Lehman Brothers analyst.

headline: Australia’s Sims Strikes $1.4 Billion for Metal Management
abstract: Metal Management, announcing a transaction it said would create “a global powerhouse” in the scrap-metal industry, disclosed Monday that it had agreed to be acquired by Australia’s Sims Group for stock valued at $1.48 billion.

headline: 3i Plans to Build $1 Billion India Fund
abstract: Publicly listed British private equity house 3i Group plans to build on its already strong relationships in India with the establishment of its first dedicated India infrastructure fund, which has an initial target of $1 billion.

headline: Should Yahoo Try Again for Facebook?
abstract: An at Bear Stearns suggests that Yahoo is also being left behind by sites such as MySpace, Facebook and LinkedIn, and said that an acquisition could be a good way to catch up.

headline: Unit of Idealab, Still Dabbling in Bits, Tries I.P.O.
abstract: Internet Brands, the owner of CarsDirect that was started by IdeaLab, files for a public stock offering.

headline: DealBook Talks Dow Jones
abstract: On Tuesday night’s episode of “The Charlie Rose Show,” DealBook’s Andrew Ross Sorkin sat down with Charlie Rose and The New Yorker’s Ken Auletta to talk about the News Corporation‘s $5 billion deal for Dow Jones. You can watch the full video after the jump.

headline: Business Intelligence Software Grows Up
abstract: A new report from IDC shows Microsoft and Oracle giving new competition to the leaders in this rapidly growing market.

headline: More From Ooma
abstract: Andrew Frame, the chief executive of Ooma, has answered the second batch of questions from Bits readers on his new telephony start-up.

headline: Diageo’s Chief Has an Eye on Absolut Auction
abstract: Diageo‘s chief executive, Paul Walsh, said his company, which owns the Smirnoff vodka brand, is “very interested” in buying Sweden’s Absolut vodka, valued at about $6 billion. Any possible antitrust problems are probably surmountable, he added.

headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: Mutual Funds Go Light on Wall Street Stocks
abstract: Lots of fund managers say they are bullish on Wall Street — but they aren’t necessarily investing that way. In fact, managers of the largest mutual funds seem to be avoiding substantial stakes in Wall Street’s top firms, a trend that Tobias Levkovich, the chief United States investment strategist at Citi, calls “surprising.”

headline: Encore Sets I.P.O.
abstract: Encore Bancshares is planning an initial public offering of 2 million shares at a price set between $20 and $22. Net proceeds are expected to hit $36.2 million. The bank is based in Houston with additional operations in southwest Florida.

headline: American Home Mortgage Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: American Home Mortgage Investment filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection Monday in Wilmington, Del., capping a tumultuous 10 days for what had been one of the nation’s biggest home lenders.

headline: Will DreamWorks Say ‘Cut’ to Paramount?
abstract: Even as “Transformers” has proven one of the breakout hits of the summer, could Paramount Pictures still lose the studio that made it and other blockbusters? Tensions between the Viacom-owned studio and DreamWorks, the star-studded boutique it bought almost two years ago for $1.53 billion, have been anything but secret.

headline: Analyst Sees More Leeway for Bookstore Merger
abstract: What does organic broccoli have to do with Harry Potter?

headline: Morgan Threatens to Walk Away from Reddy Ice Deal
abstract: The fate of a pending $1.1 billion leveraged buyout of Reddy Ice Holdings is in jeopardy after Morgan Stanley said it had the leag right to pull its debt financing commitment for the deal. The maker of packaged ice agreed to be bought by hedge fund GSO Capital Partners in July for $1.1 billion, with Morgan Stanley providing $775 million of debt financing for the buyout.

headline: Guilty Plea Is Arranged in Tax Plot
abstract: The owner of the nation’s largest maker of machine tools agreed Friday to plead guilty to conspiracy in cheating the government out of $34.3 million in taxes through what the I.R.S. called “deceptive and elaborate tax evasion schemes.”

headline: New Ideas in Thin Computing – I
abstract: Teradici is attacking the thin-client computing market with a customized chip.

headline: Mystery Bidders Arise for Alitalia
abstract: A largely Italian consortium of financiers and entrepreneurs has expressed interest in buying ailing Italian airline Alitalia, which is struggling to find a buyer after a failed auction, the group’s lawyer said on Friday.

headline: WCI Strikes Deal with Icahn to End Proxy Fight
abstract: In what appears to be a humbling development for WCI Communities, the homebuilder said on Monday that it has agreed to let Carl C. Icahn place three directors on its board, ending a long-running proxy fight.

headline: Landry’s Says Review Showed No ‘Intentional’ Misconduct
abstract: A second internal investigation turned up no intentional misconduct, but past stock-options practices will likely prompt Landry’s Restaurants to take a bigger one-time charge than it previously thought, the company said Monday.

headline: British Financier Calls for Private Equity Code
abstract: Sir David Walker, a former Bank of England director and a former Morgan Stanley International chairman, presented his findings in a preliminary report on private equity on Tuesday. Among the more salient points to be made were that large buyout funds need not appoint independent, nonexecutive directors to their portfolio companies. Making such a shift would “go right across the grain” of the private equity industry, said Walker according to TheDeal.com.

headline: The Buyout Loan Merry-Go-Round
abstract: If you aren’t confused by the recent credit crunch and its effects on the leveraged-buyout business, you will be soon.

headline: Dubai to Buy Stake in MGM Mirage for $5 Billion
abstract: Dubai World agreed to pay $5 billion for a 9.5 percent stake in MGM Mirage and half of the Las Vegas casino owner’s biggest development, bringing billionaire shareholder Kirk Kerkorian his biggest investment in the company.

headline: A City Jumps into the V.C. Game
abstract: In an unusual effort to make venture capital investing communal, San Jose, Calif. invested $350,000 in a local company, Bentek Manufacturing, to help it grow and provide good pay and benefits for its 120 employees.

headline: Carlyle Consortium Win Spain’s Applus
abstract: A consortium led by theCarlyle Group has won the auction for an inspection and certification company, Applus, with a bid of 1.48 billion euros ($2.04 billion) in what would be Spain’s biggest leveraged buyout in the last two years.

headline: Is Eddie Lampert Feeling the Pain?
abstract: Edward Lampert, long ranked among the world’s best-performing investors, may be enduring a rough patch, according to Reuters.

headline: Buyout Behemoths May Need to Think Smaller
abstract: Can the giants of private equity wean themselves off the megadeal?

headline: Countrywide’s Big Credit Draw Fuels Market Fears
abstract: Stocks fell sharply Wednesday in the United States, set off by worries that Countrywide Financial, the largest mortgage lender in the nation, could face bankruptcy if liquidity worsens after a Merrill Lynch analyst flagged that possibility. The mood grew even more grim Thursday morning, when the lender said it tapped its entire $11.5 billion credit line to boost cash on hand.

headline: Goldman Sachs: ‘This Is Not a Rescue’
abstract: Goldman Sachs may be pumping billions of dollars in one of its troubled hedge funds, but don’t call it a bailout. Or a rescue.

headline: Wall Street Takes a Left Turn
abstract: The Democratic takeover of Congress put Wall Street’s lobbyists in a quandary. The financial services industry wants to back winners, but the latest crop of winners on Capitol Hill seem prone to tax and regulate them.

headline: Dean Kamen Lends a Hand, or Two
abstract: The man who invented the Segway has a new creation: a robotic arm.

headline: Private Equity Increasingly Hires Its Own Legal Aces
abstract: As private equity firms grow, broaden the scope of their investments and encounter more litigation, a rising number of them are hiring general counsel, The National Law Journal reports.

headline: The World According to VMware
abstract: One month after staging one of this year’s most successful initial public offerings, VMware is throwing itself a party.

headline: Policy Will Let More Chinese Invest in Hong Kong Market
abstract: The Chinese government announced Monday that it would allow mainland Chinese citizens to invest in the Hong Kong stock market, the most significant move to date by Beijing officials to dismantle the barriers that prevent most Chinese from making international investments.

headline: AOL’s Case Backs New Online Payment System
abstract: Stephen Case, the co-founder of AOL, is launching a new online payment company that promises to let users transfer funds for free and offer a credit card with sharply lower fees for merchants.

headline: Revising History
abstract: Alan Greenspan has discovered that the Bush administration is not a paragon of financial responsibility, and is under attack for not having mentioned that fact back when it could have done some good — when the 2001 tax cut was being passed.

headline: American Airlines Becomes Subject of Renewed Takeover Chatter
abstract: Shares of American Airlines parent AMR rose more than 7 percent on Monday amid persistent talk in the stock options market about a possible takeover of the company.

headline: Deutsche Bank Posts Rise in Profit
abstract: Deutsche Bank, Germany’s biggest bank, said profit rose 31 percent, beating analysts’ estimates, on record second-quarter trading revenue. Net income climbed to 1.78 billion euros ($2.43 billion), or 3.60 euros a share, from 1.35 billion euros, or 2.44 euros, a year earlier, the Frankfurt-based bank said on its Web site Wednesday.

headline: Closing the Open Facebook
abstract: Facebook has put pressure on Christian Flickinger, a programmer, to remove code from his blog that would let someone change a profile page without logging into its site. How much control can it maintain as it opens to developers?

headline: I’m Outta Here
abstract: I’m headed for vacation, although my Friday and Saturday columns will appear this week. Comments will continue to be posted, but I probably won’t write new items until Aug. 27.

headline: City Trading Falls Under Watchful Eye in London
abstract: London’s chief financial regulator is recommending that companies involved in public takeovers should adopt more stringent measures to investigate information leaks and enforce a more rigorous strategy when selecting insiders to be privy to sensitive information.

headline: ABN Amro Shares Fall on Bid Concerns
abstract: Stock in ABN Amro, the Dutch bank, fell the most in almost six years on concern turmoil roiling financial markets may hinder its takeover.

headline: Learning the Downside of Derivatives, the Hard Way
abstract: Here is a question for Wall Street to ponder over the long weekend: Has the spreading out of market risk — a defining feature of the new age of financial engineering — actually increased it as well?

headline: Having Fun on Web Video Before They Make the Rules
abstract: New online video network My Damn Channel is bringing professional comedians to YouTube and other Web sites. Up first: Harry Shearer as a Dick Cheney the lounge lizard.

headline: Appeals Court Grants Bail to Ex-Qwest Chief
abstract: Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications International who was convicted of insider trading, may remain free on $2 million bail while he appeals, a federal court ruled Wednesday.

headline: Lee Equity Buys Deb Shops for $395 Million
abstract: A private-equity group, Lee Equity Partners, founded by the buyout veteran Thomas H. Lee, is buying a junior-girl fashion retailer, Deb Shops, a Philadelphia company founded as a women’s hosiery store, for $395 million, the company said Friday. The $27.25-per-share deal requires shareholder approval and represents a small premium over Thursday’s closing price of $26.68.

headline: EBay’s Swarm Strategy to Take on Craigslist
abstract: After starting Kijiji, a free classified advertising site in the United States, eBay is also bringing Gumtree, its British classified site, to three cities here too.

headline: Minority Group Joins Fight Over Carried Interest
abstract: So far, much of the opposition to raising the tax rate on the bulk of private equity’s profits has come from big buyout firms. Now it appears that a new group has joined the fight: minority and women investors.

headline: Measuring the High-Yield Debt Pile-Up
abstract: A string of debt offerings, many related to private equity buyouts, have recently crashed on the rocks of an imploding credit market. So how many of these deals have met with resistance from increasingly wary debt investors?

headline: New Ideas in Thin Computing – II
abstract: NComputing: the $70 computer for schools and offices?

headline: Time for the Spin Cycle?
abstract: If the buyout chill continues, more companies might try demergers, otherwise known as spinoffs, to get rid of unwanted business units without the help of a buyer.

headline: Reddy Ice to Be Sold for $1.1 Billion
abstract: Reddy Ice Holdings, the largest maker of packaged ice in the United States, will be acquired by GSO Capital Partners for $681.5 million. The total price of the deal, including debt, comes to $1.1 billion.

headline: Standard & Poor’s Cuts British Firm’s Debt Rating
abstract: A London money management firm, Cheyne Capital Management, may be forced to liquidate the assets backing its $10 billion commercial paper program in the latest casualty of the jittery credit market.

headline: Safenet Ex-C.E.O. Is Indicted for Options Fraud
abstract: The former president and chief operating officer of SafeNet, a maker of network security products, was indicted Wednesday on securities fraud charges in connection with the backdating of millions of dollars of employee stock options grants, prosecutors said.

headline: 21 Potential Suitors for Dow Jones, but Only One Bid
abstract: Advisers to Dow Jones discussed the possibility of a transaction with 21 potential partners after the News Corporation publicly made its $5.6 billion bid for the media company, but did not receive viable counteroffers from any of the parties, according to a filing with regulators.

headline: Citi’s Income Rises on Record Deal Advisory Fees
abstract: Citigroup said Friday that its second-quarter earnings increased 18 percent from a year ago to $6.23 billion. Revenue grew 20 percent to a record $26.6 billion, lifted by strength in investment banking and international markets.

headline: More U.S. Law Firms in London Like the Sound of M&A
abstract: London’s growing band of U.S. law firms are once again in the market for serious expansion. According to Legal Week’s annual survey of American firms in London, 47 percent of respondents would consider a merger with a British firm in the future, up from 39 percent last year and 29 percent in 2005.

headline: Bank of China’s $9 Billion Subprime Problem
abstract: The Bank of China, the nation’s second-largest commercial bank, said Thursday that it held almost $9.7 billion of securities backed by American subprime loans, the most of any Asian company.

headline: Yahoo to Buy Business E-Mail Service
abstract: Yahoo said Monday that it was buying Zimbra, a start-up that provides Web-based e-mail to businesses and institutions, as it seeks to extend the reach of its popular e-mail service and better compete with Google.

headline: Cramer’s Own Bond-Driven Meltdown
abstract: While the debt markets continue their convulsions — or their return to sanity, depending on whom you ask — one high-profile stock picker is calling for action in the strongest terms. On Friday afternoon, the voluble Jim Cramer appeared on CNBC to talk with Erin Burnett about Bear Stearns‘ latest hedge-fund-related troubles.

headline: Takeover Rumors Lift Quest Stock
abstract: Shares of Quest Diagnostics, the biggest United States medical testing company, jumped more than 10 percent Thursday amid renewed speculation that it is a takeover target. Speculation that Quest would be the target of a leveraged buyout is not new and surfaced earlier this year.

headline: Duff & Phelps Prices I.P.O.
abstract: Duff & Phelps, the financial advisory firm and investment bank, priced its initial public offering at $16 a share, below the expected range, raising about $133 million. PEHub.com said it was the first public offering backed by private equity this month.

headline: TPG Presents Iberia with Ultimatum
abstract: The Texas Pacific Group‘s 3.4 billion euro ($4.6 billion) bid for the Spanish airline Iberia is verging on collapse after Texas Pacific warned the carrier that it would pull its offer should it not receive an answer by the end of the month.

headline: Jaguar, Land Rover Won’t Fetch Ford’s Price, Report Says
abstract: Ford should not hold its breath for the 3 billion pounds ($6 billion) it hopes to get from the sale of Jaguar and Land Rover, The Telegraph reported Thursday citing unnamed sources.

headline: A Place to Rate (and Bash) V.C.s
abstract: Entrepreneurs are banding together on a new Silicon Valley-based website to alter the power structure between those hunting for cash and the venture capitalists who hold the keys to the coffer.

headline: A Bull Market Without Beer and Cholesterol?
abstract: A bull market that left behind Bud and Wal-Mart

headline: The happier man at McLaren – a semiotic analysis of driver hairstyles
abstract: The photo below not only shows who was happier after the qualifying session on Saturday – Lewis Hamilton who scored the pole or Fernando Alonso who finished second – but it also tells us in a subtle way which driver fits in better at the McLaren Mercedes team. Hamilton’s short McLaren hair fits in perfectly with the company image and work ethic. While Alonso instantly became cleaner cut with his very first appearance testing the McLaren last December – after years worth of the grunge image cultivated at Renault – his hair by comparison to Hamilton’s is infinitely less the McLaren look. We should have seen from the beginning the significance of this sign, as Alonso’s rebel tendencies were clearly there to be read from the outset: My hair will be cut thus far, but no further.

headline: In Blackstone Deal, a Hint of Gordon Gekko
abstract: There were probably a few chuckles on Wall Street this week when Blackstone Group, the giant private equity firm led by Stephen Schwarzman, announced that it was investing $600 million in a Chinese company called BlueStar.

headline: Clips: Snipes and Intros
abstract: — AMC’s first original series, the critically acclaimed “Mad Men,” has been renewed for a second season. The finale of season one airs on Oct. 18.

headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
