abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: Minor Magazines
abstract: Halsey Minor’s venture into publishing exploits user-generated content.

headline: Funds Hunt for Bargains in Canada
abstract: As banks, private equity firms and hedge funds eye deals for leveraged loans amid the credit crunch, deal-seekers are also reportedly circling Canada’s asset-backed commercial paper market, seeking to snap up securities on the cheap from distressed sellers.

headline: Judge Approves Dana’s Private Equity Infusion
abstract: Bankrupt Dana got a $750 million private equity infusion that the auto parts maker will use to fund vital union agreements as the fulcrum of its plan. A judge in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan approved the capital injection from a New York private equity firm, Centerbridge Capital Partners, Kenneth Eckstein, creditors’ counsel at Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel, told The Deal.com.

headline: Carrefour Takes a Spanish Shopping Spree
abstract: Carrefour is expanding its reach in Spain by agreeing to pay 200 million euros ($275.4 million) for 250 Spanish discount retailers, TheDeal.com reported. The Spanish stores are being acquired from a privately held German retailing giant Tengelmann Warenhandelsgesellschaft.

headline: Blackstone May Take Stake in Wind, Report Says
abstract: The Blackstone Group is in talks to buy a minority stake in Italy’s No. 2 fixed-line phone operator Wind, two years after it lost out in a bid battle for the company, according to Reuters. An Egyptian billionaire Naguib Sawiris bought Wind, the telecom unit of Italy’s Enel, in May 2005 for 12.1 billion euros ($16.45 billion) in one of Europe’s largest leveraged buyouts, topping a rival bid from Blackstone.

headline: Citi’s Non-Prime Mortgage Unit Opens for Business
abstract: From DealBook colleague Eric Dash:

headline: Kohlberg Kravis May Allow Covenant on First Data Debt
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts appeared willing to agree to a covenant, requiring certain financial ratios to be met, on the bank debt financing its $26 billion buyout of the First Data Corporation, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Google Goes Corporate
abstract: Google agrees to buy Postini, a company that offers message security services, for $625 million in cash. Eric Schmidt doesn’t mince words that the company is going full speed into the hosted corporate applications market.

headline: Losing Money on the iPhone and Making It Up on Volume
abstract: Apple is likely to make so much money from its cut of iPhone usage fees that it can sell the product at a loss and still make money.

headline: Big Law Firm Embracing Bankruptcy Practice
abstract: While other Manhattan firms are building up their bankruptcy departments, Cravath, Swaine & Moore, is just getting into the practice. For the first time in its history (parts of the firm date back to 1819), Cravath is forming a restructuring practice. And it has broken tradition to do so, by hiring a partner from outside the firm.

headline: After Pulling I.P.O., BioVex Gets Funding
abstract: The BioVex Group, a drug developer that withdrew plans for an initial public offering last year, has accepted $22 million in a new, fifth round of private funding that is still open to a new investor.

headline: Banking Group Eyeing Quintain Estates
abstract: Banking group HBOS is considering a 1.2 billion pound ($2.5 billion) bid for Quintain Estates and Development, which owns London’s Wembley Arena. The Times of London reported that HBOS’ corporate banking unit an 11.9 percent stake in the property company last week and is believed to have hired Merrill Lynch to look at the possibility of a takeover.

headline: Many Midsize Firms See Deals Ahead
abstract: Multibillion-dollar megabuyouts grab headlines, but smaller deals help pay the bills for many deal advisers. Consider the investment bank Lazard, which often advises on big-ticket transactions but recently created a unit devoted to middle-market work. So there could be a bit of good news in a recent survey, which found that many midsize companies have deal-making plans for the year to come, even though they are generally cautious about the economy as a whole.

headline: Sony Financial Plans $2.9 Billion I.P.O.
abstract: Sony will sell about 332 billion yen ($2.9 billion) of shares in its insurance unit in Japan’s biggest initial public offering this year, raising funds to invest in the consumer electronics and games divisions. The electronics maker will sell 725,000 shares, or 34.5 percent of Sony Financial Holdings, and the unit will offer 75,000 new shares, according to a statement Tuesday.

headline: Beazer Faces Formal S.E.C. Investigation
abstract: Beazer Homes USA said Monday afternoon that a previously disclosed informal inquiry by federal regulators has been raised to a formal investigation into possible violations of federal securities laws. In a regulatory filing, Beazer said that last Friday it has received a formal order from the Securities and Exchange Commission to determine whether anyone or any entity related to Beazer has broken securities laws.

headline: Blackstone to Advise Basis on Hedge Fund Losses
abstract: Basis Capital Fund Management, an Australian hedge fund manager, has hired the Blackstone Group to help it limit losses after being hurt by the rout in the subprime mortgage market.

headline: On Wall Street, Hiring Spree Meets Credit Crunch
abstract: Talk about market timing.

headline: U.K. Insurance Firms Lower Deal Hurdle
abstract: Two British life insurers, Friends Provident and Resolution, have changed the structure of their planned 8.4 billion pound ($17.1 billion) merger, with a simple majority of Resolution shareholders now needed to push through the deal.

headline: Short-URL Services: A Great Web Freebie
abstract: How to shrink those long ugly URLs.

headline: Nymex Is Said to Bid for Winnipeg Exchange
abstract: The New York Mercantile Exchange has emerged as the mystery bidder for the Winnipeg Commodity Exchange, Bloomberg News reported Thursday citing an unnamed source. On Wednesday, Reuters said that an unsolicited bid of C$50 million ($48 million) had been put forth from an unnamed group. The bid was C$10 million higher than one which came from Intercontinental Exchange in June.

headline: Blackstone I.P.O.: Buyers’ Remorse?
abstract: With the Blackstone Group‘s shares taking a beating on Wall Street, investors are feeling anger at the chief executive, Stephen A. Schwarzman, and are hoping he will do something to raise the flagging stock, The New York Post reported over the weekend.

headline: Weill Pays $42 Million For Chic New Address
abstract: The hedge-fund manager Daniel Loeb created a stir in New York’s real estate world when he agreed in 2005 to pay $45 million for a penthouse at 15 Central Park West, the uber-luxurious new condominium building set to open this fall.

headline: What’s On Tonight: “Survivor China”
abstract: Mark Burnett and Jeff Probst are at it again: the 15th installment of the powerhouse franchise “Survivor” premieres tonight at 8 p.m. on CBS. This time, the 16 American contestants will be transported to China.

headline: Solent Closes Battered Fund
abstract: In the latest instance of the credit crunch claiming a hedge fund victim, Solent Capital of Britain said Monday that it would wind down one of its funds because of the drop in value of its asset-backed securities.

headline: Despite Market Woes, Sellers Target Real-Estate Record
abstract: It may seem like a long-shot given the recent news from Wall Street, but a group of homeowners is holding firm on an ambitious goal — to break the record for the most expensive home sale in American history.

headline: Will Market Turbulence Dampen I.P.O. Ardor?
abstract: Some venture capitalists, who’ve seen improving conditions in recent years for taking companies public and cashing out investments, are worried the turbulence that has roiled financial markets this summer could spill over into their investment niche.

headline: Cumulus Buyout Has Analyst Singing Praises
abstract: The radio broadcaster Cumulus Media said Monday that it had agreed to a $1.3 billion buyout led by its chief executive and Merrill Lynch, reviving expectations of further deals in an industry struggling with weaker advertising.

headline: Calidora Skin Gets Funding From Fluke
abstract: Seattle-based Calidora Skin Clinic, which operates stores that offer skin care treatments and products, said it raised $4 million to expand into Southern California.

headline: Tully’s Coffee Sets I.P.O. Price Range
abstract: Tully’s Coffee, the Seattle-based coffee company, moved a step closer to its initial public offering, saying it expected to price its new stock between $10 and $12 a share.

headline: Amanda Congdon and ABC Part Ways
abstract: When Amanda Congdon received a contract to host a weekly show on ABCNews.com, the 25-year-old was heralded as “the first video blogger to make the jump to a major network” and described herself as “bridging the gap between old and new media.”

headline: Mr. Vranos Has a Deal for You
abstract: Hedge fund managers are not short on chutzpah, as a rule. But it takes a special kind of cheek to ask investors at this very tender moment in the housing market for $750 million to fund a new company specializing in subprime residential mortgage loans.

headline: Of SAT Scores and the Hedge Fund Manager
abstract: For many, the days of worrying about SAT scores are in the past. But for some hedge fund managers, the importance of those standardized tests (and their attendant No. 2 pencils) may come back to haunt them, or help them, depending on their college of choice.

headline: Sony Financial Slashes I.P.O. Price
abstract: Sony slashed the value of its financial unit’s initial public offering Tuesday.

headline: No Bad News Words
abstract: Euphemisms rule as Merrill makes “valuation adjustments.”

headline: Answers from Yang Fuqiang
abstract: Today we have answers to reader questions from Yang Fuqiang in Beijing. Mr. Yang is the chief representative of the Beijing office of the Energy Foundation, a San Francisco-based non-governmental organization that promotes energy efficiency. Mr. Yang began his career working in Chinese energy research and has spent three decades working on energy and environmental issues. His present work is focused on finding ways to help China use energy more efficiently, which, in turn, can help reduce pollution.

headline: MetroPCS May Need to Leap Higher
abstract: There was no Labor Day rest for MetroPCS Communications and its advisers, who spent the holiday weekend cooking up a $5.1 billion deal.

headline: Under Quadrangle, Maxim Turns to a New Page
abstract: The Quadrangle Group is expected to complete its $245 million takeover of the American portion of Dennis Publishing Tuesday and plans to immediately fold the struggling magazine Stuff, The New York Post reported.

headline: Candover Withdraws Offer for Stork
abstract: Candover, the British private equity firm, said on Monday it was withdrawing its 1.5 billion euro ($2.07 billion) offer for Stork, the Dutch industrial company, but that a new offer was still possible.

headline: Quick Bits: Better Late Than Never
abstract: With news on Microsoft, Vizio and Apple.

headline: Sun Valley: Stalking the B.M.O.C.
abstract: The Allen & Company summit in Sun Valley is a lot like high school, albeit with fewer available girls and a group of B.M.O.C.’s that are defined by net worth in the billions as opposed to what they can bench press.

headline: TissueLink Builds $20 Million in Series E Round
abstract: TissueLink Medical, a maker of devices that control bleeding during surgery, has completed a $20 million Series E round of venture capital. The round was led by previous investors Arnerich Massena & Associates and RiverVest Venture Partners.

headline: Critics Warn About ‘Carried Interest’ Bill
abstract: The Bush administration warned lawmakers on Wednesday not to raise the tax rate of private equity and hedge funds or their managers, maintaining that it would injure the economy and discourage risk-taking.

headline: Ayn Rand’s Literature of Capitalism
abstract: One of the most influential business books ever written is a 1,200-page novel published 50 years ago, on Oct. 12, 1957. It is still drawing readers; it ranks 388th on Amazon.com’s best-seller list. (“Winning,” by John F. Welch Jr., at a breezy 384 pages, is No. 1,431.)

headline: CME to Cut 380 Jobs After Merger
abstract: CME Group, formed out of the $12 billion deal that united the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade, said Monday it would cut 380 positions “across all departments.” Some of the positions being eliminated will be retained through June 2008 as transitional projects — notably trading floor integration — are completed, CME said.

headline: Merrill Lynch Invests in Indonesian Coal Project
abstract: Merrill Lynch has put its own money to work alongside a couple of hedge funds in yet another highly structured equity deal, which will provide financing for an Indonesian coal mine at a time when global demand for this commodity continues to increase, FinanceAsia reported.

headline: Highland Capital Fund Withdraws I.P.O.
abstract: Highland Capital Management, facing a sudden chill in parts of the credit markets, has pulled plans for an initial public offering of a fund that invests in collateralized debt obligations and other structured finance instruments.

headline: Inside the Countrywide Lending Spree
abstract: On its way to becoming the nation’s largest mortgage lender, Countrywide Financial often led potential borrowers to high-cost and sometimes unfavorable loans that resulted in richer commissions for Countrywide’s smooth-talking sales force, outsize fees to company affiliates providing services on the loans, and a roaring stock price that made Countrywide executives among the highest paid in America, according to The New York Times.

headline: Pallinghurst Raises Bid for Consolidated Minerals
abstract: Pallinghurst Resources Australia has increased its offer for Consolidated Minerals in an effort to thwart a rival bid from Territory Resources. Pallinghurst, an investment fund led by former BHP Billiton C.E.O. Brian Gilbertson, has now offered A$752 million ($662 million) in cash. Territory’s bid is higher at A$806 million, but includes stock, reported Bloomberg News.

headline: Bancrofts Meet to Consider Dow Jones Sale
abstract: As it assembles at the Boston Hilton on Monday to consider selling Dow Jones & Company and its main prize, The Wall Street Journal, to Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, the controlling Bancroft clan faces some stark choices.

headline: 3Par Joins Parade of Storage I.P.O.’s
abstract: 3Par this week became the third data-storage systems specialist in less than two months to file for an initial public offering. The venture-backed company hopes to raise as much as $100 million to finance its campaign against the established industry giants, the analyst firm 451 Group wrote.

headline: Canadian Bomb-Disposal Company Buys Rival
abstract: Canada’s Allen-Vanguard, which makes bomb disposal equipment, has struck a cash and stock deal worth 650 million Canadian dollars to acquire a privately held explosive-disposal company, Med-Eng Systems

headline: Dubai Group Eyes Auckland Airport
abstract: Dubai Aerospace Enterprise has its sights set on Auckland International Airport. In a takeover bid made Monday, Dubai Aerospace is seeking to acquire a 51 percent to 60 percent stake in New Zealand’s busiest airport.

headline: Ford C.E.O. Warns of Credit Impact on Jaguar Sale
abstract: Ford Motor Chief Executive Alan Mulally said on Wednesday that volatility in global credit markets was a concern in its disposal of British luxury brands Jaguar and Land Rover, but the conditions were not slowing down the sale.

headline: Crowning the Corporate Governance Elite
abstract: Move over People’s “Most Beautiful” and Forbes “400 Richest People” – the world of magazine lists has grown by one.

headline: Cedar Fair Is Said to Be in Takeover Talks
abstract: Cedar Fair Entertainment, the nation’s third-largest theme-park operator, has entered talks with an investment firm, Destiny Capital Solutions, about a $4.1 billion takeover, The New York Post reported Monday. As part of the deal, Cedar Fair’s management would remain in place for a period of time, and Destiny would commit between $500 million and $800 million to upgrade the company’s 12 parks.

headline: Kohlberg Kravis Steps Deeper Into Wall Street’s Territory
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘ ambitions to expand its capital markets capability make sense for the private equity firm — but what is good for Kohlberg Kravis is not always good for Wall Street, Lex writes.

headline: McLaren Mercedes drivers to be outclassed this weekend at the Nurburgring
abstract: I don’t think it’s all that fair, really. As a result of the spy scandal involving a top McLaren Mercedes staff member and 780 pages of data about their chief rival, Ferrari, the McLaren drivers have been forced to race this weekend in the Mercedes-Benz “S” sportscar pictured below. This is to ensure that McLaren drivers have no unfair advantage over the Ferrari drivers until the team has a chance to defend itself against accusations of stealing Ferrari intellectual property.

headline: IBasis Deal Goes to Shareholder Vote
abstract: IBasis, which carries voice over the Internet, will seek final approval from shareholders Thursday to merge with a unit of a Dutch telecom group, Royal KPN in a $55 million deal.

headline: Another Debt Offering Down the Tubes
abstract: And another one bites the dust.

headline: Sony Defeats Truman
abstract: A prediction that Sony might beat Microsoft in game console sales doesn’t quite pan out. The Nintendo Wii stays on top, of course.

headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: Evercore Adds Two Bankers in London
abstract: Evercore Partners doesn’t seem to be letting the credit crunch get in the way of its hiring plans.

headline: Quick Bits: AOL Shrinks, Dell Gains Support
abstract: What’s hot today, with reports on Apple’s latest products and iPhone software updates, hacking RFID passports, and updates on the fate of the online Wall Street Journal, and the F.C.C.’s wireless spectrum auction.

headline: Message to Gemstar: Don’t Sell to Private Equity
abstract: Private-equity firms have recently been enjoying a symbiotic relationship with hedge funds. Hedge funds buy stakes in companies, pressure them to put themselves up for sale, and then buyout firms swoop in to acquire them.

headline: Most Big-Company C.E.O.’s Await Millions in Severance, Study Finds
abstract: A study of 137 companies in the Fortune 200 has found that more than 71 percent of the chief executives are eligible for severance payments when their jobs are terminated without cause. The median potential payout? About $21 million.

headline: Athenahealth Soars 97% in Debut
abstract: Athenahealth rocketed 97 percent above its initial public offering price in its first day of trading on the Nasdaq, an encouraging debut for both company investors and the many venture-backed companies waiting in the queue.

headline: With Lerach Plea, Another Notch for U.S. Prosecutors
abstract: When the securities lawyer William S. Lerach pleaded guilty Tuesday to a conspiracy charge involving his former firm, now known as Milberg Weiss, one man was left standing in the federal investigation of the firm: its senior partner, Melvyn I. Weiss.

headline: Kraft Offers $7.2 Billion for Danone Biscuit Business
abstract: Kraft Foods offered $7.2 billion for Groupe Danone‘s cookie business to spur expansion in Europe. It is believed that the billionaire Nelson Peltz, who owns 3 percent of Kraft, is pressuring the company to accelerate takeovers to revive growth.

headline: As SunRocket Sets, No Joy in VOIP-Ville
abstract: So much for schadenfreude.

headline: Right90 Adds $12 Million in Venture Capital
abstract: In a second round of venture funding, a sales forecaster, Right90, raised $12 million. The company sells software used to predict sales and improve sales productivity.

headline: Do Bankers and Bikinis Mix? Bistro Owner Says Yes
abstract: Morgan Stanley, Lehman Brothers and Smith Barney recently forbade employees from entertaining clients at the Hawaiian Tropic Zone, a Times Square restaurant where the waitresses wear bikinis.

headline: Tribune Profit Falls as Buyout Looks Shakier
abstract: The newspaper publisher and broadcaster Tribune said on Wednesday that quarterly profit and revenue fell as newspaper advertising sales suffered. The results come as the company, which publishes the Chicago Tribune and Los Angeles Times, prepares to go private in an $8.2 billion deal led by the Chicago real estate tycoon Sam Zell.

headline: Cisco to Acquire Wireless Services Provider Cognio
abstract: Cisco Systems said on Tuesday that it would acquire Cognio, a company specializing in analyzing and controlling wireless networks, in the latest in a string of company purchases. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: The Real ‘Fake Steve’ Unveiled
abstract: The parlor game that has captivated high-tech insiders for the last 14 months has come to an end after The New York Times’ Brad Stone unmasked the man behind “The Secret Diary of Steve Jobs,” a blog that channels and lampoons Steven P. Jobs, Apple‘s chief executive and one of the world’s most famous businessmen.

headline: Old Buyout Investors Question New Money
abstract: Private equity and hedge funds often defend themselves by saying they manage billions of dollars for public institutions, and that the above-average, risk-adjusted returns they make translate to bigger endowments and better-funded pensions.

headline: Dimon Says Buyout Bridges Look Shaky
abstract: The pushback against easy debt for buyouts isn’t going unnoticed. James Dimon, the chief executive of J.P. Morgan Chase, warned on a conference call Wednesday morning that banks like his may be left holding more loans than they would like.

headline: Qwest Picks Phone Veteran to Succeed Retiring Chief
abstract: Qwest Communications named Edward A. Mueller, a telecommunications industry veteran and a former chief executive of the retailer Williams-Sonoma, as its new chief executive Monday.

headline: Virgin Media Loses Chief
abstract: Troubled cable TV company Virgin Media, which two weeks ago postponed its auction due to turmoil in the credit markets, suffered a fresh blow Tuesday with the news that its chief executive, Steve Burch, was leaving immediately for “family and personal reasons”.

headline: An Even Funnier iPhone Spoof Video
abstract: Maybe I was just tired and slap-happy, but I couldn’t stop laughing at this brilliant spoof.

headline: Glaxo Doubles Stock Buyback Plan
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline, whose shares have been weighed down by a negative report on its blockbuster diabetes drug Avandia, announced Wednesday that it was doubling its stock buyback program to 12 billion pounds ($24.7 billion) through 2009.

headline: EXCO to Tap Public Markets for $1.7 Billion
abstract: EXCO Partners, which was recently formed by oil and gas producer EXCO Resources, filed with U.S. regulators on Thursday to raise up to $1.725 billion in an initial public offering of common units.

headline: The Worst Best Team
abstract: It’s the weekend, and my attention wanders from credit crunches and bank rescues.

headline: Federal Court Delays Wild Oats Acquisition
abstract: The acquisition of Wild Oats Markets by Whole Foods Market was delayed Monday by a federal appeals court in Washington. The appellate court said that it needed more time to consider the Federal Trade Commission’s argument that the deal should be blocked pending the outcome of an appeal of a lower court ruling.

headline: Can Murdoch Charge for WSJ.com and Give It Away Too?
abstract: News Corporation may not give WSJ.com away free. It could instead bolster its free MarketWatch site and link it to the Fox business news channel.

headline: United Artists and Merrill Said to Be Close to Financing Deal
abstract: Tom Cruise’s United Artists movie studio and Merrill Lynch have essentially wrapped up negotiations over about $500 million in film financing, The New York Post reported. Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, which owns UA, and Merrill are combing through final deal points and should be ready to go public with the financing by mid-August, according to the report.

headline: Analysts Cut Earnings Forecast for Bear Stearns
abstract: Bear Stearns will earn less profit than previously estimated this year because of losses in fixed-income trading and hedge funds, according to two brokerage houses. Banc of America Securities and Deutsche Bank Securities on Friday cut their earnings forecasts and share-price estimates for Bear Stearns, a leading underwriter of mortgage bonds.

headline: The Vanishing Rating
abstract: From AAA to bad junk, in two easy steps

headline: NYSE Euronext 2nd Quarter Profits Rise
abstract: NYSE Euronext reported Thursday a second-quarter profit that more than doubled, getting a boost from record trading on its European stock and derivatives markets.

headline: Morgan Stanley Chief Is Host for Clinton Fund Raiser
abstract: Morgan Stan­ley‘s chief executive, John Mack, has invited senior staff to a fund raiser for Hillary Clinton on Monday, in what The Financial Times called “a pointed endorse­ment of the Democratic presidential hopeful from an important backer of President George W. Bush in 2004.”

headline: Discovery Said to Embrace Treehugger
abstract: Discovery Communications has scooped up a companion Web site to its upcoming Planet Green cable network, agreeing to buy Treehugger.com for about $10 million, The New York Post reported.

headline: Yahoo-Microsoft Chatter Rises Again
abstract: School kids aren’t the only ones returning from vacation. Dog-eared speculation about a potential deal between Yahoo and Microsoft is back as well.

headline: BlackRock Cofounder to Resign
abstract: BlackRock, the fast-growing asset-management firm that merged with a unit of Merrill Lynch last year, said Thursday that a co-founder, Ralph Schlosstein was stepping down as president to “pursue other entrepreneurial interests.” The company said Robert Kapito, head of portfolio management at BlackRock, had already been chosen to succeed Mr. Schlosstein, who will stay on as an adviser through early next year.

headline: Behind Silicon Valley’s Love of Silly Names
abstract: Even if you could say Abazab or Eefoof without snickering, would you want to do business with them? Would you feel OK owning Wakoopa shares in your 401(k)? Telling potential in-laws you met on Frengo?

headline: Chinese Banks Could Raise $1.46 Billion in I.P.O.s
abstract: The Bank of Nanjing and the Bank of Ningbo could raise a combined $1.46 billion in the first initial public offerings by Chinese city lenders, seeking funds to help fend off larger competitors, Bloomberg News reported Wednesday.

headline: 3i Reports Strong Figures, but Warns of Slowdown
abstract: The 3i Group, the publicly traded British private equity and venture firm, said Thursday it had doubled its investments and had had a 62 percent increase in realization proceeds in the first five months of its financial year. But it also warned that the debt market turmoil could affect new buyout deals in the coming months.

headline: More Companies Open Talks With Investors, Report Says
abstract: Shareholders participating in proxy votes so far this year are, no surprise, seeking greater accountability from corporate directors, especially on executive pay and majority share voting, according to an overview of the 2007 proxy season by Institutional Shareholder Services.

headline: Carlyle Goes Back to School in China
abstract: The Carlyle Group plans to invest $20 million in a China-based language school operator, the NeWorld Education Group, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Ex-Software Executive Begins Prison Term
abstract: Sanjay Kumar, the former chief executive of Computer Associates, now known as CA, began serving a 12-year prison term Tuesday for his role in a $2.2 billion accounting fraud at the software company.

headline: Gabelli Backs Topps Buyout
abstract: A noted investor and Topps shareholder, Mario Gabelli, said Tuesday that he would support the trading card company’s $385 million sale to Michael Eisner’s Tornante and the private equity firm Madison Dearborn Partners.

headline: New Ideas in Thin Computing – III
abstract: Another alternative to thin computing is embedding the PC’s operating system on a chip.

headline: Ryerson Defends Its Buyout
abstract: The steel services company Ryerson on Wednesday defended its $1 billion deal to be bought by Platinum Equity, despite opposition from a hedge fund, Harbinger Capital Partners, and said it had extensive discussions with potential buyers.

headline: Democratic Commissioner to Leave S.E.C.
abstract: Roel C. Campos, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission who sparred with agency Republicans over how best to penalize companies for securities law violations, will depart in a month for the private sector, the commission said Thursday.

headline: Nordic Group Sets Sights on Geothermal Financing
abstract: Glitnir,a Nordic financial group, said Wednesday it was positioning itself to play a leading role in financing geothermal energy projects in North America, an industry expected to draw about $40 billion in financing over the next 18 years.

headline: Sun Valley: No-Deal Zone? Not Quite
abstract: “You guys,” Richard Parsons said, indicating a nearby gaggle of reporters, “have to think that there is more going on here than there is.” The chief executive of Time Warner continued: “The plain fact is that you have to look at the how the conference has changed. We are dealing in a lot bigger issues than we used to — flat earth, terrorism, war — than just deals.”

headline: Investor With Ties to Putin Is in Talks to Buy Oil Company
abstract: The owners of Russneft, one of Russia’s largest private oil companies, are in talks to sell their shares and are near a deal with Oleg V. Deripaska, an investor with close ties to the Kremlin, a Russian news agency reported on Sunday, citing an executive at a bank with ties to the company.

headline: Buffett Said to Show Interest in Bear
abstract: A report by The New York Times that Warren E. Buffett

headline: L.S.E. Wins Approval to Buy Italian Rival
abstract: The London Stock Exchange shareholders voted in favor of the exchange’s proposed 1.63 billion euro ($2.2 billion) acquisition of Borsa Italiana.

headline: Sorting Through the Buyout Freezeout
abstract: With the buyout frenzy all but over and the credit markets in disarray, there is plenty of blame to go around — and some praise too. Which private equity firms have run headfirst into the crash? Which deals earned brickbats at the time they were signed, only to look wise now? And which buyouts now stand to be repriced?

headline: Google’s Washington Hazing for Its DoubleClick Deal
abstract: A Senate panel will look at Google’s proposed acquisition of DoubleClick on Thursday. After a lot of discussion about privacy, the consensus seems to be that the deal will be approved this fall.

headline: Resize This
abstract: Check out the amazing photo-resizing software developed by these guys. Turns out scaling and cropping aren’t the only ways to make a photo smaller.

headline: Wall Street Awaits Word From Lehman
abstract: Lehman Brothers on Tuesday will be the first of four big investment banks to report quarterly earnings this week, and its results are expected to get heavy scrutiny on Wall Street.

headline: Australian Iron Miner Buys China’s Sundance for $1.4 Billion
abstract: Gindalbie Metals, an Australian iron ore mining company backed by China’s third-largest steelmaker, agreed to buy Sundance Resources for 1.6 billion Australian dollars ($1.4 billion) in stock to add projects in Africa.

headline: Walmart.com to Customers: Stop Calling
abstract: When it comes to customer service, who needs a human touch? Not Wal-Mart’s online customers, apparently.

headline: New List of Best Law Firms for Women
abstract: New Survey by Working Mother Magazine and Flex-Time Lawyers Names Best Law Firms for Women

headline: New Offer for Winnipeg Commodity Exchange
abstract: WCE Holdings, the parent of the Winnipeg Commodity Exchange, confirmed Tuesday it has received an unsolicited takeover bid of 50 million Canadian dollars from an unnamed party, Reuters said. The new offer trumps a June bid by Intercontinental Exchange.

headline: UBS Ousts C.E.O. in Shake-Up
abstract: UBS said Thursday that its chief executive, Peter Wuffli, has stepped down after the Swiss investment bank’s board refused to appoint him as its next chairman. Mr. Wuffli’s departure comes amid a year of defections and the collapse of an internal hedge fund.

headline: Peltz May Step Into Wendy’s Auction
abstract: Nelson Peltz could be cooking up another food deal.

headline: DoubleClick Employees Worry About Gaining the “Google 15″
abstract: DoubleClick employees skip pizza and walk down the back staircase to sample organic pear tarts and chicken Tikka in Google’s famed cafeteria.

headline: Meridian Board Rejects Yamana Gold’s Bid
abstract: Meridian Gold‘s board of directors unanimously recommended that shareholders reject a revised bid from Yamana Gold, calling it “inadequate” in a statement on Monday morning.

headline: Once Goldman’s Hammer, Paulson Now Waits It Out
abstract: What happened to the Hammer?

headline: Alcoa to Sell Stake in Chinese Aluminum Producer
abstract: Alcoa, the world’s top aluminum maker, is selling its entire stake in Aluminum Corporation of China, or Chalco, for up to $2 billion, reaping a potential profit on its investment of as much as $1.9 billion.

headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: Imperial Chemical Rejects Akzo Nobel’s Sweetened Offer
abstract: Imperial Chemical Industries, the British maker of Dulux and Glidden paints, rejected a sweetened 7.77 billion-pound ($16 billion) bid from Akzo Nobel of the Netherlands as too low. Akzo, the world’s largest coatings company, raised its offer 8.3 percent to 650 pence a share.

headline: Buyout Firm Gets Extension After Falling Short on EMI Bid,
abstract: Terra Firma, the private equity group run by the British financier Guy Hands, has been given a last-minute extension by the Takeover Panel for its 2.4 billion pound ($4.9 billion) offer for the music group EMI. Before the deadline Sunday afternoon, Terra Firma had received less than 85 percent of acceptances, short of the 90 percent required to guarantee funding from its bank Citigroup.

headline: QuickBits: Farecast, Sony, SanDisk
abstract: Tech news from around the Web.

headline: Hedge Funds Sue to Block Arcelor-Mittal Deal
abstract: Three hedge funds that hold stakes in steel maker Arcelor are seeking a Dutch court order to stop the company’s takeover by Mittal Steel, which offers them a share swap they are not happy with, Arcelor said Thursday.

headline: Apollo in Talks to Sell Stake to Abu Dhabi, Report Says
abstract: Apollo Management and the investment arm of the Abu Dhabi government are reportedly in talks for a stake of the private equity firm, said CNNMoney.com citing a report in Thursday’s Wall Street Journal.

headline: Can eBay Take on Craig?
abstract: With its new free classifieds site, eBay faces an uphill battle against Craigslist – but it does have more resources to pour into the fight.

headline: When Italian politics and F1 politics meet
abstract: This is Monza, so what do you expect? Politics have been the big deal of the weekend, spy scandal-related politics. TV cameramen and photographers have been even more present and aggressive than usual every time a McLaren Mercedes driver in particular walks from one part of the paddock to the other, after the FIA drew the drivers into the spy scandal.

headline: Edgar Bronfman’s Big (Real Estate) Deal
abstract: Edgar Bronfman Jr. and his investor group reaped big profits from their acquisition and subsequent public float of Warner Music Group. Now, Mr. Bronfman might be about to repeat his success, this time with the sale of his New York City townhouse.

headline: Hedge Funds Thank Heaven for Lockups
abstract: Starting a couple of years ago, many privacy-loving hedge funds started using “lockups” as a way to sidestep a new rule requiring them to register with regulators. Under lockup provisions, investors’ capital cannot be withdrawn for some period, often one to two years. Funds with lockups of two years or longer were exempt from the fund-registration rule.

headline: Murdoch’s Deal History Shows Fickle Streak
abstract: Don’t count on Rupert Murdoch holding on to Dow Jones and the Wall Street Journal for the long term, warns Slate’s Jack Shafer, the media critic who has written many scathing columns about Mr. Murdoch since the media baron’s News Corporation made its bid in May. He’ll keep it long enough to destroy it, then sell it off, Mr. Shafer predicts.

headline: Hollywood Will Let You Copy Movies, Sort Of
abstract: A vote Wednesday changedthe legal agreement that governs the copy-protection system used on DVDs. Now people can burn DVDs at home.

headline: Powerset to Skeptics: Try Us
abstract: Powerset opens the kimono, a bit, hoping to turn skeptics into believers

headline: C.I.B.C. Comments on Subprime Exposure
abstract: Barron’s reported over the weekend that, according to “some observers,” the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce‘s exposure to the United States subprime mortgage market could be more than $2 billion.

headline: The Graying of the Web
abstract: Older people are sticky.

headline: From the Self-Referential Dept.
abstract: There appears to be a great desire to believe that Fake Steve Jobs just might be the real one. Reaction and counterreaction to the unveiling of the Apple chief’s alter ego.

headline: Assurances Fail to Halt Run on Northern Rock
abstract: Panicky customers of Northern Rock, the troubled British mortgage lender, have withdrawn 2 billion pounds ($4 billion), since the bank acknowledged Friday that it could no longer raise money because of the credit squeeze that has constrained global markets after a meltdown in the market for subprime loans in the United States.

headline: Networks Clash Over the Cume
abstract: A recent Nielsen rule change makes measuring audiences for television shows more difficult.

headline: Sainsbury’s Opens Books for Qatar Fund
abstract: J Sainsbury, the British supermarket chain, softened its opposition to Qatar’s 10.5 billion pound ($21 billion) takeover bid after Qatar said it would borrow less to fund the deal.

headline: Picis Buys Lynx With Help from Goldman Sachs
abstract: A hospital software maker Picis announced on Tuesday a $155 million debt and equity infusion from Goldman Sachs that it is using to acquire Lynx Medical Systems.

headline: BofA Buys $2 Billion Stake in Countrywide
abstract: Bank of America said Wednesday that it has agreed to invest $2 billion in troubled lender Countrywide Financial, buying preferred shares that carry an interest rate of 7.25 percent and can be converted into common stock at $18 each.

headline: Turkish Delight F1 style
abstract: It was not a great weekend for my photo harvest – too hot and too many other problems. Just imagine what it’s like for the men and women whose job it is only to take photos all day at every race – 36 degree Celsius temperatures, and elsewhere, rain, snow….

headline: Warner Music Hires Veteran Banker to Advise on EMI
abstract: As the deadline nears for its 2.3 billion pound ($4.7 billion) bid for EMI, the Warner Music Group has hired a veteran Wall Street banker, Alan Mnuchin, to advise, according to a report in The Daily Telegraph.

headline: Spark Lights Up With $360 Million Fund
abstract: Spark Capital, a Boston-based venture capital firm, has reported closing a $360 million fund, The Mass High Tech Business Journal said. The fund invests in the media, entertainment and technology industries. The new fund, Spark’s second, increases its total capital under management to $622 million.

headline: Ask Tina Fey
abstract: This time last year, as NBC introduced Tina Fey’s “30 Rock” and Aaron Sorkin’s “Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip,” the conventional wisdom favored Sorkin’s show.

headline: Financial Stocks Surge Ahead of Bush Speech
abstract: Goldman Sachs, Blackstone Group and Countrywide Financial were among the financial firms whose shares moved sharply higher Friday before the opening bell as investors eagerly awaited an announcement from President Bush about what steps the government would take to help Americans with their mortgages.

headline: Going Long on Divorce?
abstract: Amid the recent market turmoil, securities firms and hedge funds have been scrambling to escape from money-losing trades. But could another kind of Wall Street transaction — the one between husbands and wives — start unwinding as well?

headline: Backdating Conviction Rattles Silicon Valley
abstract: The conviction of Brocade Communications Systems former chief executive, Gregory L. Reyes, for conspiracy and fraud connected with options backdating sent shockwaves through Silicon Valley and law offices around the country and raised the prospect that prosecutors may be emboldened to pursue similar cases.

headline: K.K.R. I.P.O., Hilton Buyout: The Deals Keep Coming
abstract: Only a week ago, the buyout boom seemed ready to deflate.

headline: D.E. Shaw Gets Approval to Raise Stake in I.T.G.
abstract: D.E. Shaw, the giant quantitative hedge fund, seems poised to increase pressure on the Investment Technology Group, an electronic brokerage, to either sell off assets or buy back stock. But, given the current credit climate, the activist investor may have missed the boat.

headline: Macquarie Warns on Debt Fund Losses
abstract: Australia’s Macquarie Bank warned on Wednesday that retail investors in two debt funds face losses of up to 25 percent as fallout from the global credit crunch widened, knocking 10 percent off its shares.

headline: Wharton Halts Redemptions at Flagship Fund
abstract: Wharton Asset Management, one of London’s oldest and largest hedge funds, is halting redemptions at Y2K Finance, its flagship fund, until at least December because of credit market turmoil.

headline: A Company’s Stock Suffers, but Mostly in Silence
abstract: By its own measures, everything looks good at ACA Capital Holdings, a financial management and insurance company. But other numbers do not look so good, and the stock price is falling rapidly. The company will not comment on what is going on.

headline: Have the Days of Gordon Gekko Gone By?
abstract: With buyout kings swimming in wealth, markets in turmoil, and Ray-Bans back in fashion, it might seem like Wall Street has stood still since 1987. But to Oliver Stone, the creator of Gordon Gekko and director of the epoch-defining “Wall Street,” times have certainly changed.

headline: Fund Investors May Sue Bear Stearns
abstract: Investors smarting at losses from two Bear Stearns hedge funds, which were virtually wiped out by bets on risky mortgages, are studying the possibility of legal action.

headline: Is True.com Being Untrue to Advertising Partners?
abstract: The onetime Internet dating leader True.com is having problems paying its large advertising bills at major Internet sites, people in the industry say.

headline: Och-Ziff Continues Hedge Funds’ Public Path
abstract: Och-Ziff Capital Management‘s initial public offering would be the first by a pure-play American hedge fund, offering a rare glimpse into the performance, asset growth and profitability of these kinds of firms.

headline: Moving Against the Tide, Invesco to List in New York
abstract: Invesco, the big fund management group, plans to switch its primary stock exchange listing from London to New York, because investors in the United States now hold more than 50 percent of its shares and it believes it will benefit.

headline: Blackstone to Acquire Hilton Hotels for $26 Billion
abstract: The Blackstone Group announced Tuesday that it will pay $26 billion in cash for Hilton Hotels, in one of its biggest deals this year. The buyout firm will pay $47.50 a share for the hotel chain, a 40 percent premium to its closing price Monday.

headline: Bankers Worry the Sun Has Set on L.B.O.’s
abstract: A worsening credit crunch and its broad impact on financial markets has some dealmakers predicting that leveraged buyouts are on hold for the rest of the year and perhaps well into 2008, Reuters reported.

headline: Yahoo’s New President Oversees a Shake-Up
abstract: Susan L. Decker, Yahoo‘s new president, is putting her stamp on the company in a reorganization of its management ranks that creates a new division responsible for generating the bulk of the company’s revenue.

headline: Quadrangle to Combine Men’s Magazines
abstract: Stuff, one of the biggest of the “lad” magazines that took off in the 1990s, is being stuffed into its bigger sibling, Maxim, the publications’ new owners confirmed Wednesday.

headline: Blackstone Shares Move Above Offer Price
abstract: BX is back in the black.

headline: A strategic break, and a tactical F1 take
abstract: Yes, we’re in the middle of the August F1 break. So I decided it was the perfect time to indulge in a bit of fun recounting a story that takes a look at the sport from a kind of alternative angle, if you like.

headline: Goldman’s ‘Global’ Confusion Over Romney Investment
abstract: The current upheaval in the market seems to have banks so bemused that they are having hard time keeping their funds straight.

headline: K.K.R. Denies Delaying I.P.O.
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts on Wednesday denied a report by the Times of London saying that the private equity firm has put its $1.25 billion initial public offering on hold.

headline: Nokia Gobbles Up Twango
abstract: Twango, a media-sharing Web site founded by five former Microsoft employees, announced Monday that it had been acquired by the cell phone giant Nokia. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: ICE Prepared to Increase Offer for CBOT
abstract: IntercontinentalExchange, one of two bidders competing to buy the Chicago Board of Trade, said Tuesday that it is prepared to improve its offer for the futures exchange.

headline: Behringer REIT to Buy Canadian Rival
abstract: The Behringer Harvard Real Estate Investment Trust of Dallas is proposing to buy Canada’s IPC US Real Estate Investment Trust in an all-cash deal valued at about 1.4 billion Canadian dollars ($1.3 billion).

headline: Virgin Radio I.P.O. Still On Track
abstract: The new chairman of Britain’s Virgin Radio said the station’s initial public offering was on track despite financial market turbulence and persistent speculation that the business will go to a single bidder.

headline: Bell Canada Picks Buyer, But Auction Draws Criticism
abstract: Bell Canada agreed over the weekend to be taken private by the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan and the private equity firm Providence Equity Partners. The deal, worth about 51.7 billion Canadian dollars ($48.8 billion) including debt, would be the largest leveraged buyout ever and Canada’s largest takeover to date.

headline: I.B.M.: The Net Trumps Television
abstract: A new study from I.B.M. suggests Americans now spend more time browsing the Web than watching television

headline: It Keeps Falling Apart
abstract: A bleak picture, from WalMart to a REIT in trouble.

headline: Appeals Court Backs Whole Foods Deal
abstract: A federal appeals court has rejected the attempt by regulators to block Whole Foods Market‘s $565 million takeover of the rival Wild Oats Markets.

headline: Fugitive Fund Manager Arrested in Greece
abstract: A fugitive U.S. hedge fund manager who admitted defrauding investors out of millions of dollars was arrested in Greece on Monday, Greek police said on Tuesday.

headline: Lawmaker Who Criticized Blackstone I.P.O. to Hold Hearing
abstract: Democratic U.S. Rep. Dennis Kucinich seems to like setting ambitious goals for himself. Running for president is one. Slowing the rush of initial public offerings by managers of alternative assets (private equity and hedge funds) is another.

headline: What Goes Down Sometimes Goes Up
abstract: LCD TV prices have been dropping all year. But they bounced back in July and stayed stable in August, according to iSuppli. The roller coaster is heading down again for the holidays.

headline: Apple Flash: 270,000 iPhones in 2 Days
abstract: Apple said it sold 270,000 iPhones in the last two days of June. It expects to sell 1 million by the end of this quarter. Oh yes, the numbers. Apple blew away Wall Street’s profit forecast.

headline: Home Depot Confirms New Price for Supply Unit
abstract: Home Depot said on Tuesday that it was lowering the price of its wholesale supply unit business by nearly $2 billion, confirming media reports. As previously reported, the retailer will sell HD Supply to a consortium of private equity firms for $8.5 billion, while holding onto a 12.5 percent stake in the unit and backing $1 billion in financing.

headline: Genstar Buys PRA, Again
abstract: The private equity firm Genstar Capital of San Francisco announced Wednesday that it would buy PRA International for $790 million. If the deal goes through, it would mark the second time Genstar has owned a majority stake in the company, a drug industry contractor, but early reaction and certain terms of the deal suggest the offer may not hold water, The Deal.com said.

headline: South Korean Bank Ponies Up for First Data Deal
abstract: South Korea’s National Agricultural Cooperative Federation, better known as Nonghyup, will lend $180 million to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘ $26 billion purchase of First Data, a Nonghyup official told Reuters.

headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: Takeover Talks Buoy Nymex Stock
abstract: Wall Street registered its approval Wednesday of a potential takeover of the commodities exchange operator Nymex, sending the parent company’s stock higher. The share price jumped after the chairman of Nymex Holdings, Richard Schaeffer, said late Tuesday that the company had had preliminary discussions with a possible buyer. He said any deal must offer a meaningful premium to the current stock price.

headline: Citi, Credit Suisse Said to Fight Over China Venture
abstract: Credit Suisse and Citigroup are competing to secure a Chinese partner to set up an investment banking joint venture to tap the country’s fast growing capital markets, Reuters reported.

headline: L.B.O. Angst Hits Deutsche Bank Shares
abstract: Last week, fears about buyout-related loan losses were focused on investment banks in the United States. On Monday, those jitters hopped a plane to Germany.

headline: Cost-Cutting Plays Smaller Role in Buyout Profits, Report Says
abstract: Despite the image of private equity investors as ruthless, job-slashing cost-cutters, buyout shops make their profits primarily from expanding the businesses they buy, not from reducing expenses.

headline: Bancrofts Back Dow Jones Sale to Murdoch
abstract: Rupert Murdoch finally seems to have his grasp around his long-coveted prize, tentatively gaining enough support from the deeply divided Bancroft family to buy Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, for $5 billion.

headline: Bad News Bear? It’s All Relative
abstract: For a company that just had two big hedge funds evaporate, Bear Stearns seemed to be faring relatively well on Wednesday. Its shares were down 1.1 percent in late-morning trading Wednesday, far less than the after-hours decline of 3.6 percent they registered Tuesday night. That is when reports started emerging that two Bear Stearns-run hedge funds, worth an estimated $1.5 billion at the end of 2006, has lost nearly all their value because of mortgage-related bets gone bad.

headline: Will Credit Crisis End the Activists’ Run?
abstract: The recent credit crunch may strip activist shareholders like Carl C. Icahn of an important tool of their trade. The reason: Their strategies often depend on access to cheap capital.

headline: Prosecutors in KPMG Case Appeal Dismissal of Charges
abstract: Federal prosecutors have appealed a judge’s dismissal of tax fraud charges against 13 defendants from the KPMG accounting firm, but prosecutors may face a higher hurdle as they fight to get the faltering case back on track, The New York Times reported.

headline: Stalking the Next Virtualization Deal
abstract: VMware‘s spectacular I.P.O. and the acquisition of XenSource have only increased the already intense interest in virtualization software.

headline: Germany Looks Into Subprime Fallout at IKB
abstract: Prosecutors in Düsseldorf and government regulators in Berlin are looking into how a German bank became overexposed to the subprime mortgage lending crisis in the United States, but stopped short Friday of announcing a formal investigation.

headline: Barclays Posts Rise in Profit
abstract: Barclays, the British bank competing to buy ABN Amro, posted a 14 percent increase in first-half net income and said subprime mortgage defaults in the United States will not slow the investment bank this year.

headline: Former Kidder Bond Trader Ordered to Pay $8.4 Million
abstract: A federal court in Manhattan has ordered a former Kidder Peabody bond trader, Orlando Joseph Jett, to hand over more than $8.4 million sought by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Lindt Considers Bid for Godiva
abstract: The Swiss chocolate maker Lindt & Spruengli is considering buying Campbell Soup‘s Godiva Chocolatier brand, its chief executive told the Financial Times Deutschland newspaper.

headline: Huntsman Declares Apollo Bid Superior
abstract: Apollo Management, a buyout firm, scored a victory Friday when Huntsman, the specialty chemical maker, declared that the $10.4 billion offer from Apollo’s Hexion was superior to a previously accepted deal with a unit of Access Industries. That declaration gives Huntsman the legal right to negotiate with Hexion.

headline: Whole Foods and Wild Oats Head to Court to Defend Deal
abstract: Whole Foods Market and its rival, Wild Oats Markets, head to court on Tuesday, hoping to convince a federal judge to allow their proposed merger to proceed over the objections of federal antitrust authorities.

headline: Deerfield’s Triarc Deal Up in the Air
abstract: Triarc, the holding company controlled by billionaire investor Nelson Peltz, said Thursday that Rosemont-based Deerfield Triarc Capital hasn’t yet secured financing for its planned acquisition of Triarc’s stake in money manager Deerfield.

headline: HSBC Signs $6.3 Billion Deal for Korean Bank
abstract: HSBC  said Monday that it has agreed to buy a 51 percent stake in Korea Exchange Bank from the U.S. private equity firm Lone Star Funds for about $6.3 billion in cash as it attempts to increase its profile in South Korea.

headline: The Wait Is Over! News Corp./NBC’s NewSite has a Name.
abstract: The online video venture between NBC and Fox has a name: Hulu.com

headline: Deutsche Will Write Down L.B.O. ‘Mistakes’
abstract: Deutsche Bank, Germany’s biggest bank, will write down the value of leveraged loans and scale back hiring plans after making “mistakes” during the credit boom that ground to a halt in the past two months, the bank’s chief executive, Josef Ackermann, said.

headline: Dubai Group Is Said to Prepare Rival Bid for OMX
abstract: In a move that could thwart a proposed $3.7 billion merger between Nasdaq and OMX, the Dubai International Financial Center, owner of the Dubai stock exchange, is preparing an offer for the Nordic stock market group, Reuters reported citing a report in The Daily Telegraph.

headline: Ford Offers $78 Million for Stake in Romanian Car Company
abstract: Ford Motor has offered 57 million euros ($78 million) for the Romanian government’s majority stake in troubled carmaker Automobile Craiova, officials said on Friday.

headline: Goldman to Waive Fees to Lure Investors to Fund
abstract: Goldman Sachs waived fees to draw investors to its Global Equity Opportunities hedge fund after stock-market losses wiped out $1.4 billion of assets this month.

headline: Hollinger Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: Hollinger, the Canadian company that Conrad M. Black used to control his newspaper empire, filed for bankruptcy Wednesday and said it would explore options for the Sun-Times Media Group while facing payments on debt and shareholder suits.

headline: Bank of Beijing Seeks $2 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: China’s Bank of Beijing began a public stock offering on Monday in to raise up to 15 billion yuan ($2 billion). Bank of Beijing said it had set the price range for its offer of up to 1.2 billion A shares, or about 19 percent of its enlarged capital, at 11.50 to 12.50 yuan apiece.

headline: Subprime Troubles Sack HRJ
abstract: HRJ Capital, the investment firm whose partners include retired football players Joe Montana and Ronnie Lott, said one of its funds lost 12.3 percent in the first two weeks of August, erasing most of its 2007 gain, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Blackstone to Buy Stake in China’s BlueStar, Report Says
abstract: The Blackstone Group will buy about 18 percent of specialty chemical maker China National BlueStar Group for $500 million, Bloomberg News reported citing two unnamed sources.

headline: QuickBits: End of Summer Edition
abstract: With items on EarthLink, NBC, Dell, Yahoo and Google.

headline: Sears Names Former Capital One Executive C.F.O.
abstract: Sears Holdings said Monday that it had hired J. Miles Reidy to be its new chief financial officer. Mr. Reidy, an executive at Capital One Financial, will join the retailer next month.

headline: Dog Days for Goldman’s Global Alpha
abstract: Goldman Sachs‘s Global Alpha hedge fund, in which many of Goldman’s top clients are investors, fell 22.5 percent in August, registering its steepest monthly decline and leaving it down by about a third for the year.

headline: For Lawyers, Boom Also Brings the Blues
abstract: A rising tide, they say, lifts all boats. And law firms are no exception: recent years have bestowed a bounty upon the legal profession as work for mergers and acquisitions, leveraged buyouts and hedge-fund deals has surged. Profits per partner are rising because firms can charge clients more per hour. Lawyers at New York firms are making record salaries even as many of them grouse that they should be making more.

headline: J.P. Morgan, Goldman May Advise Apollo I.P.O.
abstract: JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs have been hired by Apollo Management to advise on on its expected initial public offering. The Financial Times said late Wednesday that this is the first sign of a comeback by other Wall Street banks after the early dominance of Morgan Stanley and Citigroup in the battle to underwrite private equity floats.

headline: Lewis Has Peaceful Intentions Toward Bear, Report Says
abstract: Joseph C. Lewis comes in peace, apparently.

headline: More From Bagehot, Gramley and Bear Stearns
abstract: Rising fears over American credit markets

headline: For The Woodruffs, An Off-Air Role
abstract: Bob Woodruff, the ABC News correspondent who was critically injured in Iraq in January 2006, returned to “World News” six months ago and has scored a number of journalistic coups since. He has repeatedly reported on traumatic brain injury suffered by American service members in Iraq — something he has intimate knowledge with.

headline: Convio Files for I.P.O.
abstract: Convio, which provides fundraising and advocacy software and services for nonprofit organizations, plans an initial public offering, according to a regulatory filing Thursday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Territory Aims for Consolidated Stake
abstract: Territory Resources has offered 966 million Australian dollars ($843 million) in a takeover bid for Consolidated Minerals, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: The Weird Psychology of Security
abstract: A noted security technologist talks about how the brain illogically measures risk.

headline: When Hedgies Drink Box Wine, That’s News
abstract: This just in: Hedge fund managers like to drink expensive booze, Dan Dorfman revealed Wednesday in the New York Sun. He reports that six hedgies showed up at Tse Yang, a Chinese restaurant in New York, and spent $4,800 on a single round of a rare cognac.

headline: The Most Privacy-Friendly Search Engine on the Web Is…
abstract: Microsoft and other major Internet companies are changing their privacy policies in the face of regulatory scrutiny.

headline: Telkom South Africa Enters Sales Talks
abstract: Telkom South Africa may sell the rest of a mobile-phone venture, the nation’s biggest, to the Vodafone Group and dispose of its fixed-line unit to the MTN Group. Telkom South Africa said in a statement that it was in talks with Vodafone and MTN over “mobile strategy.”

headline: Nine Million Viewers For “Kid Nation”
abstract: Not surprisingly, kids certainly seem to like “Kid Nation.”

headline: Funds Sue Wachovia Over LeNature Debt
abstract: A group of hedge fund firms is suing over what they say was a conspiracy to hide massive debt of the beverage maker LeNature from shareholders.

headline: SAC Said to Consider Minority Stake Sale
abstract: SAC Capital, the secretive hedge-fund firm run by the billionaire Steven Cohen, may become the latest manager of alternative assets to open the door — if only just a bit — to outside investors. The Financial Times reported Wednesday that the firm is considering selling a stake of as much as 20 percent to private investors.

headline: With Barclays, China Continues Overseas March
abstract: Monday’s announcement by Barclays that it had raised its offer for ABN Amro following a cash infusion from the China Development Bank and Temasek Holdings of Singapore was just the latest development in a takeover battle that has had more twists and turns than an Alpine pass.

headline: Web Video’s Audience Likes 2.7 Minutes at a Time
abstract: Most Internet users in the United States watch an average of three hours of online video a month, according to data from ComScore.

headline: Ignorance Is Not An Excuse
abstract: A CEO learns that ignorance is not a good defense.

headline: QuickBits: Calacanis, Moritz and Blodget, Oh My
abstract: What’s news on blogs and in online publications, with mentions of AT&T, Facebook and AMD.

headline: Doerr Rallies the Valley on Global Warming
abstract: John Doerr, the famous venture capitalist and guru of clean-technology investing, said Wednesday that there’s still a long way to go in the battle against global warming.

headline: V.C.’s Turn Back the Clock for Aging Rock Stars
abstract: Past-their-prime rock bands have a new groupie: venture capital.

headline: A brand (new) center
abstract: McLaren finally came out with its new “motor home.” As expected, this one outdoes every other one in the paddock. Unfortunately as it is now raining in Silverstone, I was unable to take great works of art photos of this new “motor home.” The last McLaren motor home was called the Communications Center, and now Vodafone McLaren Mercedes has decided to call this one the “Brand Center.” (Of course, they spell it “Centre,” but I will take the liberty of spelling it the other way.) I will also go into more details on it later and do some better photos when it stops raining. Suffice it to say that this thing looks like a space ship even more than the last one did. It looks like a flying saucer of a modernist kind. That’s outside. Inside it looks sort of like a church of a modernist kind.

headline: CDS Contracts on Investment Banks Surge on Debt Woes
abstract: Recent roiling in the debt markets has stirred fears about the health of the recent private equity boom. But the more immediate impact will be the investment banks left holding the bag on billions of dollars in loans meant to finance the deals.

headline: Lazard Tends to Its Own Deal
abstract: Lazard, which recently acquired a middle-market investment bank Goldsmith Agio Helms, is taking steps to avoid the integration woes that often afflict bank mergers, Investment Dealers’ Digest reports.

headline: NowPublic.com Eschews Takeover Bids for New Funding
abstract: NowPublic.com, a “citizen journalism” Web site based in Vancouver, announced that it had closed a $10.6 million round of financing from venture capital groups in the United States and Canada after having turned down several offers to acquire the company outright.

headline: A Few Lessons from Absolute’s Meltdown
abstract: Absolute Capital, the AIM-listed hedge fund that halted redemptions this week, built what appeared to be a gem of a record by stuffing its funds with U.S. penny stocks. But, after its investors pulled more than $100 million following the resignation of the company’s chief investment officer, it became clear these positions were completely illiquid.

headline: Layoffs at Bill Gates’s Other Company
abstract: Corbis, owned by Bill Gates, quietly lays off 15 percent of the staff.

headline: Regulators Cry Foul on Dubai’s OMX Stake
abstract: Borse Dubai‘s planned $4 billion cash bid for OMX seemed in jeopardy on Thursday after Sweden’s Financial Supervisory Authority ruled it broke the law when it bought a large stake in the Nordic market operator on August 9. But the regulator will allow the sale to continue.

headline: Investors Said to Push Canadian Exchange Merger
abstract: Major shareholders in the TSX Group, the parent of the Toronto Stock Exchange, and its rival, the Montreal Exchange have mobilized to push for a merger between the companies, a deal the two exchanges have discussed but so far failed to reach.

headline: National Grid Clears Hurdle to Keyspan Deal
abstract: In a deal that was originally announced in the winter of 2006, National Grid said Monday it had reached an agreement with regulators at the New York State Department of Public Service to close its $7.3 billion takeover of KeySpan.

headline: Crescent Investors Approve Morgan Stanley Buyout
abstract: Crescent Real Estate Equities said Wednesday that its shareholders overwhelmingly approved the sale of the company to Morgan Stanley Real Estate. At a morning shareholders meeting, 74 percent of the total shares outstanding voted in favor of the sale for $22.80 a share, Crescent said.

headline: Hearst to Buy Consumer Health Site
