abstract: Magazines and newspapers across the country are building up their Web offerings in health and fitness as their specialized advertising dollars and readers migrate online at a particularly rapid pace.

headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: NeurAxon Relieves V.C.s of $32 Million
abstract: Pain relief drug developer NeurAxon of Waltham, Mass., has secured $32 million in a second round of venture funding, twice the size of its first round.

headline: A few views from the paddock and elsewhere
abstract: There has been very little time for ruminating on the quality of life in the new paddock at Spa-Francorchamps in the past couple of days, but hopefully, over the next couple of days tensions will die out somewhat. Nothing I hear of the rumors making the rounds of the paddock today leads me to believe that this will be the case, however, so stay tuned for more “news of fresh disasters,” as fans of Beyond the Fringe might recall someone once saying, as I report either in the regular news and sports pages of the IHT or on this blog, the latest moves by the FIA and the other teams involved in the spy scandal.

headline: Changing Technology Politics: Cisco-Microsoft
abstract: Cisco and Microsoft join hands in peace and harmony, sort of.

headline: Ex-Wall St. Executives Go to Bat to Help Nonprofits
abstract: An organization founded by two former Goldman Sachs partners is using Wall Street methods to help charities raise money to finance expansion.

headline: Toronto-Dominion to Provide $3.64 Billion in BCE Takeover
abstract: The Toronto-Dominion Bank has agreed to provide 3.8 billion Canadian dollars ($3.64 billion) in financing for the proposed takeover of BCE for 34.3 billion Canadian dollars by the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, Providence Equity Partners and Madison Dearborn Partners.

headline: Ablation Frontiers Raises $21.8 Million
abstract: Ablation Frontiers, which develops treatments for cardiac arrhythmia, said it closed a $21.8 million round of venture funding led by Novartis Venture Fund. The round also included new investors Affinity Capital Management, Hexagon Investments and Trellis Health Ventures.

headline: Is Buffett Mulling a Play for Countrywide?
abstract: Does Warren E. Buffet have his eye on Countrywide?

headline: BlueArc Joins Parade of Data-Storage Offerings
abstract: BlueArc last week became the latest data-storage company to aim for an initial public offering. But, the research firm The 451 Group asks, how many independent storage specialists will the public market support?

headline: ESPN Deportes Makes Its Move
abstract: ESPN Deportes, the Spanish language version of the sports programming powerhouse, is moving off Time Warner Cable’s “en Espanol” tier and onto the digital basic channel line-up favored by viewers and advertisers.

headline: High Wattage at Sun Valley, but No Deals
abstract: There are a few givens at Allen & Company‘s rarefied annual summit for media moguls in Sun Valley, Idaho, including titans arriving in a conga line of private jets, attending some gold-plated panels followed by cocktails, and occasionally heading out to the paths of the Sun Valley Resort for a little speed-dating.

headline: Mohegan Sun Joins Race for N.Y. Tracks
abstract: Capital Play said that casino operator Mohegan Sun has joined its $1.8 billion bid for racetracks owned by the New York Racing Association, which is in bankruptcy protection.

headline: A Domain Name Worth $100 Million
abstract: The owner of Answers.com agreed to buy the owner of Dictionary.com for $100 million. If it can raise the money.

headline: Quick Bits: The Late Edition
abstract: With news from Sun, Sony and Intuit, among others.

headline: De La Hoya Gets into The Ring
abstract: The boxer Oscar De La Hoya has purchased The Ring, a magazine that has chronicled boxing since 1922 and is the oldest sports magazine in the country.

headline: Blackstone’s Swelling Lobbying Bill
abstract: Currying favor in Washington is no cheap task, as the Blackstone Group is learning.

headline: Understanding F1 press releases
abstract: Formula One’s annual summer break – I specify “summer” because this year I seem to recall something like a five week break after the first race and another three week break after the second or third race – is coming to an end. As it winds down and the teams and F1 personnel wind up for the Turkish Grand Prix this coming weekend, the team press releases are beginning to flow into our mailboxes. Beware team press releases.

headline: Text Message Gambling?
abstract: Limbo, a cell phone entertainment company says it offers a promotion that will keep the money from SMS message sweepstakes coming in.

headline: Laidlaw Reaches Agreement on $2.8 Billion Deal
abstract: Laidlaw International said that it expects federal antitrust regulators to sign off on the company’s long-stalled $2.8 billion agreement to be acquired by FirstGroup of Britain later this week, and the two companies now expect to complete the deal Oct. 1.

headline: Deutsche Bank Creates New Asian Post
abstract: Deutsche Bank has appointed Michael Leung to the newly-created position of director and head of asset backed securities trading in Asia, outside Japan. Mr. Leung comes to Deutsche Bank from UBS in New York where he was executive director of the fixed-income division.

headline: Building a Portfolio With Things, Not Paper
abstract: Zelda Cheatle isn’t only a London photography gallery owner, who managed to buy 4,000 photographs, including Pablo Picasso by Brassai and Malcolm X by Eve Arnold. She also manages a photography investment fund set up by London-based hedge fund WMG, which raised the money to buy the photos from a handful of investors.

headline: Och-Ziff Capital Files for I.P.O.
abstract: Another hedge-fund firm is opening its gates to the public. But will investors step up?

headline: Home Prices, Down Again
abstract: Home prices keep falling

headline: Swiss Cement Maker Raises Bid for Canadian Rival
abstract: Stock in the St. Lawrence Cement Group was bolstered Friday after its minority shareholders received a raised takeover offer from the Swiss cement maker Holcim. Holcim revised its offer to C$681 million ($651 million), up C$51 million from a previous bid, although it did not indicate the reasons for doing so, said The Globe and Mail.

headline: Virgin Media Gives Bidders More Time
abstract: The British cable operator Virgin Media postponed its $23 billion (11.3 billion) sale of the company on Tuesday after it became apparent buyers would not have access to the debt needed to do a deal right away.

headline: Sun Valley: Closing the Deal
abstract: DealBook is pulling out, having whiffed on his effort to hitchhike a ride back on a private business jet. But fear not. He phoned ahead to Continental and found that once he takes the puddle jumper back to the redeye on to Newark, there is a business class upgrade awaiting.

headline: Chief of Continental AG Hints at Going Private
abstract: Manfred Wennemer, chief executive of the German auto parts maker Continental, says he is not concerned about being the world’s biggest auto-parts supplier — even though the purchase last month of Siemens VDO moved his company closer to the leader, Robert Bosch.

headline: Productivity, Baseball Style
abstract: If rising productivity means getting the same results for less work, then baseball pitchers are more productive than they used to be.

headline: Punishment That Does Not Fit the Crime
abstract: Is six years enough for Qwest’s Joe Nacchio?

headline: Yankees’ YES Network Stake Not for Sale
abstract: Investors who were licking their lips Thursday on the news that YES Network might be up for sale may be disappointed to learn that only a portion of the Yankees channel is being shopped. The New York Times reported that Goldman Sachs is evaluating whether possible new investors in the YES Network would pay enough to place a value of at least $3 billion on it – about four times what it was worth nearly six years ago when it was formed.

headline: Delphi Accepts $2.55 Billion Financing Plan
abstract: Delphi and its former parent, General Motors, will lost out on more than $1 billion under the financing plan it accepted on Wednesday. But the investments, up to $2.55 billion and led by Appaloosa Management, will help bring the car parts maker closer to an exit from bankruptcy, The New York Times reported.

headline: Hedgehog Capital Takes Stake in Accredited Home
abstract: Hedgehog Capital has taken a 6.8 percent stake in the embattled mortgage lender Accredited Home Lenders, according to a regulatory filing.

headline: Hedge Funds Muscle In on Bally’s Bankruptcy Plans
abstract: A group of angry investors in Bally Total Fitness has made its own offer to block the struggling gym operator’s plan to file for bankruptcy protection. On Saturday, The New York Post reported, Bally said it had agreed to open its books to the shareholders who proposed an alternate restructuring plan.

headline: First Data Closes $26 Billion Buyout
abstract: Update: First Data has officially closed its $26 billion buyout by K.K.R. Michael D. Capellas, the former chief executive of Compaq, will replace Henry Duques as chairman and C.E.O., among other personnel changes.First Data appears to be right on time.

headline: Behind Energy Deal, Hedge Funds and Tax Breaks
abstract: Pogo Producing agreed Tuesday to sell itself to another oil and gas producer for $3.5 billion in cash and stock, but the deal with Plains Exploration & Production was as much about shareholder activism and taxes as it was about energy.

headline: Top Banks Tap Federal Reserve for Financing
abstract: The country’s four biggest banks announced Wednesday that they had each borrowed $500 million from the Federal Reserve, taking an unusual step to ease the credit squeeze that has been rattling the financial system for weeks.

headline: Carlyle to Acquire Manor Care for $6.3 Billion
abstract: The Carlyle Group is starting the summer in heavy deal-making mode. Less than a week after it and a partner agreed to buy a unit of General Motors for $5.6 billion, the Washington-based private equity firm announced plans to acquire Manor Care, a nursing-home operator, in a $6.3 billion transaction. (Carlyle is also said to be considering a bid for Britain’s Virgin Media.)

headline: Microsoft’s Ballmer Dodges Yahoo Deal Talk
abstract: Try as he might, not even veteran interviewer Charlie Rose could get Microsoft‘s chairman and chief executive, Steve Ballmer to disclose whether the company continues to mull an acquisition of Yahoo.

headline: Brocade Jury Breaks for Weekend
abstract: The jury in the first criminal trial associated with stock-option backdating adjourned early Friday afternoon without returning a verdict.

headline: Ripplewood Hitches Former Ford Executive to Its Wagon
abstract: Former auto-industry executives continue to find new homes at private equity firms. The latest example is Sir Nicholas Scheele, a former president of Ford Motor, who has joined Ripplewood Holdings to help in its bid to buy Jaguar and Land Rover from his former employer, BusinessWeek writes.

headline: Dow Chemical Said to Prepare Imperial Bid
abstract: Dow Chemical, the largest chemicals group in the United States, is considering making a rival offer for Imperial Chemical Industries, the British maker of Dulux paints, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Hedge Fund Says No Plans for Stake Sale
abstract: Renaissance Technologies, the hedge fund group led by the mathematician James Simons, said there was “no truth” to a recent report that it may sell a minority stake.

headline: Quick Bits: Monday Morning Tech News
abstract: Quick Bits: The day’s news about the F.C.C., Microsoft, Monster, Verizon, Adobe, NowPublic.

headline: Vodafone Is Said to Consider Deals in Italy, Spain
abstract: Vodafone is considering buying telecoms infrastructure in Italy and Spain to allow it to supply fixed-line broadband to its mobile phone customers, The Financial Times reported Thursday. Vodafone is mulling an offer for fixed-line networks in Italy and Spain owned by Tele2, a Swedish telecoms company.

headline: Alcoa Hires Former Siemens C.E.O.
abstract: The aluminum company Alcoa named Klaus Kleinfeld, the former chief executive of Siemens, president and chief operating officer Wednesday, and said he would most likely take over as chief executive when Alain J. P. Belda retired.

headline: Northeastern Banks Consolidate in Two Deals
abstract: In two separate deals valued at more than $500 million each, a quartet of Northeast banks consolidated on Thursday, TheDeal.com reported. M&T Bank agreed to buy Partners Trust Financial Group for about $555 million and PNC Financial Services Group will acquire Sterling Financial for $565 million.

headline: Funds Circle Northern Rock
abstract: A consortium of private equity and hedge fund firms are reportedly plotting a break-up of an ailing British lender, Northern Rock, that could generate profits of hundreds of millions of pounds from the stricken mortgage bank – but leave shareholders with virtually nothing.

headline: S.E.C. Sues Sentinel for Fraud
abstract: It’s been a bad few days for the Sentinel Management Group.

headline: S.E.C. to Publish 2 Shareholder Proposals
abstract: A bitterly divided Securities and Exchange Commission agreed on Wednesday to issue for public comment two proposals – one that could overturn a court decision giving shareholders more sway over board elections, and a second that would grant shareholders some influence.

headline: Goldman Names Co-Head of Investment Management
abstract: Goldman Sachs appointed Edward Forst co-head of its investment-management unit, a business that oversees more than $796 billion in assets, including the Global Alpha hedge fund, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Warner Bros. and NBC A Little Closer
abstract: Warner Bros. and NBC Universal Television Stations have announced the first syndicated production for fall 2008: a talk show hosted by Bonnie Hunt, the actress, comedian and frequent Letterman guest.

headline: ITT to Buy Aerospace Company EDO
abstract: Defense contractor ITT said Monday it is buying EDO, an aerospace and defense company, for about $1.19 billion in cash to broaden its presence in other markets.

headline: Guilty Plea for Couple in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Morgan Stanley finance vice president and her husband, a former hedge fund analyst at ING Investment Management, pleaded guilty Wednesday to conspiracy and insider trading.

headline: No Bank Bailouts, Britain Says
abstract: Britain’s Treasury chief, Alistair Darling, told the Labor Party’s annual convention on Sunday that Britain would not protect businesses that make bad judgments, despite a billion-dollar rescue of a struggling bank.

headline: Spy scandal moves to the court of appeal
abstract: Given the statements various Ferrari team members have been making since McLaren Mercedes was let off the hook in the spy scandal last week, it is of little surprise that the case is now moving to the FIA Court of Appeal, after a request from the Italian Automobile Club. What I find most interesting, however, are all of the details of the F1 scandal that the FIA has now released to the public. These answer some of the questions we have been asking on this site in the past couple of weeks, and show why it is dangerous to jump to conclusions about what happened when we do not have all of the facts about the case.

headline: Quick Bits: Hasta La Vista, Vista?
abstract: This is going to have to be really quick today. If you are stuck in an elevator today with some techie, you can probably fake it with this:

headline: The Accoona Files 1: A Search Company?
abstract: Notes on Accoona’s search business: There’s not much R&D spending. SuperTargeted search doesn’t work.

headline: Quick Bits: Dell Tries Zing, Steve Case Sells Lime, Palm Hears Silence
abstract: Hot stories today from Microsoft, Apple, Palm, Buy.com, Dell and more.

headline: Capital One to Close Residential Mortgage Unit
abstract: In yet another casualty of the fallout in the mortgage industry, Capital One Financial said Monday that it would stop making residential mortgages and close GreenPoint Mortgage, its wholesale mortgage banking unit.

headline: Lawmakers Turn to Buyout Tax Bills
abstract: A bill that would affect much of the private equity industry by raising taxes on carried interest has a “good shot at passing in the House before year’s end,” The Washington Post reported Tuesday. But its prospects in the Senate are not as strong, the newspaper said.

headline: SoloPower Closes $30 Million Funding Round
abstract: SoloPower, a maker of photovoltaic cells used in solar panels, said it raised $30 million in a Series B round of venture funding. Oslo-based Convexa Capital, a new investor, led the round, much of which will go toward building up a manufacturing plant, SoloPower’s chief executive said.

headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: Blackstone Eyes $500 Million Stake in Chinese Chemical, Report Says
abstract: The Blackstone Group plans to take a 20 to 40 percent stake in a chemical maker, China National BlueStar, for up to $500 million, according to Reuters.

headline: More Signs of a Chill in Buyout-Land
abstract: Even before the recent turmoil in the credit markets, the $6.1 billion buyout of Affiliated Computer Services was already on shaky ground.

headline: Hedge Fund Managers Sue Akin Gump
abstract: In what The New York Law Journal regards as a cautionary tale, two former managers of a collapsed hedge fund, Veras Investment Partners, are suing Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld, claiming that the law firm advised them that the late trading that led to the fund’s collapse was legal.

headline: Lewis Hamilton crashes, unhurt – but ….
abstract: Lewis Hamilton’s McLaren Mercedes broke apart with five minutes left during the last qualifying session today, sending the championship leader flying off the track into a tire barrier. The impact was so heavy that the driver was clearly shocked, and was unable to stand up after the accident. He was taken to the medical center where track doctors declared he was unhurt, broke no bones, and would spend a couple of hours resting under observation, according to a McLaren team spokesman. There is as yet no word as to whether or not he will race tomorrow. I will update the news as it develops.

headline: Collateral Damage as the Buyout Boom Ends
abstract: The abrupt halt to the private-equity boom will create some serious fallout on Wall Street and beyond, Andrew Ross Sorkin wrote in his Sunday DealBook column in The New York Times. It doesn’t just spell the end of those record-breaking bonuses that bankers have been enjoying, it could mean some serious across-the-board slashing of jobs.

headline: C.I.B.C. Says 3Q Profit to Beat Expectations
abstract: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce said on Monday it expects to report higher third-quarter profit than analysts had expected despite taking a hit on the subprime mortgage debacle in the United States.

headline: Should Yahoo Try Again for Facebook?
abstract: Yahoo clearly wants a seat on the social-networking train. But how much should it spend for a ticket?

headline: Appeals Court Rejects Kerkorian’s Daimler Suit
abstract: A U.S. federal court has upheld a lower court ruling that investor Kirk Kerkorian is not entitled to damages over the $36 billion merger of Daimler-Benz and Chrysler nine years ago, DaimlerChrysler said Wednesday.

headline: Canadian Investment Firm Snags Hotel REIT
abstract: British Columbia Investment Management has struck a deal worth 1.2 billion Canadian dollars ($1.1 billion) to acquire the Canadian Hotel Income Properties Real Estate Investment Trust, offering 19.10 Canadian dollars per unit.

headline: For Buffett Lunch Winner, Fifth Time’s the Charm
abstract: Two investors bid $650,100 in an annual charity auction to win the chance to dine with billionaire Warren Buffett. Mohnish Pabrai, who manages about $600-million for Pabrai Investment Funds in California, teamed up with a friend to bid $30,000 more than last year’s winning sum. Mr. Pabrai said he bid unsuccessfully in the previous four auctions.

headline: Brazilian Sugar Giant Raises $1.2 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: Fueled by its global ethanol business, the Brazilian sugar giant Cosan, which bills itself as the largest grower and processor of sugar cane in the world, said Monday it closed a $1.2 billion initial public offering. Shares of Cosan listed in the United States closed at $10.05 a share on Friday.

headline: Dodd Backs Banks in Enron Suit
abstract: Senator Christopher Dodd, who heads the Senate Banking Committee, joined a number of lawmakers and officials of both parties Tuesday in calling on the Bush administration not to side with defendant companies in a Supreme Court case that could determine the fate of a separate Enron lawsuit.

headline: Tip of the Week: Where to Share Photos With Others
abstract: Flickr, the popular photo-sharing site, recently redesigned its Web form to let users upload their images more efficiently.

headline: HDTV Recordings Need More Room
abstract: How much more hard drive space does it take to record a program in high definition than it takes in standard definition?

headline: Tip of the Week: Mobile-Friendly Web Sites
abstract: How to find Web sites that offer slimmed-down versions of images for mobile devices.

headline: Stop Completing My Thoughts
abstract: When I address an e-mail to “Mary,” my program lists all the Marys to whom I have ever sent messages. Is there a way to eliminate the name of a person I no longer wish to see on this list?

headline: A Math Test for Bargain Hunters
abstract: Is it more appealing to hear that a product is selling at a 50 percent discount or to hear that it has been marked down twice, first by 25 percent and then by a further 33 percent? The two options come out to the same result, of course. But a paper in the Journal of Consumer Research reports that consumers tend to prefer the second option, since they often proceed by the flawed arithmetical process of adding the two sale percentages together to get 58 percent.

headline: Cellphone-Only Homes Hit a Milestone
abstract: From September 2006 to April 2007, the percentage of Americans in cellphone-only households for the first time overtook the percentage in landline-only households.

headline: Excerpts From ‘Dawn Evening or Night’
abstract: Following are excerpts, translated by The New York Times and printed with permission of the publisher, from “Dawn Evening or Night,” a book by the playwright Yasmina Reza about President Nicolas Sarkozy of France:

headline: Memory Cards for Antiquity
abstract: How long can I store pictures on a memory card?

headline: Politely Refusing Word’s Help
abstract: When I am making lists in Microsoft Word, the program automatically capitalizes the first letter of each word when I press the return key. How can I make it stop doing this?

headline: The Router’s Fine Print
abstract: Why does all the fine print on the newest, fastest network routers say “draft specification”? What does this mean if I want to buy a new router?

headline: In Myanmar, U.N. Envoy Meets Dissident
abstract: The envoy met today with the detained opposition leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and with members of Myanmar’s military junta.

headline: Pillow Talk for the Weary
abstract: Yet another wave of bed amenities is here, with lighter, softer sheets that keep you cool, and thicker mattresses that can feel better than the one you have at home.

headline: British Mosques Teach Civics to Combat Extremism
abstract: The British government is financing an effort to teach a special curriculum intended to reach students who might be vulnerable to Islamic extremism.

headline: Abbas Plays on Hamas Boycott to Keep His Cabinet in Place
abstract: With parliament unable to meet, Mahmoud Abbas can extend the life of the emergency cabinet he appointed after Hamas took over Gaza.

headline: Washington Taking a Look at Air-Traffic Problems
abstract: The Transportation Department has been sending signals that it is determined to take some action to address air traffic delays across the nation.

headline: From Iraq’s Rumor Mill, a Conspiracy of Badgers
abstract: Many residents of Basra have convinced themselves that the British Army has loosed savage cattle-eating badgers onto its unsuspecting populace as a final gesture of ill intent.

headline: Bodies Found in Mexico City May Be Victims of 1968 Massacre
abstract: After two decades of fear and silence, an architect has come forward to say that bodies that may belong to student protesters killed in 1968 are buried under a hospital in Mexico City.

headline: Archive to Expand Access to Files on the Holocaust
abstract: Access to the vast archive of records created by the Nazi government during the Holocaust, long open primarily to survivors, is being opened to scholars for the first time.

headline: Your Ad Here, on My S.U.V.? And You’ll Pay?
abstract: Thousands of motorists have agreed to wrap their cars in advertisements in exchange for up to $800 a month.

headline: Britain: 4 Get Prison in Cartoon Case
abstract: Four men were sentenced to prison for inciting murder and racial hatred last year during a raucous demonstration against the publication of cartoons of the Prophet Mohammed. Marching among several hundred protesters in front of the Danish Embassy here, the men had called for the death of those responsible for publishing the cartoons, which were first published in a Danish newspaper in 2005. Three of the men  Mizanur Rahman, 24, Umran Javed, 27, and Abdul Muhid 25  were sentenced to six years in prison; the fourth, Abdul Saleem, 32 was sentenced to four years.

headline: CARE Turns Down Federal Funds for Food Aid
abstract: CARE, one of the world’s biggest charities, said that American food aid may hurt the people it aims to help.

headline: ‘Core Issues’ Raised in Mideast Talks
abstract: It was unclear how detailed the talks between Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert and Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas were.

headline: Airline Alliances Aim for New Efficiencies and Traveler Loyalty
abstract: Airline alliances can deliver a level of consistency and confidence that transcends individual carriers.

headline: Burmese Junta Sets Curfew to Combat Protests
abstract: It was the most ominous situation that tens of thousands of Buddhist monks and their supporters have yet seen during a month of demonstrations.

headline: Forget the Calendar: The Beauty Is in 30 Days of Marketing
abstract: The Hearst Magazines division of the Hearst Corporation is bringing back for a second year a multimedia campaign called 30 Days of Fashion.

headline: Fortis Shareholders Back ABN Amro Bid
abstract: Shareholders of Fortis, which is part of a group bidding for ABN Amro, voted on Monday in the first of two meetings to support what would be the world’s largest banking takeover.

headline: Iranian Raises Possibility of an Intrusion Into Iraq
abstract: Iranian diplomats suggested that Iran might respond militarily if the Iraqi government failed to prevent militants from crossing in to Iran to carry out attacks.

headline: Bush Vows a Veto on Any Tax Increase
abstract: President Bush described the economy as “thriving” and said lower taxes were the best way to guarantee prosperity.

headline: Toyota Says Quarterly Profit Jumped 32%
abstract: Toyota reported a 32 percent rise in second-quarter profits and strong sales in North America as the company seeks to widen its lead over G.M. as the world’s largest automaker.

headline: Suicide Bombing Kills 27 Afghans
abstract: A bomber wearing an Afghan military uniform approached a bus full of Afghan soldiers on their way to work and detonated a belt of explosives.

headline: Record Failures at Oil Refineries Raise Gas Prices
abstract: A third of the country’s oil refineries have reported disruptions like fires, power failures, leaks, spills and breakdowns this year.

headline: Alerts Do Not Keep Public From Diana Tribute
abstract: To many Britons, a concert in honor of Princess Diana was  a chance to show, as Gordon Brown vowed, that “we will not allow anyone to undermine our British way of life.”

headline: Marine’s Defense Team Ends Haditha Hearing Abruptly
abstract: The hearing for a Marine squad leader accused of killing 17 Iraqi civilians in Haditha in 2005 ended abrubtly on Thursday after only three days of testimony.

headline: Germany: Bank Posts Big Loss
abstract: IKB Deutsche Industriebank, the bank that is being bailed out after investing in subprime loans, will post a loss of up to 700 million euros, or $954 million, for the fiscal year. The chief executive, Günther Bräunig, said during a conference call that the bank would curtail investments in international securities financed by commercial paper, a type of short-term business loan, and that it expected future earnings to be “significantly lower.” The bank had a profit of 179.6 million euros in the year that ended March 31. The government-owned KfW development bank and the German banking associations agreed to cover some losses at IKB after rising defaults on home loans hurt the value of mortgage-backed securities.

headline: A Medical Publisher’s Unusual Prescription: Online Ads
abstract: The international media giant Reed Elsevier hopes to pep up its lackluster medical publishing unit by giving away the latest articles from 100 of its own medical journals on the Internet.

headline: Good Times, Bad Times: Make a Deal
abstract: Buyout firms have drawn upon a seemingly bottomless wellspring of investors’ money and extraordinarily lenient lending terms to close ever-larger deals.

headline: Travel Information and Dinner Reservations in the Palm of Your Hand
abstract: Handmark Pocket Express Travel Edition works with BlackBerry, Palm and Windows Mobile cellphones and other P.D.A.’s.

headline: Treasury Bills Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The Treasury Department’s schedule of financing this week includes today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: Welcome or Not, Orthodoxy Is Back in Russia’s Public Schools
abstract: The drive by a revitalized Russian Orthodox Church to weave its tenets into the education system has prompted a backlash.

headline: 2 Ex-Officials of Take-Two Plead Guilty
abstract: The former chief lawyer and chief account of the maker of the Grand Theft Auto video games pleaded guilty Thursday to falsifying business records.

headline: U.S. Is Seen in Iraq Until at Least ’09
abstract: The American command in Baghdad has prepared a detailed classified plan that calls for restoring security in local areas by the summer of 2008.

headline: Ready for Anything (That’s Their Job)
abstract: Emergency management has emerged as a formal career path.

headline: Foot Locker Reports First Loss in 6 Years
abstract: The second-quarter net loss was $18 million, or 12 cents a share, in contrast to a profit of $14 million, or 9 cents, a year earlier.

headline: Registered Traveler Program Remains a Work in Progress
abstract: In a Congressional hearing last week, a major backer of Registered Traveler programs criticized the Transportation Security Administration.

headline: Rising Breed of Migrant: Skilled and Welcome
abstract: As legions of workers across the globe face new barriers to migration, professionals find more welcome mats.

headline: Apple Quarterly Profit Rises on Mac Sales
abstract: The results exceeded analysts' expectations as the company reported strong sales of its Macintosh computers and sold 270,000 iPhones.

headline: Anti-Inflation Curbs on Prices Create Havoc for Zimbabwe
abstract: Zimbabwe’s week-old campaign to quell its rampant inflation by forcing merchants to lower prices is edging the nation close to chaos, some economists and merchants say.

headline: North Koreans Say They’ve Shut Nuclear Reactor
abstract: The North Korean claim, which was synchronized with the arrival of a shipment of fuel oil from South Korea, marked the first step toward reversing a confrontation with the U.S.

headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: Government May Raise Limits on Home-Loan Purchases
abstract: Hoping to increase liquidity in the mortgage market, the secretary of housing and urban development suggested that the government might raise the limit on purchase of home loans by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

headline: Obstacles Abound for Auto Builders in India
abstract: Indian automakers are plagued by a shortage of skilled workers, inferior product quality and deficient highway infrastructure, among other challenges, according to a new study.

headline: No Suitcase Is Safe
abstract: Some airports in Latin America and Africa are known for high rates of theft, but experts say airport baggage thieves prosper in the U.S. as well.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: LOOKING TO THE FED While the markets have stabilized a bit, investors still wonder whether the Federal Reserve will cut the federal funds rate. They will be scrutinizing any remarks made on Friday by the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, at the annual symposium of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Mo., in Jackson Hole, Wyo., which continues Saturday.

headline: Bodies of 4 Afghan Judges Are Found
abstract: The grim discovery today in Ghazni province heightened concerns for the fate of a group of South Korean hostages.

headline: Pushing Fed to Act Early if Not Often
abstract: In the future, the Federal Reserve Bank should push harder against a bubble while it is still inflating.

headline: In Google Earth, a Service for Scanning the Heavens
abstract: After turning millions of Internet users into virtual explorers of the world, the Internet search giant is now hoping to turn many of them into virtual stargazers.

headline: China: Reporter Arrested for Faking Food Report
abstract: A television reporter was arrested for fabricating video purporting to show a vendor selling steamed buns made of cardboard soaked in chemicals, the police in Beijing said. The arrest came as the Chinese authorities stepped up efforts to counter widespread reports of safety problems affecting exports of foodstuffs and other products.

headline: Hurricane Weaker, but Still a Threat
abstract: Hurricane Dean began battering Mexico’s Gulf coast as residents fled or hunkered down at home.

headline: Capital One Financial to Quit Residential Mortgage Business
abstract: The company also said it would close its wholesale mortgage banking unit and lay off roughly 1,900 employees.

headline: Mark Weil, Tashkent Theater Director, Dies at 55
abstract: Mark Weil was an internationally known theater director in Uzbekistan whose troupe, Ilkhom, caused controversy at home with its experimental productions.

headline: Home Sales and Prices Fall Sharply
abstract: Sales of new homes dropped to the slowest pace in over seven years, foreshadowing further economic trouble ahead.

headline: Old Notions Put Aside, Penney Takes Aim at the Heartstrings
abstract: J.C. Penney has introduced a series of  advertising campaigns that look very little like anything a department store has done before.

headline: Keyboard for Xbox Speeds Typing
abstract: The Chatpad for Microsoft’s Xbox attaches to the underside of the 360’s controller without interfering with the controller’s comfortable feel in the hands.

headline: Toys for Toddlers From PG-13 Movie
abstract: Warning: “Transformers” is steering toward your toddlers. At least that’s the complaint from a Boston-based advocacy group.

headline: Japan: Mobile Phone Company’s Profit Surges
abstract: The Softbank Corporation, the Japanese mobile phone company, posted an eighteenfold increase in first-quarter profit after adding users at a pace twice that of the market leader, NTT DoCoMo.

headline: South Koreans Connect Through Search Engine
abstract: Tapping a South Korean inclination to help one another on the Web has made Naver.com the undisputed leader of Internet search in the country.

headline: Around the World, With Borderless Investing
abstract: For the typical retirement plan investor, the stake in foreign equities has more than tripled over the past five years.

headline: The Ludlum Conundrum: A Dead Novelist Provides New Thrills
abstract: Robert Ludlum died six years ago, but that has done nothing to slow the release of books published under the name of the actor-turned-novelist.

headline: Rocket Fired From Gaza Hits Israeli Border Town
abstract: A rocket fired from Gaza on Monday morning landed in an empty courtyard between a day care center and an elementary school in the Israeli border town of Sderot, said police officials there.

headline: After the Deluge, the Reality of Deprivation
abstract: For survivors of some of the worst floods to hit the north of India in decades, the real endurance test is just beginning.

headline: Study Says Delays at S.B.A. Harm Program for Women
abstract: Delays in the Small Business Administration’s disbursal of grant money caused layoffs and cutbacks at women’s business centers.

headline: Sarkozy Pressing to Simplify Aircraft Maker’s Leadership
abstract: The French president wants an agreement to streamline the dual French-German management at Airbus’s parent company, EADS.

headline: Doubts Raised on Magazine’s ‘Baghdad Diarist’
abstract: Many people are asking The New Republic about the identity of the author of a number of articles attributed to an American soldier in Baghdad.

headline: Trade Gap Grew 2.3 Percent in May
abstract: The nation’s trade deficit widened as oil prices jumped, but the overall trend still appears to be improving.

headline: Apparel Maker VF Acquires Jeans and Activewear Brands
abstract: VF’s acquisitions of Seven for All Mankind and Lucy Activewear for a combined $885 million are intended to add new contemporary labels to brands including Wrangler and The North Face.

abstract: The aircraft maker recommended grounding the Q400 turboprop airplanes after two were involved in landing-gear failures this week.

abstract: Kraft Foods said Wednesday that Timothy R. McLevish, currently C.F.O. of Ingersoll-Rand, would take the same position at Kraft in October.

headline: Russia: Prison for Activist’s Killers
abstract: A St. Petersburg court sentenced four young men to prison terms of up to 12 years for their roles in a stabbing attack in the city in 2005 that killed Timur Kacharava, left, a 20-year-old student who belonged to an antifascist group that campaigned against hate crimes. Three young men received suspended sentences. The harsh sentences are a victory for prosecutors and rights groups who complain that Russian courts have underplayed the extent of neo-fascist violence in the country by handing down light punishments for hate crimes.

headline: Toy Magnets Attract Sales, and Suits
abstract: Magnetic toys have been ubiquitous at birthday parties for years. Now they are also appearing in lawsuits.

headline: Wal-Mart Adds Drugs to $4 Program
abstract: Wal-Mart said it would add about seven new compounds, including generic versions of the heart medication Coreg and the anti-fungal drug Lamisil, to the program.

headline: Antonio Carlos Magalhães, Brazil Politician, Dies at 79
abstract: For nearly five decades, Mr. Magalhães was one of Brazil’s most powerful and colorful political leaders.

headline: Frank Rosenfelt, Studio Chief, Dies at 85
abstract: Frank E. Rosenfelt helped steer MGM into new ways of making and showing movies, and he acquired and produced movies like “Doctor Zhivago” and “Network.”

headline: Japan’s Prime Minister Tries to Avoid Big Loss
abstract: The news media were predicting a loss for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s Liberal Democratic Party in  Sunday’s elections for Japan’s upper house of Parliament.

headline: British Jurors Fail to Reach Verdict for 2 in Botched Transit Attack
abstract: The trial of six men accused of conspiring to bomb the London transport system in 2005 ended when the jury failed to reach a verdict on two of the defendants and was discharged.

headline: After Losses, Fund Halts Withdrawals
abstract: Pirate Capital, the hedge fund management company run by Thomas Hudson, has barred withdrawals from its two Jolly Roger Activist funds after the firm’s assets declined by almost 80 percent in the last year.

headline: Foreign Automakers Pass Detroit in Monthly Sales
abstract: American companies lost their leadership of the domestic car market in July, a dismal month for sales.

headline: China to Free Jailed New York Times Employee
abstract: A Chinese research assistant for The Times served three years in prison on a conviction that sparked outrage.

headline: Harvard Endowment Reports 23% Gain for Fiscal Year
abstract: The results brought the value of the nation’s largest university endowment, now overseen by Mohamed A. El-Erian, to $34.9 billion.

headline: Former Chief Executive of 7-Eleven Chosen to Lead Blockbuster
abstract: Blockbuster, the movie rental chain, named a former chief executive of 7-Eleven to succeed its chief executive, John F. Antioco, who is resigning.

headline: The Electric Car, Part 2:  The Tesla Roadster
abstract: David Pogue’s interview with Tesla’s then-chief executive Martin Eberhard at Tesla’s headquarters in Silicon Valley.

headline: Murdoch Awaits Decision on His Dow Offer
abstract: The News Corporation appeared tantalizingly close to succeeding in its bid to acquire Dow Jones & Company.

headline: China: Communist Party to Meet Oct. 15
abstract: A major congress expected to produce a new Communist Party leadership team will open on Oct. 15, the state news media reported.

headline: Oops! Portable Hard Drive Is Tough Enough to Survive Being Dropped on the Floor
abstract: Iomega’s portable external drive, eGo, comes with “Drop Guard” technology, internal reinforcements that can help the 160-gigabyte drive withstand the rigors of travel.

headline: More Retailers Found to Have Lead-Tainted Items
abstract: Congressional investigators determined that major American retailers have found more lead-contaminated children’s products in their inventories but have not yet notified the public.

headline: G.M. and Union Keep Talks Alive
abstract: It appeared the two sides were making progress as, in an unusual move, they continued to bargain into the early-morning hours.

headline: Chandra Shekhar Dies at 80; Led India
abstract: An argumentative proponent of social change, Chandra Shekhar served as prime minister in 1990 and 1991 as the leader of a coalition government.

headline: France: Sales Rise at L’oréal
abstract: L’Oréal, the cosmetics maker, said second-quarter sales rose 10 percent on gains in Eastern Europe and Asia and a recovery in North America. Sales rose to 4.25 billion euros ($5.85 billion) from 3.85 billion euros a year earlier. L’Oréal, based in Paris, has expanded in emerging markets from Russia to Brazil to stoke growth as customers in those countries spend more money on cosmetics products. “Our most dynamic category was skin care,which has a lot of added value,” the chief executive, Jean-Paul Agon, above, said on a conference call.

headline: Taking On Apartheid, Then a Nation’s Stance on AIDS
abstract: Though she may be nobody’s vision of a rabble-rouser, Nozizwe Madlala-Routledge, recently dismissed as South Africa’s deputy health minister, has found herself at the center of controversy.

headline: S. Africa Fires Official Praised for Anti-AIDS Work
abstract: South African anti-AIDS advocates called the firing of  Nozizwe Madlala-Routledge a setback to efforts to curb the spread of AIDS.

headline: Nasdaq to Sell Stake in London Exchange
abstract: Abandoning its effort to buy the London exchange would allow Nasdaq to focus on its bid for the Swedish exchange operator OMX, where it faces a challenge from Borse Dubai.

headline: Former Take-Two Official Is Sentenced in Backdating Case
abstract: The former general counsel of Grand Theft Auto maker Take-Two was sentenced to three years of probation for his role in the company’s options backdating woes.

headline: A Dark, Gloomy Summer in England Turns Menacing
abstract: This summer has brought unusually abysmal weather to Britain. An average of 10 inches of rain in June and July is just shy of the record, set in 1768.

headline: American University Reflects Normality of Life in Kurdish Corner of Iraq
abstract: Supporters of the privately-run American University of Iraq hop that it will stand as a symbol of positive change that is possible at least in Iraq’s Kurdish north.

headline: DAM-lerChrysler? If You Say So, Chief
abstract: In the nine years that DaimlerChrysler was in existence, no one could ever decide how to pronounce the first two syllables. The new chief executive has his own take.

abstract: Take-Two Interactive Software, the maker of Grand Theft Auto, was alerted to a possible enforcement action after announcing its new game would be delayed.

headline: Suicide Bombing Kills at Least 26 in Southern Afghan Market
abstract: The bomb or bombs killed 13 policemen and 13 pedestrians. At least two dozen other people were wounded.

headline: Role of Foreign Doctors Draws Scrutiny in Inquiry
abstract: Britain will review its methods for recruiting foreign doctors after it emerged that all eight of the people detained in failed car bombings last week are from the medical profession.

abstract: Alpha Media Group will turn Stuff magazine into a section of Maxim, while keeping Stuff.com as a stand-alone Web site.

headline: In Hollywood, a Sacred Cow Lands on the Contract Table
abstract: Studios want to junk the residual payment structure for writers.

headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: Britain Asks to Take Back 5 Guantánamo Detainees
abstract: The request is a policy shift for Britain, as the Blair government insisted it had no obligation to help the detainees because they were not citizens.

headline: Steve Jobs: iCame, iSaw, iCaved
abstract: Steve Jobs insists that songs on iTunes cost 99 cents and television episodes cost $1.99 because consumers crave simple pricing. Except, of course, when it comes to Apple’s own products.

headline: China Raises Interest Rates to Cool Its Heated Economy
abstract: The People’s Bank of China said it was raising the one-year yuan lending rate 18 basis points to 7.02 percent from 6.84 percent, effective Wednesday, to curb inflation.

headline: Toy Magnets Attract Sales, and Suits
abstract: An article last Sunday about magnet building toys misspelled the name of the government agency charged with regulating toys and other consumer goods. It is the Consumer Product Safety Commission, not the Consumer Products Safety Commission.

headline: Saudis Rethink Taboo on Women Behind the Wheel
abstract: From a taboo about which there could be no open discussion, a woman’s right to drive is becoming a topic of growing and lively debate in Saudi Arabia.

headline: Zimbabwe: Foreign Businesses to Locals
abstract: A new law decrees that majority ownership of all businesses be gradually transferred to so-called indigenous citizens.

headline: Japanese Premier Reshuffles Cabinet
abstract: With his approval ratings sinking, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe today formed a new cabinet made up of veterans.

headline: U.S. Forces Battle Iraqi Shiite Militia
abstract: At least eight Iraqis were killed in the fighting in northwest Baghdad early this morning, the military said.

headline: Spain: Boat Carrying Migrants Capsizes
abstract: Spanish rescue crews pulled 48 migrants to safety after their wooden boat was spotted struggling in large waves south of Tenerife in the Canary Islands, but 50 others were missing and feared drowned. The survivors were handed over to the Red Cross in the Canaries. The accident is one of the deadliest recorded by the Spanish authorities since a wave of small vessels crammed with would-be immigrants began traveling from Africa to Europe in recent years.

headline: Two Still Cameras Are Made With Uploading Videos in Mind
abstract: The Exilim EX-S880 and EX-Z77 shoot YouTube-compatible videos that can be uploaded quickly, without even pausing to load them onto your computer’s hard drive.

headline: German Coalition Meeting Boasts Modest Agenda
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel’s coalition government of conservatives and Social Democrats will gather Thursday to seek unity and direction.

headline: Vonage Infringed 6 Patents of Sprint, U.S. Jury Rules
abstract: The provider of Internet phone service infringed on Sprint Nextel’s patents and should pay $69.5 million in damages, a federal jury ruled.

headline: Complex Defeat for Nobel Winner in Guatemala
abstract: The puzzling election loss of Rigoberta Menchú, Guatemala’s first indigenous presidential candidate.

headline: Halo 3 Mimics Halo 2, With Some Improved Graphics
abstract: Quick action, varied weaponry and lots of enemies. Sound familiar?

headline: For Dance Troupe, Travel Is a Test of Poise
abstract: For dancers in the Mark Morris Dance Group, air travel is a bitter enemy.

abstract: A South African mining company claimed to have found a greenish-tinged diamond weighing in at 7,000 carats, but skeptics said the claim remained unproved.

headline: Prosecutors in KPMG Case Appeal Dismissal of Charges
abstract: The judge who dismissed the case said that prosecutors had violated the defendants’ rights to a fair trial and legal representation.

abstract: A team of computer security consultants say they have found a flaw in the Apple iPhone that allows them to take control of the device.

abstract: Technology entrepreneurs are starting a host of new social networking sites aimed at baby boomers.

headline: It’s Monetary Policy, Not a Morality Play
abstract: Markets rarely fit into simple moral narratives, and while stories of heroes and villains may comfort us, they are not a good guide to understanding financial policy.

headline: Investors Buy Stake in Global Hyatt
abstract: A group of investors, including Goldman Sachs Capital Partners, is taking a minority stake in the hotel company for $1 billion.

headline: New Twist on Musharraf Plan Emerges
abstract: Gen. Pervez Musharraf plans to run for another term but resign his military post if he is re-elected as president.

headline: A Stock Caught in the Iraq Debate
abstract: One of the biggest business beneficiaries of the war in Iraq  is a little-known maker of specialty ceramics used in body armor.

headline: Mexico Increases Pipeline Security After Recent Rebel Bomb Attacks
abstract: Security was stepped up around gas pipelines on Tuesday after a long-dormant rebel group claimed responsibility for several explosions along pipelines in the state of Guanajuato in recent days.

headline: At 25, ‘McPaper’ Is All Grown Up
abstract: An older, more serious USA Today is facing the challenge of readers and advertisers fleeing to the Internet.

headline: Delphi Drops Financing Deal
abstract: The Delphi Corporation said that it had terminated a $3.4 billion financing plan to bring the company out of bankruptcy protection but that it expects to sign a new deal this month.

headline: Doctor Accused in Glasgow Attack Described as Loner Angry About the Iraq War
abstract: Associates of Bilal Abdulla say he was a religious zealot and a lone wolf whose anger about political developments in Iraq may have driven him to an act of terrorism.

headline: Altria Board to Consider a Spinoff Overseas
abstract: The parent company of Philip Morris is considering whether to spin off the international arm of its cigarette business.

headline: As China’s Economy Roars, Consumers Lack Defenders
abstract: The food-safety crisis has revealed major weaknesses in China’s emerging civil society, which has never developed a consumer movement or citizen advocacy groups.

headline: A Sweet 16 Party, but Not for Investors
abstract: An appearance on MTV may offer a clue to how Gary M. Milby spent some of the $19 million that federal regulators contend he ripped off from investors.

headline: Advocate to Offer Magazine Without 2nd Cover
abstract: The national gay magazine will cease shipping its issues with a second cover concealing its identity.

headline: Ebola Outbreak Feared in Congo
abstract: United Nations officials said they did not know if Ebola was the cause of a mystery illness that has killed more than 100 people.

headline: Japan: Broad Survey Points to Growth
abstract: Japan’s broadest indicator of the outlook for growth signaled for the first time in eight months that the economy would expand. The leading index climbed to 80 percent in June, the Cabinet Office said, the first time it has been at or over 50 since October. A reading of 50 or more indicates the economy may expand in three to six months. The index is derived from as many as 12 monthly indicators. “The economy will probably accelerate in coming months as a pickup in U.S. exports brings a positive impact on the economy over all,” said Takeshi Minami, chief economist at the Norinchukin Research Institute in Tokyo. “As foreign demand remains robust, we can expect sustainable growth.”.

headline: Burned Once, but Starting Up Again
abstract: Michael Wolff, Vanity Fair columnist and author of “Burn Rate,” is helping launch an online news aggregation service.

headline: Memo Pad
abstract: REGISTERED TRAVELER UPDATE The Registered Travel program continues to emerge  slowly. Verified Identity Pass, which runs Clear, the first version of the program to be in operation, said it would open and market a Clear lane at La Guardia Airport in New York in a partnership with AirTran Airways. Clear, which began operating at the airport in Orlando, Fla., two years ago, also has lanes at Kennedy International Airport and at Newark Liberty International Airport, and at airports in Indianapolis, Cincinnati and San Jose, Calif. It plans to open at the Albany airport next month. Steven Brill, the chief executive, said that Clear has 55,000 members (at $99.95 a year). He said he believed membership would reach 100,000 by September. In an interview last March, Mr. Brill said he expected that Clear could have 200,000 to 400,000 members by the end of the year.

headline: Cerberus Chairman ‘Committed to Chrysler’
abstract: John Snow, chairman of the private equity firm that is buying Chrysler, said that higher fuel economy standards threaten the future of the domestic auto industry.

headline: Save Time and Savor the Countryside
abstract: The train is becoming an attractive option for business travelers in Europe.

headline: Close Aides to Musharraf Meet With His Opposition
abstract: The meetings with Benazir Bhutto and Nawaz Sharif come at a time when government officials say they are starting a dialogue seeking “national reconciliation.”

headline: Alcan Gets $38 Billion Takeover Bid
abstract: The $101-a-share Rio Tinto bid represents a 32.8 percent premium to Alcoa’s hostile offer of $76.03 a share, potentially making it difficult for Alcoa to increase its bid.

headline: Cholera Case Reported in Baghdad
abstract: Iraqi health officials confirmed the first cases of cholera in Baghdad today, in a sign that an epidemic that has infected approximately 7,000 people in northern Iraq is spreading south.

abstract: The Bank of Korea unexpectedly raised its benchmark interest rate for a second time in two months to curb lending that may fuel asset-price bubbles.

headline: Chinese Regulators Find Mobile Phone Batteries That Can Explode
abstract: After concerns over pet food, toothpaste, seafood and defective tires, China may now have to cope with another consumer product disaster: exploding mobile phone batteries.

abstract: Seeking to cool China’s rapid growth rate, the People’s Bank of China announced Friday that it will raise interest rates to 6.84 percent, the highest level in eight years.

abstract: As Pakistani forces tightened a cordon around the mosque in Islamabad Maulana Mohammad Abdul Aziz was caught trying to slip out dressed as a woman, officials said.

headline: Hamas Forces Shoot Own Supporters at Rally; Youth Killed
abstract: Witnesses said that the Hamas paramilitary police opened fire when protesters attempted to dash to the Egyptian side of a border crossing during a demonstration.

headline: Oil Is Shipped to North Korea Under Nuclear Shutdown Pact
abstract: A South Korean ship loaded with 6,200 tons of heavy fuel oil left for North Korea on Thursday under an agreement intended to end the North’s nuclear program.

headline: Solve a Mining Puzzle and Win $10 Million
abstract: Barrick Gold is offering a $10 million prize to anyone who can increase the amount of silver it recovers from a mine in Argentina.

headline: Zimbabwe Price Controls Cause Chaos
abstract: Merchants reported huge losses as crowds descended on stores to buy goods at government-ordered prices.

headline: Fascist Overtones From Blithely Oblivious Rock Fans
abstract: During a Croatian rock star’s shows, some young fans give Nazi salutes and wear the black caps of the Nazi puppet regime that ruled the country during World War II.

abstract: Gordon Brown’s visit to Camp David is being closely watched for signs of how his relationship with President Bush will differ from that of his predecessor, Tony Blair.

headline: Blair Begins Role as Middle East Envoy
abstract: There are many questions about what the former British prime minister can achieve as special envoy.

headline: Meeting on Aiding 2 Million Iraqi Refugees Highlights Divisions
abstract: A meeting intended to help develop a strategy for settling the growing crisis of Iraqi refugees stopped short of proposing any concrete solutions.

abstract: Concerns about product safety and workplace conditions have driven Mattel to become a role model for how to do business prudently in China.

abstract: Morgan Stanley has agreed to settle a class-action lawsuit that accused it of unfair treatment of black and Latino employees in the retail brokerage division since 2002.

abstract: About 1.7 million households will lose their homes to foreclosure this year and next, according to estimates, nearly double the number of the previous two years.

abstract: The health care conglomerate announced plans today to eliminate up to 4,800 jobs in a restructuring that it said would save $1.3 billion to $1.6 billion a year.

headline: House to Leave Fuel Efficiency Out of Debate on Energy Bill
abstract: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi decided not to allow a vote on an amendment that would have required cars and light trucks to achieve a fleet average of 35 miles per gallon by 2019.

abstract: Manufacturing has suffered in Africa as cheap Chinese goods flood the market, eliminating needed jobs.

abstract: Fires continued to consume homes and to advance on the ruins where the Olympic Games were first played.

abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. headline: Mexico: New Allegations of Corrupt Police for Tijuana’s Ex-Mayor
abstract: Jorge Hank Rhon, the fabulously wealthy former mayor of Tijuana, faced new accusations of corruption in his city’s police force, just four days before voters are to decide whether he will be the new governor of Baja California. The newspaper Reforma reported that federal authorities had issued arrest warrants for two of Mr. Hank’s former police commanders, alleging the cover-up of a murder by police officers in 2005 and the killing of another police commander in 2006. Mr. Hank, 51, who operates a network of betting parlors, has been running on a promise to clean up crime in the drug-plagued state, while his political opponents have accused him of being involved in crimes ranging from money-laundering to murder. He denies any wrongdoing and has never been charged with a crime.

headline: Israel: Telecom Company Acquired
abstract: ECI Telecom, an Israeli maker of telecommunications equipment, agreed to be bought by the Swarth Group and the Ashmore Group for $1.2 billion.

headline: French and Russian Foreign Ministers Meet, in Iran’s Shadow
abstract: Tense talks between the two countries were dominated by the West’s standoff with Iran, with Russia saying it would oppose tougher sanctions for the time being.

headline: Low-Cost Chinese Cars Making Restrained Entry to European Market
abstract: Aided by a weak dollar, China is quietly entering the European auto market in the first test of rich markets by Chinese automakers

headline: Harley Profit Is Up 19% on Overseas Sales
abstract: Overseas sales helped push profits at Harley-Davidson up 19 percent in the second quarter, but shares fell due to a slump in domestic sales.

headline: At Least 7 Killed as Israel Raids Gaza
abstract: Israeli military officials described the raid today as routine, while Hamas officials called it a provocation.

abstract: American military officials said Sunday that they had captured a suspected militant linked to last week’s assassination of a Sunni tribal leader in Anbar Province.

abstract: Sony is trying to edge into Internet videos with a Web site called Crackle that will feature short segments by aspiring filmmakers.

abstract: Construction may be slowing in some parts of the country, but it is booming in New York City, creating a seemingly insatiable demand for people with expertise in construction management.

abstract: The Greek government, heading for elections next month, is facing a crisis over its handling of deadly forest fires.

abstract: The first flight with paying customers aboard Singapore Airlines’ new Airbus A380 aircraft will depart on Oct. 25 from Singapore to Sydney.

abstract: The efforts of federal regulators to curtail cronyism on corporate boards have led to some odd outcomes.

abstract: Seven banks try to entice investors to buy $24 billion in loans and bonds to pay for the sale of the First Data Corporation to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: Dipping a Toe Into Marine Biology, at a Summer Camp
abstract: About 50 camps now specialize in marine biology studies, according to the American Camp Association. That is an increase of about 25 percent since 1998.

abstract: The S.E.C. is looking into whether credit ratings agencies improperly inflated their ratings of mortgage-backed securities.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: COMPANY REPORTS Earnings season gets into full swing, particularly for technology, financial and drug companies. Reports will come from Charles Schwab and Mattel (Monday); Coca-Cola, I.B.M., Intel, Johnson & Johnson, Merrill Lynch, Novartis, Wells Fargo and Yahoo (Tuesday); Abbott Laboratories, Altria, AMR, Delta Air Lines, eBay, JPMorgan Chase, Pfizer, Southwest Airlines and United Technologies (Wednesday); Advanced Micro Devices, Bank of America, Bank of New York Mellon, Continental Airlines, Dow Jones, First Data, Google, Honeywell, Microsoft, Motorola and Wyeth (Thursday); and Boston Scientific, Caterpillar and Citigroup (Friday).

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Bye, Bye B-School
abstract: An article last Sunday about young workers in the financial industry deciding to forgo M.B.A. programs referred incorrectly to a designation that some of these workers are pursuing. It is C.F.A., for chartered financial analyst, not certified financial adviser. And while that designation requires study toward a series of examinations, it is not a degree program.
