headline: FedEx Hopes for the Right Bounce From Golf
abstract: FedEx is trying to drum up frenzy over the FedEx golf playoffs that start at the Westchester Country Club on Thursday.

headline: Google Earnings Up 28% but Miss Expectations
abstract: The search giant’s shares declined sharply in after-hours trading despite its 58 percent increase in quarterly revenues.

headline: Pope’s Death Is Drawn Into Euthanasia Debate
abstract: Over the last week, the Vatican and an Italian physician have sparred over the doctor’s accusation that the pope should have been fitted earlier with a feeding tube.

headline: U.S. Envoy Offers Grim Prediction on Iraq Pullout
abstract: Ryan C. Crocker and the Iraqi foreign minister warned that withdrawing U.S. troops could lead to a wider war.

headline: Judge Lets Black Remain Free on Bail
abstract: A federal judge today imposed strict travel limits on the former press baron while he awaits sentencing for swindling the Hollinger International newspaper empire.

headline: Kosovo Talks to Start Anew, but Parties Express Doubt
abstract: Leading members of the opposing delegations in talks over Kosovo’s future, which begin Wednesday, said that they doubted that a compromise could be reached.

headline: Politically Neutral, in a Blurry Sense
abstract: Wikipedia devotees meet in Taiwan, while the Web site continues to be blocked in mainland China.

headline: Musharraf  Puts Ally in Key Post
abstract: Gen. Pervez Musharraf is shoring up his power base as he prepares to run for another term as president.

headline: 26 Nations Call for Sending U.N. Peacekeeping Force to Darfur
abstract: The composition of the peacekeeping force, and whether it would include non-African troops, remains a point of contention with the government of Sudan.

headline: Public Service  Through Mug Shots
abstract: Animal Care & Control of New York City, a nonprofit organization that runs the city’s animal shelter system, is counting on mug shots to increase support.

headline: Italian Priest Accused of Sexual Assault by Ex-Clients
abstract: A prominent Italian priest who is close to some of Italy’s most powerful politicians has been accused by men who were once clients of his drug rehabilitation charity of sexually abusing them.

headline: At Marines’ Hearing, Testament to Violence
abstract: A marine sergeant offered gruesome testimony on Friday against a former squad leader charged with killing 17 Iraqi civilians in Haditha nearly two years ago.

headline: Silent Hands Behind the iPhone
abstract: With little fanfare, Taiwan companies are playing a big role not only in the production of Apple’s latest device but in a wide array of other communications equipment.

headline: Brown’s Reaction to Terrorist Threat, So Different From Blair’s, Reassures Many
abstract: For the many Britons who had expressed fatigue with Tony Blair’s apocalyptic view of terrorism, Gordon Brown’s very dourness was a welcome change.

headline: U.S. Official Says Syria May Have Nuclear Ties
abstract: A top U.S. non-proliferation official said that North Korea may be aiding Syria in a covert nuclear program.

headline: The Economy and the Traffic Are Humming in Hanoi, but the Price Is Dirtier Air
abstract: Motorcycles have become the symbol of economic freedom in Vietnam, as its economy surges. But they are also a main source, together with cars, of serious air pollution.

headline: Earthquake in Peru Kills Hundreds
abstract: A powerful earthquake shook Peru last night, killing at least 437 people, Civil Defense authorities said today.

headline: Even Nonhousing Markets Feel Mortgage Fallout
abstract: The days of easy, cheap money for corporations and individuals alike have disappeared, and the ripple effect is being felt by nearly everyone.

headline: Some Experts at Timing Go for Cash
abstract: The Blackstone Group seems to have picked the right property to sell — itself — at the ideal time.

headline: Dubai: M.I.T. Center for Developing Countries
abstract: A Dubai-based private investment company will create a center at M.I.T. to help students from developing countries hone their skills and meet mentors and financiers.

headline: Nikon and Canon Offer High-End Cameras in Fight for Pro Market
abstract: After decades as the undisputed leader of the market for professional 35-millimeter cameras, Nikon finds itself in an unfamiliar position in the digital age.

headline: Serbs See Rift With West if Kosovo Gains Independence
abstract: Anger in Serbia is flaring again as Western governments consider recognizing Kosovo this year as an independent state.

headline: Israeli and Palestinian Leaders Meet in Jerusalem to Move Toward Peace Talks
abstract: The leaders agreed to set up a team of negotiators to flesh out their understandings of what a permanent, two-state solution would look like and require.

headline: Greece Declares Emergency as Forest Fires Rage
abstract: Forest fires that have killed at least 46 people continued to burn out of control, leaving some villages trapped within walls of flames.

headline: Trademarks Can Protect Your Good Name
abstract: Cross a border or advertise a product for sale around the world on the Web, and even small entrepreneurs must think about how to protect their good business names from misuse by others.

headline: This Fund Concept Blurs Old Lines
abstract: An innovation is emerging from a short incubation period among institutional investors and becoming available to ordinary investors.

headline: Investigator Urges Dismissal of Charges Against Marine
abstract: Citing a lack of evidence, an investigator recommended dropping all charges against an infantryman accused of murdering three Iraqis in Haditha in 2005.

headline: Group Raises Cash Bid for ABN Amro
abstract: A consortium of banks led by the Royal Bank of Scotland increased the cash portion of its bid for ABN Amro to 93 percent from 79 percent.

headline: Markets Fall as Lender Woes Keep Mounting
abstract: Stocks tumbled on fears that worsening ills in the mortgage and debt markets could soon take a significant toll on the overall economy.

headline: Ruling Paves Way for Noriega to Be Sent to France
abstract: A federal judge in Miami cleared the way for the former Panamanian leader to face money laundering charges.

headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: Standouts Among Strong Rivals
abstract: Three fund managers discussed their holdings and the outlook for the year ahead.

headline: Russia: Bombers Grounded After Crash
abstract: The air force grounded its fleet of hundreds of Su-24 attack planes after one of the jets crashed during a training flight in Russia’s Far East.

headline: Fortis Shareholders Back ABN Amro Bid
abstract: More than 90 percent of Fortis’s shareholders backed the company’s participation in a consortium that is trying to undertake what would be the world’s largest banking takeover.

headline: At Many Homes, More Profit and Less Nursing
abstract: Insulated from lawsuits by their corporate structures, private investors in nursing homes have cut expenses and staff, sometimes below minimum requirements.

headline: For Elderly Investors, Instant Experts Abound
abstract: Financial advisers with little training give counsel they are unqualified to offer, advocates for the elderly say.

headline: One Answer to Global Warming: A New Tax
abstract: The case for using a carbon tax to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases.

headline: Baseball Gets Into Resale of Tickets
abstract: Major League Baseball has struck a revenue-sharing deal with StubHub to allow fans to resell or buy tickets online.

headline: Why There’s Strength in Small Numbers
abstract: Mark J. Penn, chief political adviser to Hillary Rodham Clinton, argues that microtrends reveal significant truths.

headline: European Company Close to Reaching Libyan Arms Deal
abstract: E.A.D.S., Europe’s largest aerospace company, said that it was close to agreement with the government of Libya on arms contracts worth $405 million.

headline: Russia: BBC Removed From FM Station
abstract: It was the latest in a series of moves that have reduced access in Russia to news produced by Western news organizations.

headline: U.S. Says Iran Helped Iraqis Kill Five G.I.’s
abstract: A charge by a U.S. military spokesman was the most specific allegation of Iranian involvement in an attack that killed American troops.

headline: Switzerland: Cement Maker Beats Estimates
abstract: The cement maker Holcim increased profit more than analysts estimated on expansion in China and India and may acquire a controlling stake in Ambuja Cements of India. Second-quarter net income more than tripled, to 2.07 billion Swiss francs ($1.72 billion), bolstered by a gain of 1.1 billion francs from the sale of a stake in its South African unit, Holcim, based in Jona, Switzerland, said. Sales rose 16 percent, to 7.27 billion francs. Holcim will offer up to $1.34 billion to gain a majority of Ambuja, based in Mumbai.

headline: An Outpost of the Arts, Secured by a Military Dictator
abstract: The National Art Gallery in Islamabad, Pakistan, which opened last month, has brought new texture to an otherwise sterile, highly planned capital.

headline: Inquiry Urges End to Charges Against Marine
abstract: A military investigator has recommended dismissing all charges against a Marine Corps infantryman accused of killing Iraqi civilians in Haditha in late 2005.

headline: Conrad Black Found Guilty in Fraud Trial
abstract: The former press tycoon was found guilty of three counts of mail fraud and one count of obstruction of justice.

headline: Funds Pressure Oil Companies on Iran Links
abstract: Some of the nation’s largest public pension funds are leaning on European and Asian oil companies to reconsider their investments in Iran.

headline: Subprime Fallout Could Help Venture Capitalists
abstract: Could the subprime problems that have fouled the public market be a mixed blessing for Silicon Valley’s high-technology investors?

headline: In Peaceful Switzerland, Trouble at a Historic Meadow
abstract: At Switzerland’s birthplace, concerns about skinheads and a dispute over security costs are marring plans for an annual celebration.

headline: Wal-Mart Cuts Annual Forecast
abstract: The nation’s largest retailer and a bellwether for the  economy warned that profits would be lower than expected for the year, citing higher energy costs and interest rates.

headline: Federal Judge Overturns Ruling Against Mexico’s Former President in 1968 Student Killings
abstract: A federal magistrate has ruled  Thursday that former President of Mexico, Luis Echeverría, cannot be tried or punished for a 1968  massacre of student protesters.

headline: Clash Over Iraq Becomes Bitter Between Bush and Congress
abstract: President Bush told lawmakers that they had no business trying to manage the war hours before they approved a measure to withdraw most combat troops from Iraq by April 1, 2008.

headline: It’s Not Business Travel; It’s Show Business Travel
abstract: I have been lucky to experience ways to keep frequent flying interesting, even if there are no complimentary peanuts being handed out.

headline: IPhone Enters Its European Phase
abstract: Steve Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, said the iPhone would become available to British consumers in November in an exclusive arrangement with O2.

headline: Typhoon Spares Worried Shanghai
abstract: A powerful typhoon lashed at China’s east coast today, forcing evacuations in Shanghai and other coastal cities and causing widespread damage to the south of the city.

headline: Drivers Size Up Fords (Unknowingly) in New Campaign
abstract: Commercials for “Swap My Ride,” Ford’s new advertising campaign, feature people who drove Fords for a week instead of the cars they had just purchased.

headline: Who Founded Facebook? A New Claim Emerges
abstract: The Web site has been fighting claims that its founder stole the idea. Now another man says he was the creator.

headline: As Envoys Meet, No Budging on a Stalemate Over Kosovo
abstract: Politicians and diplomats are skeptical that any agreement can be reached to end the stalemate over Kosovo’s future.

headline: Sales Outpace Inventories at Wholesalers
abstract: Sales at United States wholesalers rose faster than inventories in June, increasing the chances that companies will order more from factories and help offset the housing recession.

headline: Paying More, but Reaching Fewer Ears
abstract: Radio ads have become roughly twice as expensive over the last decade, while radio ratings have dropped by 6.6 percent.

headline: G.M. Cuts Production for Quarter
abstract: General Motors cut its fourth-quarter production schedule by 10 percent as a tightening credit market caused sales at other major automakers to decline in August.

headline: And the Winning Flavor Is...
abstract: Häagen-Dazs and Gourmet magazine are sponsoring a multimedia contest to find an exotic flavor to sell under the Häagen-Dazs brand name.

headline: Timbuktu Hopes Ancient Texts Spark a Revival
abstract: Timbuktu, Mali, a name synonymous with nowhere, may again claim a place at the intellectual heart of Africa.

headline: Cambodia: Frenchman to Defend Khmer Rouge Jailer
abstract: A French lawyer is defending the first member of the Khmer Rouge to be charged in connection with the deaths of 1.7 million people from 1975 to 1979.

headline: A Baffling New Phenomenon: Customized Ringtones
abstract: Apple is selling a ringtone and the full song together for $2, and claims that that’s a bargain.

headline: Subprime Problems Spread Into Commercial Loans
abstract: Turmoil in the subprime mortgage market bled into a type of short-term security held by money-market mutual funds.

headline: Eva Crane, English Expert on World’s Bees, Dies at 95
abstract: Dr. Crane devoted herself to spreading knowledge about bees as a researcher, historian, archivist, editor and author.

headline: When Balance Sheets Collide With the New Economy
abstract: The Re:Framing column last Sunday about accounting for intangible assets referred incorrectly at one point to the Social Venture Technology Group, which specializes in developing nonfinancial valuation methods. It is known as the S.V.T. Group, not the S.V.P. Group.

headline: 250 Palestinian Prisoners to Be Freed
abstract: The promise was made at a meeting between Israel’s prime minister, Ehud Olmert, and the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, in Jerusalem.

headline: New Scrutiny for Facebook Over Predators
abstract: Like MySpace before it, Facebook, the online social network, is being subjected to accusations that it does not do enough to keep sexual predators off its site.

headline: Kazakhstan: Austria Rejects Extradition
abstract: Austria will not extradite Rakhat M. Aliyev, the former son-in-law of the president, because there is no guarantee that he will get a fair trial in Kazakhstan.

headline: Portugal: DNA Match for Missing Girl
abstract: The Portuguese police have confirmed that a trace of DNA found in the trunk of a rented car perfectly matches that of the missing 4-year-old Madeleine McCann.

headline: Hints of Progress, and Questions, in Iraq Data
abstract: Military statistics show that U.S. forces have made some headway at protecting the Iraqi population, but there are questions over whether the gains can be sustained.

headline: 2 Out of 3 Anchors Join Colbert in Wrist Stunt
abstract: The Comedy Central host has turned his ordinary wrist injury into a media crusade, perhaps revealing contrasts among television’s three evening news anchors along the way.

headline: Marines Punish 3 Officers in Haditha Case
abstract: The officers were reprimanded for failing to thoroughly investigate why a group of enlisted men killed 24 Iraqis in Haditha nearly two years ago.

headline: To Compete With E-Mail Greetings, Funny Cards Try to Be Topical
abstract: Greeting card companies hope to promote the idea that cards can be sent anytime, not just on holidays and special occasions.

headline: The Dismal Science, Dismally Taught
abstract: Why aren’t introductory economics courses more effective? One possibility is that instructors may not have mastered some of the basic concepts themselves.

headline: Wyeth Raises Forecast as Profit Jumps
abstract: Profits at the drugmaker increased 13 percent in the second quarter on higher sales of its arthritis drug and pneumonia vaccine.

headline: Israel Agrees to Release 250 Palestinian Prisoners
abstract: The release of Fatah prisoners was intended to bolster the Palestinian president and his emergency government.

headline: Pakistan Leader Says Deal Not Set
abstract: Benazir Bhutto said Pakistan’s president agreed to resign as army chief as part of a deal that would allow him to serve another term as president if he is re-elected.

headline: The Weight of One Observer’s Words
abstract: GENERAL ELECTRIC has traditionally had a friendly relationship with Wall Street analysts and, despite its anemic share price, it has suffered little criticism. So when Jeffrey T. Sprague, a veteran Citigroup analyst, issued a report titled “Partial Break-Up Could Break Deadlock on the Stock,” it shook up the clubby world of G.E. watchers.

headline: Gazprom to Form an Armed Security Force
abstract: Gazprom was exempted from a law forbidding companies other than private security firms to arm their employees.

headline: Chechnya: Russia Liable in Disappearance
abstract: The European Court of Human Rights ordered Russia to pay damages to a Chechen man for the disappearance of his brother, who had been detained by Russian authorities in October 2000. The ruling, which blamed Russia for failing to make a record of the detention of Ayubkhan Magomadov, said that Russia had offered “no plausible explanation as to what happened to him after his detention.” Mr. Magomadov is presumed dead, one of thousands of people thought to have been killed by police and soldiers during the Chechen war that began in 1999.

headline: If It’s Hip, Fast and Furious, Is It Cricket?
abstract: The Indian cricket team’s victory over Pakistan on Monday in a new lean, swift version of the elegant old game came to signify something far larger than itself.

headline: Trading Is Halted in Shares of Mortgage Lender
abstract: Trading was halted yesterday in shares of the lender Thornburg Mortgage Asset after they plunged 47 percent, the most since their 1993 initial public offering. Earlier, five brokerage firms downgraded the stock and Moody’s Investors Service cut its debt rating amid turmoil in the home loan market.

headline: Japan Nuclear-Site Damage Worse Than Reported
abstract: Water leaking from a nuclear power plant stricken by an earthquake was 50 percent more radioactive than initially announced.

headline: Early Returns Indicate Gambling Tycoon Will Not Be Governor of Baja California
abstract: Preliminary election returns showed Jorge Hank Rhon, a gambling tycoon and former Tijuana mayor, had lost to his rival from the president’s National Action Party.

headline: Japan’s Leader Resists Calls to Resign
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe insisted that Japanese voters still supported him despite a defeat in Sunday’s elections.

headline: Afghanistan: 12 Killed in Three Attacks
abstract: Six Afghan policemen were killed when their convoy was ambushed with machine-gun fire and rockets on a dangerous section of the nation’s main highway from Kandahar to Kabul that is a frequent target of the Taliban, a police official said. Two suicide attackers outfitted in military uniforms killed three policemen and a civilian at the main police station in Khost, said that province’s governor, Arsallah Jamal. Taliban insurgents also attacked a surveying team from a road construction company in southeastern Paktia Province, killing an Afghan and a man from the Philippines, according to police officials cited by Agence France-Presse.

headline: Judge Orders Publisher to Leave Job for a Year
abstract: The ruling against Par Ridder of the Star Tribune of Minneapolis is a victory for the  St. Paul Pioneer Press, which had accused its former publisher of misusing proprietary information.

headline: South Africa: Pretoria Name Blocked
abstract: The Pretoria High Court temporarily barred the city government from posting road signs that identify Pretoria as Tshwane.

abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Doctor Born in Saudi Arabia Is 4th Charged in Bomb Plot
abstract: A Jordanian-trained doctor was charged with conspiracy to cause explosions on Thursday in the failed car bomb attacks in London and Glasgow.

headline: Arrest of One Turk in Germany Brings New Scrutiny to a Society of 2.7 Million
abstract: In the wake of this week’s foiled terrorist plot, Germans are learning that their historically moderate Turkish minority may not be quite what they thought.

headline: U.S. Settles With Hip and Knee Makers
abstract: The four companies, charged with criminal conspiracy to violate anti-kickback laws, have agreed to pay $311 million in penalties.

headline: Pakistanis Express Ire at Army and Musharraf
abstract: Dissatisfaction with the military is a sentiment expressed openly in Pakistan, rare for a country where the military has long dominated, intimidating critics from speaking.

headline: Fate of 5 in U.S. Prisons Weighs on Cubans’ Minds
abstract: Five Cubans held in the U.S. on espionage charges have become the biggest propaganda tool that Cuba’s Communist government has come up with since Che Guevara.

headline: Ad Downturn Threatening the Survival of Business 2.0
abstract: Business 2.0, a seven-year-old Time Inc. publication that covers start-ups, technology trends and changes in the new economy, might publish its final issue in September.

headline: Britain: Unions Denounce Call to Boycott Israel
abstract: Twenty-nine American labor leaders issued a statement denouncing the call by several British unions to boycott Israel over its occupation of Palestinian territories. Asserting that “there are victims and victimizers on all sides,” the union leaders said, “We have to question the motives of those resolutions that single out one country.”.

headline: Islamic Opposition Group Pulls Out of Elections in Jordan
abstract: After months of growing tension with the Jordanian government, the opposition Islamic Action Front abruptly withdrew from nationwide municipal council elections on Tuesday.

headline: Heat Waves Are Getting Longer
abstract: Researchers studying western European temperature records have found that the length of heat waves there has doubled since 1880.

headline: When Arbitrators Are Their Own Judges
abstract: For investor advocates, the potential for conflicts of interest among the members of arbitration panels ranks high on the list of problems.

headline: Expert on Murdoch Insisted the Dow Jones Deal Was Done
abstract: Andrew Neil, an expert on Rupert Murdoch, says that Dow Jones negotiators were his source for a claim that a deal had been reached with News Corporation.

headline: Verizon Wireless Suing Over Auction Rules
abstract: Verizon Wireless has sued the F.C.C., seeking to overturn auction rules requiring the buyers of some airwaves to make their networks compatible with any device.

headline: For Many Campaigns, the Little i’s Have It
abstract: Little “i”s have proliferated in product names and commercial brands like the iPod and iVillage.

headline: Dollars Still Not Equal at Canada’s Cash Registers
abstract: Even as the Canadian dollar reached parity with the U.S. dollar, prices for many goods remain higher than they are south of the border.

headline: Justifying $5 Smoothies: It’s the Juice
abstract: Paul E. Clayton, C.E.O. of Jamba, parent company of Jamba Juice, the fruit smoothies retailer, talks about his company’s expansion and service.

headline: New Worries for Small Banks
abstract: Smaller banks find problems in some commercial real estate loans.

headline: Monks Pressure Myanmar Junta
abstract: The involvement of the Buddhist clergy, which is revered in this country, presents a serious challenge to the junta.

headline: Bush Announces Tighter Sanctions on Myanmar
abstract: The president today called on U.N. members to do more to support nascent democracies and to oppose autocratic and tyrannical governments.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Accounts.

headline: Nickelodeon to Limit Use of Characters on Junk Foods
abstract: Nickelodeon, the children’s television network, will prohibit use of its characters on junk food except on special occasions like Halloween.

headline: In Its Nuclear Deal With India, Washington Appears to Make More Concessions
abstract: As India stuck fast to its demand to be able to reprocess spent fuel, it was the U.S. that appeared to make more concessions.

headline: Web Site for Job Seekers Is Sold
abstract: The Jupitermedia Corporation, an Internet research company that also sells photos and art, agreed to pay $23 million for Mediabistro.com.

headline: Georgia Accuses Russia of Firing Missile
abstract: Georgian officials said that Russia violated Georgia’s air space by firing a guided missile, which did not detonate.

headline: Soldiers Describe Baiting of Insurgents
abstract: Army snipers have begun planting fake weaponry and killing anyone who picks it up, according to testimony.

headline: More Deaths in Myanmar, and Defiance
abstract: Violence began before dawn as Myanmar’s military junta tried to crush a wave of nationwide protests with tear gas, beatings and volleys of gunfire.

headline: Putin Shuffles Government, Posing Mystery
abstract: The nomination of a low-profile cabinet official to be prime minister raised questions about who might succeed President Vladimir V. Putin if he steps down.

headline: France: Sarkozy Favors a Utility Merger
abstract: President Nicolas Sarkozy said he favored a merger of Gaz de France and the energy operations of Suez, implying Suez would have to shed its waste and water units to complete the long-pending deal.

headline: Bush Says Iraqi Leader Shares His View on Iran
abstract: President Bush said today that he was confident that Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq shared his view that Iran is a destabilizing force in the region.

headline: Pakistan Releases a Man Accused of Aiding Al Qaeda
abstract: American officials made clear their dismay at the news on Monday that a Pakistani man accused of aiding Al Qaeda has been released.

headline: Political Clashes Shake Venezuela’s Strained Oil Industry
abstract: Internal dissent is shaking Venezuela’s state-run oil company, threatening its ability to  finance Hugo Chávez’s ambitious social welfare programs.

headline: New Foot-and-Mouth Case in Britain
abstract: A national ban was imposed on the movement of cattle, sheep, pigs and other livestock to prevent a further spread of the disease.

headline: Firm Is Issued Subpoena in Inquiry on Student Loans
abstract: The New York attorney general Andrew M. Cuomo has subpoenaed the First Marblehead Corporation as part of his investigation of the student-loan industry in the United States.

headline: Plan Released by Iran and U.N. Atomic Agency Is Faulted
abstract: An agreement between Iran and the U.N. nuclear agency is inadequate and is likely to delay further international sanctions against the country, some say.

headline: From Jail, Colombian Warlord Ponders Long Years of Conflict
abstract: The confessions of Salvatore Mancuso have fed the slow-burning scandal over revelations of ties between paramilitaries and a web of elite politicians in Colombia.

headline: Late to Web Retailing? There’s Still Money There
abstract: During the tech bust, GSI Commerce Inc. increased business by buying distressed online retailers. Now the company hopes it can raise its growth through an acquisition of a different kind.

headline: Israel to Release 90 Palestinians From Jail
abstract: The Israeli government on Sunday approved the imminent release from Israeli jails of about 90 Palestinian security prisoners, including several from Gaza.

headline: Bernanke Says Fed Is Prepared to Act
abstract: The Fed chief said that the central bank “stands ready to take additional actions as needed” to limit the effect of the financial market disorder on the economy.

headline: Beijing Seeks New Scrutiny of Investments by Outsiders

abstract: The text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve after the Fed’s monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to leave interest rates unchanged.

Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

abstract: A morning quake, which flattened buildings and sparked a fire at a nuclear plant, was followed later by a second.

abstract: The president  arrived in Australia today from Iraq, where he emphasized security gains and possible troop withdrawals.

headline: India: World Bank Excludes Two Companies
abstract: The World Bank has debarred two India-based pharmaceutical companies from consideration for bank contracts because a bank investigation found they had colluded to fix prices on a bank-financed maternal and child health project in India. Nestor Pharmaceuticals is ineligible for three years, Pure Pharma for one year. The case prompted Paul D. Wolfowitz, then the bank’s president, to delay some $700 million in loans to India for health programs in 2005 and 2006, angering the bank’s board of directors; the directors felt that he should have consulted them first. It also contributed to the board’s insistence that Mr. Wolfowitz, who resigned in May, develop consistent standards for handling corruption cases.

headline: China: Floods Spur Mass Evacuations
abstract: Almost half a million people have been evacuated from a flood zone along the banks the Huai River in central China, as heavy rain caused the river to rise to its highest level in years, state media said. The evacuations took place in Anhui, left, Jiangsu and Henan Provinces, where several cities and transportation arteries risked inundation. Water from the Huai has been diverted to nearby rivers, but levels remain dangerously high, the official Xinhua news agency reported. Flooding in southern China has killed 360 people so far this summer, according to official reports.

An army spokeswoman said that the man, a member of Islamic Jihad, got out of his car and opened fire on the soldiers first. Three pipe bombs were found in the car.

headline: Russia: Investment Limits May Be Eased
abstract: Aleksandr I. Medvedev, the deputy director of Gazprom, has floated the idea of allowing foreign energy companies to take an equity stake in an operating company that will develop a large offshore natural gas field in the Russian Arctic. Mr. Medvedev’s comments suggest a softening of the Russian monopoly’s position on the Shtokman field, which could be used to supply liquefied natural gas to Europe and the East Coast of the United States. Last October, Gazprom froze talks with five foreign companies seeking a role in the project and said it would develop the field alone. Now the Norwegian companies Statoil and Norsk Hydro, which are merging into one company, Total of France and ConocoPhillips of the United States are negotiating for a role in the development. In an interview with The Financial Times, Mr. Medvedev’s suggestion that a “new model” of cooperation could be found for the big field holds the potential to ease tense relations between Russia and Western energy majors. Gazprom lacks the offshore technology to develop the field alone, industry analysts say.

abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe vowed that he would not step down after his Liberal Democratic Party was routed today in elections.

headline: Wicked Wickets of the East: Talking Tough on a Croquet Court

headline: Singapore Inflation at Year High
abstract: Singapore’s inflation in June accelerated to the highest in a year as holiday travel became more expensive and car prices increased. The consumer price index rose 1.3 percent from a year earlier, after gaining 1 percent in May, the department of statistics said. Rising wages and expanding payrolls, amid Singapore’s longest economic expansion since 1991, have encouraged consumers to spend. Inflation pressures are likely to intensify after the government this month increased its tax on goods and services and the island’s biggest power company raised electricity rates for the third quarter.

He is David Gerbino, not Gerboni.

Production at the Canadian unit of Pioneer, based in Irving, Tex., is more than 10,000 barrels of oil equivalent a day and will help Abu Dhabi National come closer to its goal of producing 100,000 barrels a day.

abstract: Two more private equity deals showed signs of unraveling on Friday, as buyers and bankers grow increasingly wary of the purchases they rushed into only months ago.

headline: China: Buffett Sells Petrochina Shares
abstract: Warren E. Buffett sold about 1.1 billion Hong Kong dollars worth ($141 million) of shares in the PetroChina Company.

headline: Spain: Telefónica Doubles Its Profit
abstract: Telefónica, the European telephone company, raised sales and earnings forecasts for 2007 after second-quarter profit more than doubled on broadband customer growth in Spain and Latin America. Net income rose to 2.57 billion euros ($3.5 billion), or 54.1 cents a share, from 1.14 billion euros, or 24.3 cents a share, a year earlier, Telefónica said. Broadband subscriptions increased 35 percent in a year as Telefónica, which is based in Madrid, added services such as pay television to win new customers and increase revenue from existing ones. Sales rose 6.5 percent, to 14 billion euros, in line with analyst estimates. Spanish fixed-line and mobile revenue increased 5.4 percent, to 5.2 billion euros.

headline: A Shopping Network Wants to Own the 17th Letter of the Alphabet
abstract: QVC, the leading home shopping channel, is launching a re-branding that focuses on the letter Q.

headline: Germany: U.S. Deal by Builder
abstract: Hochtief, the biggest construction company in Germany, agreed to buy the Flatiron Construction Corporation from the Royal BAM Group to add a bridge builder to its commercial property operations in North America. Hochtief, based in Essen, said it would pay $240 million for Flatiron. The purchase of Flatiron, based in Longmont, Colo., will add $626 million of sales and 1,700 employees to Hochtief’s Turner unit, the big American builder.

headline: Archbishop in Zimbabwe Is Accused of Adultery
abstract: Zimbabwe’s state-controlled television broadcast photographs on Tuesday that it said showed President Robert G. Mugabe’s fiercest critic, Archbishop Pius Ncube, in bed with a married woman.

headline: At Least 39 Killed in Attacks in Iraq
abstract: In the Iraqi Parliament, the political bloc loyal to the anti-American Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr halted its four-and-a-half-week boycott.

headline: New Cash Lets Barclays Add to ABN Offer
abstract: Barclays said it had struck a deal with the China Development Bank and Temasek Holdings of Singapore.

headline: Writedowns Push Morgan’s Profit Lower
abstract: Morgan Stanley, hurt by tight credit markets and adverse trading conditions, reported a 17 percent drop in its third-quarter profit today.

headline: Earthquake Shakes Japan’s Northwest Coast
abstract: A powerful earthquake in Japan killed at least nine people and injured more than 900, flattening hundreds of buildings and leaving thousands homeless.

headline: Governing Party in Japan Suffers Election Defeat
abstract: The opposition party seized control of the upper house, but Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said he would not step down.

headline: Rice Backs Appointed Palestinian Premier and Mideast Democracy
abstract: The secretary of state said that the U.S. still supported democracy in the Middle East but defended the American refusal to recognize the earlier Hamas-led government.

headline: Formerly at Voice, Editor Takes a Job at the Competition
abstract: Manhattan Media named former Village Voice editor David Blum as the editor in chief of the New York Press.

headline: U.S. Working on Its Welcome
abstract: Complaints from foreign business and leisure travelers have led the United States government to take steps to improve the treatment of travelers upon arrival.

headline: Musharraf’s Plane Reportedly Fired On
abstract: Pakistani officials dismissed reports that a plane carrying President Gen. Pervez Musharraf was fired on today, even as security officials recovered an antiaircraft gun from a nearby rooftop.

abstract: A continuing decline in advertising revenue pushed second quarter profits lower at two major publishers.

abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

abstract: An entrepreneur beats back depression and begins to develop a new product.

headline: Asia | India: Wal-Mart Wholesale Deal Set

Their venture will open its first wholesale store by the end of 2008, according to Rajan Mittal, the joint managing director of Bharti Enterprises, who spoke at a news conference in New Delhi. Wal-Mart signed a tentative agreement to start a wholesaling business with the Bharti Group in November. The venture, a 50-50 partnership known as Bharti Wal-Mart Private, is planning to open 10 to 15 wholesale stores over the next seven years to sell to small retailers, hotels and restaurants. The proposed Bharti venture would supply the retail market with goods that come directly from producers like farmers, craftsmen and artisans, Mr. Mittal said.

He said his commission had discovered many “commonalities” between the killing and 17 political attacks.

abstract: Not sure how to decorate your Gulfstream? Wondering which continent to golf on next? Then Donald J. Trump has a magazine for you.

abstract: Yasuo Fukuda, a mild-mannered political moderate, is known for his ability to build consensus behind the scenes.

headline: Memo Pad
abstract: BACK TO BACK Domestic airlines are expected to post an aggregate profit of about $4 billion this year, which would make 2006-7 the first back-to-back years of profitability since 1999-2000, the Air Transport Association said in a recent outlook for 2007. Debt levels remain high, however, “leaving the airlines vulnerable to fuel spikes, recession or exogenous shocks” like terrorist attacks and natural disasters, said John Heimlich, the trade group’s chief economist. True financial health for the industry, including the ability to add new-model aircraft to fleets, will require “many years of profitability,” Mr. Heimlich said.

headline: Translation of the Document

Nazarbayev outlining steps agents took in the 2005 presidential elections to influence the judgments of international election observers and public opinion. The document was passed to European diplomats this summer from a source with connections to Kazakh intelligence. Its authenticity could not be determined, and a Kazakh diplomat in Washington called it a "fake." The document was translated by a diplomat in Europe.

headline: U.S. Seeks W.T.O. Ruling on Product Piracy in China
abstract: The Bush administration asked the World Trade Organization to rule in a complaint against China over piracy of copyrighted movies, music, software and books, escalating a dispute that has strained commercial relations between the two trading giants. After consultations failed to resolve differences over what the United States argues are weak Chinese laws to safeguard patents and copyrights, the Trade Representative’s office took the formal step of asking the trade organization, which is based in Geneva, to decree that China’s laws fall short of international agreements.

headline: IPhone Use Disappoints; Apple Slides

abstract: General Electric is getting out of the subprime mortgage market by selling WMC Mortgage, the company announced on Thursday.

abstract: Weeks before Halloween, marketers, retailers and media companies are busily painting the town orange in order to satisfy consumers who are already in the mood.

abstract: The commander of the European Union’s police training mission in Afghanistan is returning to Germany because of wrangling with the European Union, NATO and officials in the Afghan Interior Ministry.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: China: Profit at Brokerage Firm Soars
abstract: The Citic Securities Company, the Asian brokerage firm, said first-half profit rose more than fivefold as a surging Chinese stock market fueled share trading and underwriting fees. Net income rose to 4.2 billion yuan ($554 million), from last year’s 775.8 million yuan, Citic said. Brokerage commissions at Citic, which is based in Beijing, rose sixfold, to 6.6 billion yuan, in the first half. Citic Securities made 473 million yuan, or 4.4 percent of its revenue, from arranging share sales in the first half. Its investment banking division is the leading underwriter this year, with 20.1 percent of the market. Citic and its units have 165 branches and more than 5,000 employees.

headline: Russia: Security Council Official Resigns
abstract: Igor S. Ivanov, a long-serving Russian diplomat, has tendered his resignation as secretary of the National Security Council, a powerful security and foreign policy advisory group in the Russian government. Mr. Ivanov was Russia’s foreign minister from 1998 until 2004; as secretary of the Security Council, he oversaw a policy of toughening Moscow’s position on Iran’s nuclear program, bringing Russia’s stance more in line with that of the United States. His influence was waning recently, Russia’s Vedomosti newspaper suggested in an article that linked his departure to an internal restructuring, rather than any change policy on Iran. It said Mr. Ivanov’s offer to resign may signal Mr. Putin’s intention to boost the importance of the Security Council in Russian politics by putting a more influential figure in the job.

headline: Yahoo’s New President Oversees a Shake-Up
abstract: Susan L. Decker, Yahoo’s new president, is reorganizing the company’s management ranks with a new division responsible for generating the bulk of the company’s revenue.

headline: Public Enemy to Use a Digital Distributor
abstract: TuneCore, a digital music distributor, is expected to announce that Public Enemy, one of the seminal hip-hop groups, will use its service for its new album.

headline: From a Burmese Prison, a Chronicle of Pain in Paint
abstract: Htien Lin’s paintings and illustrations, smuggled from prison during his years as a political prisoner, offer a rare vision of prison life in Myanmar.

headline: Microsoft Game Chief Moves to Electronic Arts
abstract: After overseeing the rising fortunes of the Xbox 360 game console, Peter Moore will run the sports division of the leading game publisher.

headline: Bomb Kills 25 in Baghdad After U.S. Cites Security Success
abstract: The attack occurred hours after an American military official claimed “significant success” for recent security operations in Baghdad and Diyala Province.

headline: Security Crosses the Line: Confiscating Chocolate
abstract: Running a business that trains professionals who work in the oil, natural gas, power and green energy markets requires an energy reserve of one’s own.

headline: Amazon Drops Inventory Data, Irking Writers
abstract: The company has stopped providing information to the public about how many copies of each book it had in stock.

headline: U.S. Troops Arrest Members of Iran Ministry in Baghdad
abstract: Hotel employees confirmed that six Iranians were led away blindfolded and handcuffed by American soldiers who had arrested them at a hotel in central Baghdad.

headline: Taliban Kill a South Korean Hostage
abstract: The Taliban captors complained that the Afghan government had not responded positively to its demands.

headline: Amazon Profit Is Up, With Harry Potter’s Aid
abstract: The online retailer announced today that its second-quarter net income increased more than threefold, with revenue up 35 percent.

headline: Hamas Takes Step to Force Release of BBC Reporter
abstract: A spokesman for the group that claims to have kidnapped the BBC Gaza correspondent, Alan Johnston, was arrested, as were two others.

headline: Russia: Bombers Resume Long-Haul Missions
abstract: Long-range strategic bombers, once part of the Soviet Union’s nuclear forces, were used in new flight exercises that included passing by a United States naval base in Guam.

headline: U.S. Stocks Open Lower After Major Asian Sell-Off
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average was down in early trading after the nation’s top mortgage lender sought to shore up its cash position and a report showed that construction of new homes fell in July.

headline: Iraq Toll at 250 in the Deadliest Attack of the War
abstract: The deadliest coordinated attack since the invasion of Iraq in 2003 left at least 250 dead and 350 wounded, and the toll could still rise significantly, officials said.

headline: Gates Offers Blunt Assessment of Iraqi Progress
abstract: The defense secretary said today that the Bush administration might have misjudged the difficulty of achieving reconciliation among Iraq’s factions.

headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: Imperial Tobacco to Buy Altadis for $17 Billion
abstract: If approved, the deal would be the largest acquisition in the European tobacco industry.

headline: British Move Raises Fears on Iraq Supply Lines
abstract: Officials are concerned that the British pullback from Basra will leave a major supply route at greater risk of attack.

headline: Record U.S. Corn Crop, Up 24%, Is Forecast
abstract: Fueled by high prices, farmers planted the most acres of corn since 1944, which is expected to result in a harvest nearly a quarter bigger than last year’s.

headline: Off the Payroll:  A Look at the Life of the Nonworker
abstract: Just who are these pajama-clad, TV-watching, afternoon-nap-taking people who can’t or won’t collect a paycheck?

headline: Taiwan Plans Missiles Able to Hit China
abstract: An increasingly outgunned Taiwan is quietly pushing ahead with plans to develop missiles that could strike the mainland, defense and security experts say.

headline: Helped by Generics, Inflation of Drug Costs Slows
abstract: Annual inflation in drug costs is at the lowest rate in three decades as generic versions of some of the most common drugs have recently come on the market.

headline: As U.S. Rebuilds, Iraq Won’t Act on Finished Work
abstract: Iraq’s national government is refusing to take over thousands of reconstruction projects, a report shows.

headline: Turkish Group Wields Wit as Tool for Political Change
abstract: Using both humor and conviction, a group called the Young Civilians is one of several starting to question Turkey’s established hierarchy.

headline: Trading in a Movie Star’s Ticket Sales
abstract: Does casting a star raise a movie’s box-office take? A paper soon to be published in The Journal of Marketing tries to solve that problem using a site that lets participants trade in “stocks” of movies.

headline: Even a Pilot Thinks It’s Time to Crack Down on Airlines
abstract: Pilot Vance Atkinson says it’s time for the federal government to do something about passengers being stranded on parked airplanes for long periods of time.

headline: Iranian Official Says Inquiry Into U.S. Scholars Has Ended
abstract: A senior Iranian judiciary official did not disclose the conclusions of the investigation into Haleh Esfandiari and Kian Tajbakhsh, two Iranian-American scholars who have been held since May.

headline: Free Lunch on Health? Think Again
abstract: No one really knows whether preventive medicine will save money in the long run, let alone free up the billions of dollars to help pay for universal health insurance.

headline: Pick a Category, Push a Product
abstract: Slate.com offers a review of the 12 categories of advertising formats, a chain of alternative newsweeklies gets bought and more.

headline: Inspectors Check North Korean Nuclear Reactor
abstract: U.N. inspectors were working to verify North Korea’s announcement that it had shut down its nuclear facilities in Yongbyon.

headline: Family Talks on a Sale of Dow Jones Are Called ‘Not Acrimonious’
abstract: Over the next several days, the Bancroft family members will tell their lawyers where they stand on selling Dow Jones & Company, and the lawyers will tally the results.

headline: Disclosing Bias Doesn’t Cancel Its Effects
abstract: Even when consumers know that experts may be giving biased opinions, they are likely to follow the advice.

headline: Xbox Offers a Forum to Reach Gamers Where They Live
abstract: Since November, Xbox LIVE Marketplace has offered video-on-demand downloads of movies and download-to-own episodes of television shows.

headline: The Roar (and the Risk) of Emerging Markets
abstract: Outperformance has made emerging-market funds very attractive to American investors, some of whom may not be attuned to the risks involved in holding them.

headline: News Corp. Buys Two Weeklies, Expanding New York City Reach
abstract: The News Corporation, owner of The New York Post, bought two weekly newspapers in the Bronx, giving it a chain of neighborhood papers throughout New York City.

headline: A Mentor Is Not a Coddler
abstract: “Life is all about being in the right place at the right time, and getting the opportunity to show your stuff. So many great and talented people never get that opportunity.”

headline: With This Software, Digital Home Videos Become Claymation Movies
abstract: If your home movies are just too dull to be endured, you have a new option: turn your family members into claymation characters.

headline: Fed Chief Gives No Hint of Imminent Rate Cut
abstract: Ben S. Bernanke said today that the central bank “stands ready to take additional actions as needed” to limit the effect of the financial market disorder on the economy.

headline: When Risk Is Home-Grown, Is It Time to Look Abroad?
abstract: The latest round of global financial problems started in the United States, underscoring the importance of international investing.

headline: No Shortage of Worries
abstract: Demand for biofuels could push up food prices, while Sony is accused of again undermining the security of customers’ PCs with rootkit software.

headline: Beyond the Selectric
abstract: “Growing up, I was surrounded by family members who were entrepreneurs.”

headline: Click if You Read This Column
abstract: Online ads can be effective even when not eliciting clicks; opinions on environmental policy are not heavily influencing Americans’ voting decisions and more.

headline: The Cost of Living With Debt
abstract: Though hardly groundbreaking, spending less and paying off debt sooner is sound advice.

headline: Standing Ground in a Dispute With Apple Over Music
abstract: The Universal Music Group of Vivendi told Apple that it would not renew its annual contract to sell music through iTunes, executives briefed on the matter said.

headline: Lost? A Personal Locator Beacon Could Save Your Life
abstract: While the beacons have saved lives and made search-and-rescue operations easier and safer, they have generated controversy. Some experts worry that the devices encourage careless people to get into trouble.

headline: Bet on the Jockey or, in This Case, the C.E.O.
abstract: You want to invest in the jockey (a company’s chief executive, in the metaphor) because you can’t predict what will happen to the business (the horse).

headline: What SAT Scores Say About Your Hedge Fund
abstract: Hedge funds run by managers who attended colleges with relatively high SAT scores regularly posted higher returns, according to a recent study.

headline: Broke but Still Borrowing
abstract: Last year’s bankruptcy reforms could make the current credit squeeze even worse; the varieties of money laundering; and a warning to customer service managers.

headline: Microsoft Favored to Win Open Document Vote
abstract: Amid intense lobbying, Microsoft is expected to squeak out a victory this week to have its open document format, Office Open XML, recognized as an international standard.

headline: Passengers Scowl as Airlines Smile
abstract: While the nation’s airlines are starting to work their way back to profitability, conditions for passengers are worsening with not enough seats to go around.

headline: Deal for Dow Jones a Springboard for Murdoch’s Plans
abstract: Rupert Murdoch won ownership of Dow Jones, mortgage news went from bad to worse, M.L.B. and StubHub made a deal, Mattel recalled toys painted with lead, and more.

headline: At Asian Security Meeting, Russian and Iranian Criticize the U.S.
abstract: Iran lashed out at American plans for a missile defense shield, while Russia took an indirect swipe at what it called Washington’s unilateral foreign policy.

headline: In a Maze of Indexes, Finding Prices to Live By
abstract: Measuring inflation is critically important, but no one gauge provides a categorically accurate result.

headline: It Pays to Look for Trouble
abstract: Questions managers should ask to identify problems, and avoid causing them. Also, insider trading seems to be on the rise.

headline: Music to Live By
abstract: “I had this sense of what music meant to people. It made them feel upbeat and was a soundtrack to their lives.”

headline: Kazakhstan Moves to Alter Oil Company Contracts
abstract: The Kazakhstan Parliament took steps on Wednesday to give the government the right to alter or cancel energy contracts unilaterally.

headline: Listening to TV While You Drive
abstract: Is there a way to transfer just the audio from recorded TV shows onto an iPod or a CD and listen to it in the car?

headline: Teach a New PC Some Old Tricks
abstract: Is it possible to transfer and use data from a computer with Windows 98 to a PC with Windows Vista?

headline: Tip of the Week: Sorting Music Collections in iTunes
abstract: Create multiple libraries in iTunes and then just load the library you need when you need it.

headline: Global Markets Rise Sharply After Rate Cut
abstract: Asian markets rose sharply today, and European stocks were off to a strong start after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates by half a percentage point yesterday.

headline: ABN Amro Starts Up Sustainability-Focused Fund
abstract: ABN Amro is gearing up to create a series of structured fund products built around a fund of hedge funds that invests in the sustainable investment sector, reports Finance Asia. The portfolio is run by Kenmar, which handles $3 billion of client money. Kenmar is the first long/short fund of hedge funds focused on managers that meet the criteria of investments whose ultimate goal is to create a more sustainable economy.

headline: In Europe, Interest Rate Unchanged as Banks Tighten Credit
abstract: As Europe continues to absorb shock waves from the crisis in the American mortgage market, leading financial figures are starting to acknowledge that the turmoil could have a lingering effect on European banks and on the Continent’s broader economic prospects.

headline: The Tech I.P.O. Makes a Comeback
abstract: Could the subprime skunk that is fouling the public market actually be a bit of a blessing for Silicon Valley’s high-technology investors?

headline: Is the Jewel in Cerberus’s GMAC Deal Really a Dud?
abstract: Will Cerberus end up regretting its foray into the mortgage markets?

headline: Investors Say They Were Misled About Bear Funds Risks
abstract: Some investors in two bankrupt Bear Stearns hedge funds are now claiming that the bank soft-pedaled the risks of investing in the funds, according to BusinessWeek.

headline: Elton John Is Still Standing, but He’s Not Surfing the Net
abstract: Sir Elton says the Internet has destroyed music, deflecting blame from “Candle in the Wind.”

headline: Quadrangle Hires Former Yahoo Executive
abstract: Quadrangle Group, a media- and communications-focused investment firm based in New York, said Wednesday it had hired Daniel Rosensweig, the former chief operating officer of Yahoo, to open an office in Silicon Valley in September.

headline: Bank of America Turns to Japan for Bond Sale
abstract: Bank of America sold 230 billion yen ($2 billion) of global bonds on Friday, joining a handful of major banks that have sought to raise cash in Japan’s stable credit markets, Reuters reported Friday citing unnamed sources.

headline: Judge Tells Plaintiffs in Facebook Suit to Back Up Claims
abstract: A federal judge on Wednesday gave a group of former Harvard students two weeks to finalize and back up their claim that Facebook‘s founder stole their ideas to create the fast-growing social networking Web site.

headline: Wesfarmers Is Said to Plan a Sweeter Bid for Coles
abstract: It has already prevailed over serious competition, including Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, TPG Capital and Permira. Yet Australia’s Wesfarmers may sweeten its offer for supermarket giant Coles anyway.

headline: Inside the Brain of a Gadget Compulsive
abstract: As he prepared for the onslaught of submarines, a homemade rail gun, a few billionaires and a grounded blimp, Dan Dubno took time Thursday to get his brain scanned.

headline: After Buyouts, More Profits But Less Nursing
abstract: As investment firms such as Warburg Pincus have acquired thousands of nursing homes in the United States, a rise in profits has come with a general decline in resident care, according to an analysis at The New York Times.

headline: Frenzy Over iPhone Drives Action Engine’s Funding
abstract: The introduction of the iPhone late last month apparently did wonders for Action Engine, drawing attention to mobile video, audio and Web browsing.

headline: Quattrone: ‘The Opera Is Over’
abstract: A federal judge formally approved a request by prosecutors to dismiss all remaining charges against Frank P. Quattrone, the former Credit Suisse banker.

headline: Gerdau Ameristeel to Pay $4.22 Billion for Chaparral
abstract: Gerdau Ameristeel said on Tuesday it would acquire Chaparral Steel for $4.22 billion, Reuters reported. Chaparral confirmed in April that its board was examining options and had hired Goldman Sachs to advise.

headline: Morgan Stanley Predicts Correction
abstract: A study by Morgan Stanley has warned that current jitters on the global credit markets may spread to equity markets, The Telegraph reported Monday. The study said stock market corrections occur six months after the cost of debt rises, suggesting is that the current rally in equities on Wall Street and in Europe could be more fragile than it looks.

headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: Barclays Gains After Subprime Assurances
abstract: Shares in Barclays topped the list of London gainers Monday, as investors eyed comments from the banking group’s president that appeared to soothe recent worries about the amount of subprime exposure on the bank’s books.

headline: Market Maker LaBranche Considers Its Options
abstract: LaBranche has long been in the business of bringing together buyers and sellers of stock. But is the company itself looking to connect with a buyer?

headline: Faint Signs of Life in Buyout-Loan Market
abstract: In what normally would be seen as a bit of good news for the jammed-up credit markets, Reuters is reporting that Citigroup and other banks sold a $1 billion piece of a $3.5 billion loan to finance the buyout of Allison Transmission. But, as TheDeal.com notes, the partial sale and the discount price — 96 cents on the dollar — may not bode well for other loans stuck in the pipeline.

headline: DealBook at Sun Valley: Late Night With Eric Schmidt
abstract: After two days of watching boldface names from afar, David Carr sits down with Eric Schmidt of Google for a late night chat. Surprise: He thinks Viacom’s $1 billion copyright suit against Google is nonsense.

headline: Amp’d Is Said to Near a Shutdown
abstract: Amp’d Mobile, a venture capital-backed cellphone service provider hurt by rapid growth and a deadbeat youth market, could close its doors as early as Monday after a bankruptcy court hearing on its inability to pay its network lease.

headline: Clips: Echostar, “The War,” “Family Guy” Spoof
abstract: — Echostar, the parent company of the Dish Network, is buying the maker of the SlingBox, a place-shifting device “that allows you to watch your TV’s programming anywhere on your laptop or mobile device,” CNET News reports. Also: Broadcasting & Cable says the company “is considering splitting up its business into two publicly traded companies.”

headline: K.K.R. and Banks Said to Dispute First Data Terms
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts may delay the sale of loans to finance the $26 billion takeover of the First Data Corporation until next week after failing to agree on terms with bankers, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Fortis Profits Beat Expectations
abstract: The Belgian-Dutch financial services group Fortis, which is involved in a bidding war for the Dutch bank ABN Amro, reported a 16 percent year-on-year rise in second-quarter net profit on Thursday, beating analysts’ expectations thanks to strong banking results.

headline: Banker Backs Out of Deal for Fremont
abstract: Shares in Fremont General, the embattled California savings and loan, dropped the most on Wednesday since March after the billionaire banker Gerald J. Ford abandoned a rescue plan.

headline: Counting Mitt Romney’s Private-Equity Cash
abstract: Here are two exit polls for Wall Street to consider: According to PEHub’s Dan Primack, Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney has fallen behind his rivals in collecting donations from employees of buyout firms. But The Wall Street Journal’s Brody Mullins wrote earlier this week that Mr. Romney, who helped found Bain Capital, is tops with private equity donors.

headline: Top Securitizations Law Firm Feels Pressure from Law Suit
abstract: As the global slowdown in the market for mortgage-backed securities threatens a core practice area of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, the New York law firm, it is also wrestling with a $70 million legal malpractice suit brought by a major issuer of such securities, The New York Law Journal reported Wednesday.

headline: Fortis Shareholders Vote in Favor of ABN Bid
abstract: Fortis, the Belgian financial group, moved a step closer to buying part of ABN Amro Holding after Fortis shareholders backed its financing plan.

headline: Quick Bits: A Slow Late-August Day
abstract: With news from Oracle, Nokia, Google and others.

headline: Citigroup’s Old Lane Said to Drop 5.9% in August
abstract: Old Lane, the hedge fund acquired this year by Citigroup to bring Vikram Pandit into the fold, reportedly fell 5.9 percent in August, hurt by losses on debt and emerging-market securities.

headline: Bear Funds Get Temporary Shield from Investors Suits
abstract: Bear Stearns has managed, if only temporarily, to put some distance between itself and disgruntled investors in two of its now-bankrupt hedge funds.

headline: The Intel Ministry of Education
abstract: Intel announced a new initiative to rapidly broaden the reach of its program, Intel Teach. The Intel effort focuses on training teachers around the world to use personal computers as a tool in classrooms.

headline: Thumbs Up? Thumbs Down?
abstract: O.K., I understand that YouTube’s audience is largely young and uncultured; that’s why the comments are overwhelmingly misspelled, unpunctuated and juvenile. There’s nothing Google (YouTube’s new owner) can do about that.

headline: Unitrin Sells Insurance Unit to AmTrust
abstract: Unitrin, an insurance and financial services company, said it tentatively agreed to sell its Unitrin Business Insurance segment to New York-based AmTrust Financial Services for terms that were not disclosed.

headline: Midwest to Consider Takeover Offer from TPG
abstract: Midwest Air Group said it would pursue a takeover offer, likely to exceed $400 million, from United States private equity firm TPG, which includes a passive investment from Northwest Airlines, the fifth-largest airline in the nation.

headline: Terra Firma Clinches EMI Deal
abstract: The private equity firm Terra Firma Capital Partners, run by the British financier Guy Hands, said Wednesday it had succeeded in its 2.4 billion pound ($4.9 billion) takeover of the music company EMI Group, garnering the 90 percent of shares needed to let it force out minority shareholders.

headline: U.S. Steel Buys Canada’s Stelco
abstract: United States Steel has reached a deal to take over Stelco, making the company the final domino to fall in the Canadian steel industry.

headline: Dice Rolls High with Second I.P.O
abstract: Employment Web site operator Dice Holdings went public for a second time on Wednesday and raised $217 million after pricing at the top of the range. TheDeal.com called the I.P.O. a “bonanza” for Dice’s two private equity backers, General Atlantic and Quadrangle Group, which have made roughly 2.7 times their money in two years.

headline: Royal Bank of Canada Snaps Up Alabama National
abstract: A Royal Bank of Canada subsidiary, RBC Centura, said it had agreed to acquire the Alabama National BanCorporation in a $1.6 billion deal that will add to the Canadian bank’s presence in the Southeastern United States.

headline: Activist Fund Keeps Pressure on Brink’s to Sell
abstract: One of the largest investors in Brink’s is maintaining pressure on the security company to split up to boost its flagging stock price. Included in a regulatory filing Thursday was a letter from MMI Investments, an activist hedge fund, pointing out the share performance of Brink’s to a newly public competitor and urging further action.

headline: Vodafone to Keep Stake in Verizon Wireless
