abstract: Vodafone committed itself on Wednesday to holding on to its full 45 percent stake in Verizon Wireless, the mobile phone group in the United States, turning down the right to sell back up to $10 billion of shares to its partner in the venture, Verizon Communications.

headline: A Smarter Way to Fetch E-Mail
abstract: I know everybody’s sick to death of hearing about Apple’s latest i-product, so I promise not to even mention its name in this newsletter. But as I was trying to get my e-mail set up on that cellphone, I stumbled upon a delicious secret feature of Gmail, Google’s fast, free, fantastic Web-based e-mail service. This is a trick that can help everyone, whether you have a cellphone or not.

headline: New Tools, New Techniques
abstract: Nanotechnology research advances are happening with such frequency these days that the individual achievements are losing some of their power to awe — until you stop and think about them.

headline: Paulson Says U.S. Hurt by High Corporate Taxes
abstract: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. wants people to know that the corporate tax code is hurting American competitiveness. But corporate lobbyists are not expecting him to do anything about it.

headline: Quick Bits: More Google News
abstract: This is what people may be talking about today. It may even help you strike up a conversation with the cute girl in I.T., the one with the big G-Shock watch.

headline: Board to Remain Neutral in Bids for Dutch Bank
abstract: The board of ABN Amro, the Dutch lender at the center of the world’s largest banking takeover battle, withdrew its support for a bid by Barclays, the British Bank, but it did not go so far as to support a rival bid from a banking consortium led by Royal Bank of Scotland.

headline: Senators Scrutinize Google’s DoubleClick Deal
abstract: Microsoft is fiercely opposed to Google‘s proposed $3.1 billion purchase of the online advertising firm DoubleClick. But the transaction drew no outright opposition from United States senators at a hearing Thursday, which focused on the deal’s potential threats to competition and consumer privacy.

headline: Fortress to Take Seacastle Public
abstract: Fortress Investment Group is taking Seacastle public only a few months after forming it to buy marine container rental company Interpool for $2.4 billion.

headline: Russian Oil Magnate Says He Was Forced to Sell
abstract: The owner of Russneft, one of Russia’s largest private oil companies, confirmed Monday that he would sell the business to an investor loyal to the Kremlin, but he added in an open letter that the sale was not voluntary.

headline: Fed Cuts Rates by Half a Percentage Point
abstract: The Federal Reserve on Tuesday lowered interest rates by a half point, a forceful policy shift intended to limit the damage to the economy from the recent disorder in the housing and credit markets.

headline: Google Versus the V.C.’s
abstract: Google is apparently becoming a thorn in the side of venture capitalists.

headline: Taking the Pulse of Venture Investing
abstract: These are strange and uncertain times for venture capitalists.

headline: Liberty Property Signs Deal for Republic
abstract: Liberty Property Trust, one of the nation’s largest real estate investment trusts, said Wednesday that it would buy the publicly traded Republic Property Trust for $900 million in cash and debt, enabling it to enter the Washington market.

headline: Answers From Zheng Chunmiao
abstract: Today we have answers to your questions from Zheng Chunmiao, the Founding Director of the Center for Water Research at Peking University. Mr. Zheng is an internationally recognized expert in groundwater hydrology.

headline: NBC Universal Eyes Sparrowhawk Media, Report Says
abstract: NBC Universal is holding discussions to buy Sparrowhawk Media, which owns the international operations of the Hallmark Channel, for about $350 million, according to Reuters. Sparrowhawk, a private equity group backed by Providence Equity Partners and 3i purchased the international arm of the Hallmark Channel in 2005 for about $242 million.

headline: HSBC Unit May Buy IKB, Chief Says
abstract: HSBC Trinkaus & Burkhardt, the German bank controlled by HSBC, would consider buying IKB Deutsche Industriebank after a government-sponsored bailout following losses in the American subprime mortgage market.

headline: Sentinel Management Freezes Fund
abstract: Sentinel Management Group on Tuesday froze a $1.5 billion fund, saying too many investors are trying to withdraw their money.

headline: Golf Anyone? Bankers Bide Their Time
abstract: If there is an upside to the recent downturn in the deal-making business, it was expressed Wednesday by Jonathan Nelson, the chief executive of Providence Equity Partners, a media-focused private equity firm. “It’s the first time in four years that professionals at Providence have had a chance to take a vacation,” he told the audience at the Dow Jones Private Equity Analyst conference in New York.

headline: Wall Street Hears Deal Buzz in Telecom Sector
abstract: Telecommunications bankers may be getting a lot of phone calls this summer. Several signs point to the possibility of more deal-making in the industry, including the intense interest surrounding Avaya while that company was on the block.

headline: Saks Sales Rumors Heat Up on Icelandic Investment
abstract: Speculation that a sale of Saks may be in the works heated up again after an Icelandic investment firm revealed earlier this week that it had amassed a stake in the luxury department store.

headline: Breeden Sets His Sights on Zale
abstract: Fresh from his victory at H&R Block, Richard Breeden, the former Securities and Exchange Commission chairman turned activist hedge-fund manager, has another company in the crosshairs: the specialty jewelry retailer Zale.

headline: Landry’s Arranges New Financing
abstract: Landry’s Restaurants said Thursday that it has arranged a bank loan to repay bondholders who have demanded early repayment on debt securities, but it will continue to fight a demand to immediately repay that debt.

headline: The YouTube Debates: Power to the Remixers
abstract: Tonight’s Democratic debate on CNN featuring questions asked by voters on YouTube shows the rise of remix culture, cellphone video aesthetics, and Google’s political power.

headline: Social Gaming Startup Gets $5 Million
abstract: Casual gaming startup Kongregate said on Thursday that it had received $5 million in its first round of funding. Venture firm Greylock Partners led the round.

headline: Yahoo-Microsoft Chatter Rises Again
abstract: An analyst’s report has given new life to the speculation about an acquisition of Yahoo by Microsoft.

headline: Topps Shareholders Approve Buyout Deal
abstract: Shareholders of Topps, the basebal -card and bubble gum producer brought an end to a long-running fight Wednesday, by approving a $9.75-a-share, $384 million buyout bid from Michael Eisner’s Tornante and the private equity firm Madison Dearborn Partners.

headline: VMware Loads Up and Intel Helps
abstract: VMware, the hot software company owned by EMC, filed for an initial public offering today. Intel agreed to buy a 2.5 percent stake in the company, which has raised the ire of Microsoft, long an Intel ally.

headline: Did Private Equity Ruin the Party for V.C.’s?
abstract: Lawmakers and labor unions are not the only ones criticizing Stephen Schwarzman these days.

headline: Finish Line Says Financing for Genesco Deal Is Shaky
abstract: The shoe retailer Finish Line, which is taking a closer look at its decision to acquire Genesco, the shoe and hat retailer, said on Friday that the bank providing the funds for the purchase is also taking another look.

headline: A Debate We Don’t Need: Do RFID Chips in Humans Cause Cancer?
abstract: A report that RFID chips may cause cancer when embedded into animals was flimsy science but brilliant advocacy work. There is no mass panic, however, because few are sticking their arms out to get the chips put in.

headline: Dolans’ Cablevision Offer May Be Looking Sweeter
abstract: The roiling credit markets and mediocre second-quarter results may be the push the Dolans, Cablevision System‘s founding family, need to persuade shareholders to green light their $36.26 a share offer to take the company private, The New York Post says.

headline: Icahn May Be Facing an Uphill Battle at BEA
abstract: When it comes to BEA Systems, it looks like Carl C. Icahn may have a fight on its hands.

headline: At Fidelity, a Born-Again Star — or a Has-Been?
abstract: The resignation of Ellyn McColgan, a Fidelity executive who had been considered an heir apparent to the chairman and chief executive, Edward C. Johnson III, may have paved the way for Rodger Lawson, president of Fidelity to take the reins.

headline: To Catch a Falling Knife
abstract: Private equity may not be able to save this mortgage lender.

headline: Stones Play for Bankers: So Respectable?
abstract: The Rolling Stones might be the one rock band from the 60s that can get away with playing a private show for investment bankers without having to endure complaints that they are “selling out.”

headline: SkyBridge Hires Two Top Executives
abstract: SkyBridge Capital, which provides seed money to budding hedge fund managers, said on Tuesday that it had hired Scott Prince, a former partner at Eton Park Capital Management and Goldman Sachs, as a managing partner. SkyBridge also said that it had hired Evan Wein, a former managing director at Merrill Lynch and the founder of two money management firms, as a senior partner.

headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: Regulators Approve Chinese Construction I.P.O.
abstract: China Construction Bank got the go-ahead from China’s securities regulator to launch an initial public offering to raise up to $7.4 billion, in what will be the mainland’s largest stock sale.

headline: Facebook Buys a Web Celebrity – and His Company
abstract: Facebook buys startup Parakey, founded by two creators of the Firefox Web browser. The company has been building a Web-based operating system that could further Facebook’s grand aspirations.

headline: Citigroup Leads $400 Million Deal for Cupmaker
abstract: Citigroup‘s venture capital arm led a $400 million deal for a controlling stake in Waddington North America, a maker of disposable cups, dinnerware and cutlery, according to Reuters.

headline: Dow Jones Director Resigns After Vote to Sell
abstract: One of Dow Jones‘ directors who abstained from the vote approving the company’s sale to the News Corporation has resigned, the publisher said in a regulatory filing Thursday. Dieter von Holtzbrinck, a scion of the von Holtzbrinck publishing dynasty, said in his letter that he was concerned about the company’s journalistic values under Rupert Murdoch.

headline: Arrow Investor Raises Opposition to Teleflex Deal
abstract: The $2 billion deal by Teleflex, a maker of a wide range of industrial products, to buy Arrow International may face opposition from one of the medical device maker’s largest shareholders, the Robert L. McNeil Jr. 1983 Trust.

headline: Ross Wins ‘Stalking-Horse’ Status for American Home
abstract: Wilbur L. Ross, the distressed-equity investor, is bidding roughly $500 million for the loan-servicing business of the bankrupt mortgage company American Home Investment, the company said on Wednesday.

headline: A Big Deal in NYSE’s Future?
abstract: John Thain may be back in deal-making mode.

headline: Boston Scientific Adds 2 Units to Those It Hopes to Sell
abstract: Boston Scientific said Thursday that it had added its cardiac and vascular surgery units to the list of businesses it wanted to sell to reduce debt and focus on its core businesses.

headline: A Sign of Desperation
abstract: Desperation at Countrywide

headline: Canada’s CI Financial Launches Bid for Dundee
abstract: The CI Financial Income Fund, an independent Canadian-owned wealth management company, is seizing the chance to pursue its decade-old desire for DundeeWealth by making an unsolicited bid of 2.36 billion Canadian dollars ($2.35 billion).

headline: New Electric Car Start-Up Revs Its Engine
abstract: Another day, another electric car company.

headline: Abandoning Trump
abstract: Nobody wants to buy Donald Trump’s company.

headline: Blackstone Says Tax Hike Would Cost It $525 Million
abstract: The Blackstone Group has gotten out its calculator and tallied up the cost of a Congressional proposal to more than double the tax rates buyout firms.

headline: Sallie Mae’s Buyers May Be Getting Cold Feet, Lender Warns
abstract: Sallie Mae, the student-lending giant, said Wednesday afternoon that its buyers have expressed concern over pending legislation that “could result in a failure of the conditions to the closing of the merger to be satisfied.” The lender’s parent company, the SLM Corporation, said that it “strongly disagrees” and thinks that the deal can still be completed.

headline: Goldman, Empresas Bid $4.1 Billion for Mexican Toll Roads
abstract: A Goldman Sachs fund has joined Empresas ICA in bidding $4.1 billion for the right to run four toll roads in Mexico.

headline: Lehman to Close Subprime Unit and Cut 1,200 Jobs
abstract: It appears the bloodbath is beginning. Lehman Brothers, a leader in packaging subprime mortgages into securities, is shutting down one of its home lending units and laying off 1,200 employees, or about 4.2 percent of its total workforce. The bank said it would take a $52 million hit to third-quarter earnings.

headline: Big Pension Fund Questions Buyout Firm I.P.O.’s
abstract: The California State Teachers’ Retirement System, which has invested more than $10 billion in private equity funds, is wary of private equity funds selling shares to the public. In an interview with The Financial Times, the group’s chief investment officer argued that going public could distract from deal-making and create conflicts between the short-term demands of shareholders and long-term returns sought by pension funds.

headline: Reata Pharmaceuticals Closes $25 Million Round
abstract: Reata Pharmaceuticals has closed a $25 million fifth round of funding that will help advance its two primary drug candidates through Phase 2 clinical trials.

headline: Despite Market Turmoil, Harvard Posts Gains
abstract: Despite its $500 million investment in Sowood Capital Management and a general drop in the credit markets, Harvard’s endowment seems to be chugging along, for now.

headline: Home Depot Scrambles to Save Sale of Unit
abstract: Home Depot was scrambling Thursday night to save the sale of its wholesale unit to a consortium of private equity firms, lowering its asking price by about $1.2 billion from the original $10.3 billion it agreed upon, according to The New York Times.

headline: Taking Stock After the August Storm
abstract: Smart investors love crises. People panic, everything gets out of whack, securities get cheaper, and the world gets more interesting. Academic types also love crises because they produce data, which prompts questions and every once in a while produces some answers.

headline: Justice Dept. Supports Banks in Enron Case
abstract: The Bush administration on Wednesday took the side of defendant companies in a Supreme Court case that could determine the fate of other investor lawsuits including one stemming from the Enron scandal.

headline: Taking Google to Court
abstract: Australian regulators are taking Google to court about how it describes ads on search results and whether some of those ads are misleading. This raises interesting questions but leaves out an important issue for Yahoo: paid inclusion.

headline: More Red Ink After Alcatel-Lucent Merger
abstract: The telecommunications equipment maker Alcatel-Lucent posted its second consecutive loss in the second quarter on costs related to its recent merger and an unfavorable product and geographic mix, the company said Tuesday.

headline: TXU Shareholder Voices Buyout Opposition
abstract: A major shareholder of TXU voiced opposition to the company’s $32 billion buyout as the firm announced that its chief executive, C. John Wilder, would resign once the deal closed.

headline: Intel Extends Investment Spree
abstract: Intel Capital‘s has continued its recent investment streak with the leadership of a $10 million second round of funding for Mirics Semiconductor, a developer of radio-frequency chips.

headline: Chinese Stocks Fall On Fears of an I.P.O. Glut
abstract: Chinese stocks fell Tuesday after posting a record high as fears emerged that new share offerings by banks and other big state companies might outpace demand.

headline: Banks Balk at Funding Home Depot Deal, Report Says
abstract: Home Depot‘s plans to sell its wholesale supply division to a group of private equity buyers is in doubt because the investment banks involved are reluctant to fund the deal, even at a lower price, The Financial Times reported.

headline: In Taipei, Wikipedians Talk Wiki Fatigue, Wikiwars and Wiki Bucks
abstract: At the annual gathering of Wikipedia volunteers, Jimmy Wales, the co-founder of the user-written encyclopedia, was on the sidelines. Florence Devouard, the new chair of the WikimediaFoundation, spoke more of fundraising than quality.

headline: CVC Buys Univar for $2 Billion
abstract: CVC Capital Partners, Europe’s second-largest buyout firm, on Monday agreed to purchase Netherlands-based Univar for $2.07 billion.

headline: Basell to Acquire Lyondell for $12.1 Billion in Cash
abstract: Just days after failing in its bid to acquire the chemical maker Huntsman, Basell, a Dutch manufacturer, said Tuesday it would buy another American competitor, Lyondell Chemical, for $12.1 billion in cash.

headline: Citigroup Signs Movie Deal With Wild Bunch
abstract: Wild Bunch, the Paris-based film sales and distribution company, is again tapping Wall Street’s coffers, with the help of an old friend.

headline: Deutsche Bank Hires Greenspan as Adviser
abstract: Deutsche Bank said it had hired Alan Greenspan, the former chairman of the United States Federal Reserve, as a consultant to provide “advice and insight” to the company’s corporate and investment banking unit and its clients. In May, Mr. Greenspan signed a consulting deal with Pimco, the giant bond management firm, which became his first client since leaving the Fed in early 2006.

headline: S.E.C. Said to Subpoena Jobs in Apple Options Suit
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has subpoenaed Apple Chief Executive Officer Steven P. Jobs to give a deposition in a backdating lawsuit against the company’s former general counsel, according to press reports, citing court documents.

headline: Making Sense of the Markets
abstract: Easy credit in the American home-loan market has turned from a sales pitch to a curse, as the troubles with subprime mortgages have developed into a credit squeeze that is shaking the world’s markets and has made loans much harder to get. Will the latest upheaval pose a threat to continued economic growth — and your own financial security? Today I will be answering questions from readers.To ask a question or to see my answers, click here.

headline: Appaloosa Makes Final Play for Dana
abstract: Appaloosa Management has taken its last shot at the Dana Corporation, having submitted a new offer to fund the auto parts maker’s exit from bankruptcy.

headline: Family Talks on Dow Jones Sale Called ‘Not Acrimonious’
abstract: In their last meeting before an expected vote on selling to Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, the family that controls Dow Jones & Company, owner of The Wall Street Journal, heard arguments for and against the deal yesterday from family members and advisers.

headline: Suez Deal Stymies E.U. Efforts to Open Energy Markets
abstract: The European Union’s ambitions to open its energy sector to greater competition were dealt a fresh blow Monday after the French state-owned company Gaz de France announced that it would merge with the utility Suez to create one of the world’s largest energy groups.

headline: Sallie Mae’s $25 Billion Question
abstract: In the standoff between Sallie Mae and its proposed acquirers, a few letters are getting a lot of attention: M.A.E., which stand for “material adverse effect,” the term used to describe an escape hatch that may or may not allow a group led by J.C. Flowers & Company to back out of its $25 billion agreement to take the company private.

headline: Inquiry into New Century Escalates
abstract: New Century Financial, a collapsed subprime lender that is liquidating in bankruptcy, said Thursday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had elevated its investigation of the company to formal status.

headline: A Buoy For Alternative Energy
abstract: This week, SRI International will launch a buoy that contains a pipe filled with the polymer into Tampa Bay. The substance will expand and contract, sort of like a rubber band, and in the process generate enough energy to power the navigational buoy.

headline: HSBC in Talks to Buy Lone Star’s Korean Bank Stake
abstract: Financial giant HSBC said Monday it is in talks to buy the controlling stake in Korea Exchange Bank currently held by U.S. private equity group Lone Star Funds. “The discussions are ongoing,” London-based HSBC Holdings said in a statement. If successful, the transaction would depend “on obtaining the necessary regulatory approvals in (South) Korea and elsewhere,” the bank said.

headline: RF Micro Picks Up Sirenza for $900 Million
abstract: RF Micro Devices said Monday that it had agreed to buy Sirenza Microdevices for $900 million in cash and stock in a move by the company, a maker of wireless telecommunications chips, to enter more profitable markets.

headline: Sun Hopes New Ticker Will Boost Shares
abstract: Silicon Valley investors will be soon waking up to JAVA – and Sun Microsystems hopes the new ticker symbol will help perk up its stock.

headline: Merger Delays Drag Down US Airways
abstract: On the same day that US Airways came out of bankruptcy in September 2005, it also completed its merger with the regional carrier America West. But complications in merging the two union groups have resulted in stalled cost savings which have, in turn, recently led US Airways’ stock to hit a 52-week low, Dow Jones Newswires reported.

headline: Quick Bits: Microsoft Works Free, IAC Disappoints
abstract: Also in the news today: an iTunes milestone, an open-source start-up, and a Web company’s acquisition.

headline: Just How Contagious Is That Hedge Fund?
abstract: Hedge funds may well stay vulnerable to the kind of rapidly spreading losses that have been precipitated this summer by problems in the subprime mortgage market, Mark Hulbert argues in The New York Times.

headline: Orbitz Offering Prices Below Expected Range
abstract: Orbitz Worldwide, the travel Web site whose parent company, Travelport, is owned by buyout firm Blackstone Group, raised $510 million Thursday in its initial public offering.

headline: And Now, a Look at First Data’s Bonds
abstract: On Monday, debt investors are expected to flock to New York’s Pierre Hotel to find out more about the first sale of loans related to First Data‘s buyout by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: Blackstone’s $1.1 Billion Real Estate Problem
abstract: Observers parsing the Blackstone Group‘s first earnings announcement as a public company had a lot to chew on, including its acknowledgment that the buyout boom has gone on hold. But according to Breakingviews’ Lauren Silva, the private equity giant may have a bigger problem on its hands.

headline: TPG Is Said to Consider Virgin Media Bid
abstract: Texas Pacific Group is considering joining the bidders in the $23 billion auction of Virgin Media, The Telegraph reported Thursday. The private equity firm has indicated its interest in participating in the likely sale of the troubled pay-television operator by contacting Goldman Sachs, Virgin Media’s lead adviser, according to the paper.

headline: ComScore Counts Ads and Plans to Count TV Viewers
abstract: ComScore is going to measure how many ads each Web site displays. And it is hoping to get into the TV ratings business too.

headline: Judge Approves Delphi Investment Plan
abstract: Delphi took a big step on its road to recovery Thursday when a bankruptcy court agreed to let Appaloosa Management and other investors inject up to $2.55 billion into the struggling auto-parts maker.

headline: Debenhams Seeks Merger Partner
abstract: Debenhams has held talks with German retail giant KarstadtQuelle to discuss a potential partnership and help stem the British retailer’s ailing fortunes, The Telegraph reported Monday.

headline: Absolute Capital Halts Redemptions After Homm Resigns
abstract: Absolute Capital Management will stop clients from pulling money from eight hedge funds with $2.1 billion of assets, after its colorful German co-founder, Florian Homm, quit unexpectedly.

headline: Peer-to-Peer Telephone Service?
abstract: Ooma, a startup, plans to sell a $399 device that will give its users free long distance calling for life. It does so by having users share each others’ local phone lines.

headline: HSBC’s Asian Deal Irks Activist Investor
abstract: HSBC has signed a deal to buy 10 percent of Vietnam Insurance, a move that seems to hav only increased the ire of an activist shareholder who is calling for a review of the bank’s operations. HSBC Insurance said that it had purchased the stake from Vietnamese firm, known as BaoViet, for 4,121 billion Vietnamese dollars ($254 million).

headline: Sun Valley: Google and the Facebook Question
abstract: Sergey Brin, sitting atop the Zeitgeist at Google, is hardly a press hound. But as one of the people of the moment, he was willing to show a little leg on the way out of Thursday morning’s conferences.

headline: Mircosoft Buys Ad Exchange AdECN
abstract: On the heels of its aQuantive purchase, Microsoft on Thursday announced it has bought AdECN, a company that is a technology platform for buying and selling display advertising. AdECN provides an ad exchange, like electronic stock trading markets, that allows publishers and advertisers to broker the sale of display advertising.

headline: What’s On Tonight: ‘Mrs. America 2007’
abstract: Married women have long had a beauty contest of their own, the Mrs. America pageant, which tonight it receives national broadcast exposure for the first time.

headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: Big Gifts, Tax Breaks and a Debate on Charity
abstract: The rich are giving more to charity than ever, but people like Bill Gates, Warren E. Buffett, and Eli Broad are not the only ones footing the bill for such generosity. For every three dollars they give away, the federal government typically gives up a dollar or more in tax revenue, because of the charitable tax deduction and by not collecting estate taxes.

headline: Icahn Again Raises Stake in BEA Systems
abstract: Carl C. Icahn has a added a little more leverage to his position on BEA Systems, the business software maker that he is urging to sell itself. The activist investor increased his stake for the second time in two weeks, to 9.88 percent.

headline: Nasdaq May Sell L.S.E. Stake
abstract: Nasdaq Stock Market may sell its 31 percent stake in London Stock Exchange, in what may be an effort to raise cash to sweeten its bid for Sweden’s OMX.

headline: C.I.A.’s Investment Arm Backs MotionDSP
abstract: In-Q-Tel, the venture-capital arm of the Central Intelligence Agency, has invested an undisclosed amount of money in MotionDSP, which makes technology for enhancing digital video.

headline: AFMOA (A Few More Online Abbreviations)
abstract: Following my tongue-in-cheek list of proposed new online abbreviations (to complement the tired old LOL’s and BRB’s), readers have submitted a few more proposals of their own. Thought I’d run ’em by you:

headline: Sentinel Says It Has $2 Billion in Assets
abstract: Sentinel Management Group, which filed for bankruptcy last month only days after freezing client withdrawals, has about $2 billion in assets, according to a filing in its Chapter 11 case.

headline: Gannett: Reading Between the Lines
abstract: With Dow Jones & Company set to become part of Rupert Murdoch’s media empire, Gannett is sometimes touted as the next potential takeover target in the newspaper industry. But it is so huge — with a market capitalization of nearly $11 billion — that it is hard to imagine who the acquirer would be. Jon Morton, a newspaper analyst, told The New York Times in June that only a big, non-media buyer — he mentioned General Electric or a buyout firm — could possibly do such a deal, and even that’s unlikely.

headline: Fortress Battered by Wider Loss
abstract: The Fortress Investment Corporation posted a wider quarterly loss on Tuesday, sending its shares down 6.6 percent.

headline: Cerberus Has Confidence in Chrysler, but Mileage Bill May Change That
abstract: Cerberus chairman John Snow said on Wednesday that he feels confident about Chrysler‘s prospects. “We’re committed to Chrysler; we’re committed to making it an enormous success,” he told a Detroit Economic Club audience. He also said that Cerberus had no plans to sell Chrysler or to take it public after making it profitable again.

headline: Insurer to Buy Two Merrill Lynch Insurance Units
abstract: The Dutch insurer Aegon said Monday it had agreed to buy the Merrill Lynch Life Insurance Company and the ML Life Insurance Company of New York for $1.3 billion to increase its sales of variable annuities and distribution in the United States.

headline: Credit Crisis Hits Lender in Britain
abstract: Depositors of a big British mortgage lender, Northern Rock, rushed to withdraw money on Friday after the bank, unable to raise financing because of the tight credit market, turned to the Bank of England for an emergency loan.

headline: Shareholders Approve $5.3 Billion Ceridian Buyout
abstract: Shareholders of Ceridian, the payroll processor, voted in favor of a $5.3 billion proposal from Thomas H. Lee Partners to take the company private.

headline: Apple Event: New Colors for the Shuffle; Video for the Nano
abstract: Good news for those who want a purple iPod or to watch video on a tiny tiny screen.

headline: Backers Inject $15 Million Into AdvanDx
abstract: A diagnostics developer AdvanDx raised $15 million in a Series C round from new distribution partner bioMérieux of France and longtime backers LD Pensions of Denmark and Sweden’s Scandinavia Life Science Venture to support expansion of sales and marketing of tests for bloodstream infections and for development of a pipeline of new products.

headline: Shopping in Shanghai, From Your PC at Home
abstract: A new site, Shangby, allows Western shoppers to buy the comparatively cheaper items from stores in Shanghai, China.

headline: Merrill Analyst Downgrades Three Rivals
abstract: Merrill Lynch is apparently not so hot on some of its rivals’ prospects right now.

headline: Congress Returns With Carried Interest on the Agenda
abstract: On Wednesday, Robert L. Johnson, the founder of BET, offered his take on a proposal to raise taxes on a major source of profits for private equity funds. (He’s against it.) On Thursday, another big name from the cable industry is expected to weigh in: Leo Hindery Jr., the former chief executive of the Yes! Network.

headline: Are Associate Lawyers in the Firing Line?
abstract: The current turmoil in the credit market has some law firm leaders predicting future layoffs of associates, according to The Legal Intelligencer.

headline: Thomson Sells Unit to Help Fund Reuters Deal
abstract: In a bid to raise the final cash needed to fund its purchase of the Reuters Group, Thomson has agreed to sell a unit that provides educational testing services for $435 million to ETS. ETS, which administers the SAT college admission test, will pay $310 million in cash for the Prometric unit and $125 million through a promissory note due in 2014, Thomson said.

headline: Tracking Michael Jackson’s Glove Online
abstract: A research project roped thousands of volunteers into some Michael Jackson-watching, with entertaining results.

headline: Ex-Prudential Executive Settles S.E.C. Complaint
abstract: A former senior executive with Prudential Securities is paying $100,000 to settle accusations by the Securities and Exchange Commission that he failed to supervise registered advisers who the S.E.C. says allowed favored clients to make improper “market timing” mutual fund trades.

headline: AT&T Says the iPhone Is Its Best Seller Ever
abstract: AT&T said this afternoon that in partnership with Apple the nation’s largest cellular operator had sold more iPhones over the weekend than any of previous phone models have sold in a month. It also said this morning that they are making progress in smoothing out the glitches that had bedeviled some users who attempted to used the system used to activate the phones using the Internet.

headline: Private Equity’s Jackpot Is the Fees
abstract: The lion’s share of attention on private equity these days centers on on the roughly 20 percent cut of profits that firms hold for themselves. But is that focus misplaced?

headline: The Food Line at the Googleplex Did Seem Rather Long
abstract: Google’s profits stall because it accidentally hires too many employees and deliberately fires some customers.

headline: Winnipeg Exchange Investors Approve ICE Deal
abstract: Shareholders of WCE Holdings, which owns the Winnipeg Commodity Exchange, on Thursday approved a takeover offer worth C$50 million ($47.6 million) by IntercontinentalExchange.

headline: Ventana to Buy Antibody Maker as Roche Fight Continues
abstract: Ventana Medical Systems, which makes cancer diagnostic equipment, is expected to announce Wednesday that it will acquire Spring Bioscience, a developer of antibodies, for $28.9 million in cash as it continues to battle a hostile takeover offer from the Swiss drug maker Roche Holding.

headline: Sovereign Wealth Funds: The New Hedge Fund?
abstract: One of the enduring criticisms lobbed at hedge funds is their lack of transparency. Now, regulators and lawmakers may soon have a new target in their fight against opacity.

headline: Allen Considers Charter Buyout
abstract: The billionaire Paul G. Allen may try to buy or recapitalize Charter Communications, the cable company he controls, according to a regulatory filing Wednesday.

headline: Will ‘Kid Nation’ Flunk Its First Test?
abstract: We’re a few hours away from the premiere of “Kid Nation,” the most talked-about new show of the fall season.

headline: A Thursday afternoon in Budapest
abstract: Busy day in sunny Budapest it was. The sweltering heat of recent weeks has faded into a balmy 29 degree Celsius, blue skied afternoon. But it seems rain is predicted for at least part of the weekend. Today the center of Budapest was a mess of traffic as the police closed off portions of the city to allow Gerhard Berger to drive an old McLaren while Tonio Liuzzi drove a Toro Rosso on the chain bridge. Lewis Hamilton did an event for Hungarian go-karters. We don’t know quite what his teammate Fernando Alonso did, since he was given permission by the FIA to skip the press conference but we were not told why.

headline: Clips: ‘Grey’s’ Spinoff, ‘Heroes,’ ‘Dancing’ Ratings
abstract: — “Private Practice,” the spinoff of “Grey’s Anatomy,” debuts tonight on ABC. The second soapy hour has doubled the work of the two show runners, Betsy Beers and Shonda Rhimes, as they explain in this Los Angeles Times profile.

headline: MidOcean Buys Maker of Outdoor Gear
abstract: MidOcean Partners said Thursday it had agreed to buy Bushnell Outdoor Products from Wind Point Partners for an undisclosed amount. However, TheDeal.com reported that the deal for the maker of binoculars and telescopes is estimated at a value of $500 million to $600 million.

headline: S.E.C. Inquiry Looks for Conflicts in Credit Rating
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has opened an investigation into whether the credit-rating agencies improperly inflated their ratings of mortgage-backed securities because of possible conflicts of interest, the head of the commission told Congress on Wednesday.

headline: Carlyle Can’t Save Queen
abstract: An investment group backed by the Carlyle Group has pulled out of the bidding to buy Queen Seaport Development, the bankrupt operator of the legendary Queen Mary cruise liner.

headline: Google Goes After Microsoft Again
abstract: With an alliance with Sun Microsystems , Google ups the ante in its efforts to offer a competitor to Microsoft Office.

headline: The Sheriff Comes Calling for Mystery Bidder
abstract: When someone named Theodore Roxford made an $89 billion bid for Sony Corporation in 2003, executives at the Japanese conglomerate paid him little attention. Four years later, securities regulators in the United States are giving him lots of it.

headline: Crowning Weill and the New Gilded Age
abstract: The tributes to Sanford I. Weill to his corporate — and political — prowess line the walls of the carpeted hallway that leads to his skyscraper office, with a panoramic view of Central Park. The trophies, from magazines to a pen used by President Bill Clinton, tout his achievement in building Citigroup into the most powerful financial institution since the House of Morgan a century ago.

headline: Ohio Files Antitrust Suit Against Insurers
abstract: The state of Ohio has filed an antitrust lawsuit accusing Marsh & McLennan, the American International Group and three other insurers and their subsidiaries of price fixing and other anti-competitive behavior, the attorney general, Marc Dann, said Monday.

headline: Plus Approval May Mean New Rival to L.S.E.
abstract: Plus Markets Group has won the right to become a fully fledged British stock exchange, potentially creating a new competitor for the London Stock Exchange.

headline: Debt Could Drag Buyout Boom Down, Survey Finds
abstract: Though private equity and its backers have proclaimed nothing but confidence in the industry’s future, some cracks may be beginning to show. A survey of industry professionals released Wednesday said that while the first half of 2007 has been a dealmaking feast, the debt markets are expected to intrude on the party.

headline: New World Department Store Raises $301 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: New World Department Store has set the price of its initial public offering at the top of the range after garnering strong interest from the market, Finance Asia reported Friday. The pricing allowed the group to raise $301 million.

headline: Abu Dhabi Energy Firm to Buy Canadian Assets
abstract: Abu Dhabi National Energy, better known as Taqa, expects to spend as much as $3 billion over the next 12 months buying Canadian oil and gas producers, the company’s chief executive officer said Thursday.

headline: Dow Jones Board Endorses Murdoch’s Takeover Bid
abstract: It’s now up to the Bancrofts.

headline: Oh Those Analysts
abstract: How close were the analyst’s predictions on Apple iPhone sales? Oh, say double the reality.

headline: The Ignorant CFO
abstract: Why Expect a CFO to understand accounting?

headline: Looking to Dump the Deal, MGIC Sues Radian for More Info
abstract: MGIC Investment, which agreed in February to buy rival mortgage insurer Radian Group but has since had second thoughts, has filed a federal lawsuit in Milwaukee to force the Philadelphia company to give it more information.

headline: Advice on Mentors, From One of Mine
abstract: Advice on Cultivating a Mentor

headline: VMware Marches onto the Hardware
abstract: Hewlett-Packard, Dell, IBM and others will bake VMware’s software onto the the motherboards of their server computers, striking another blow against Microsoft.

headline: Dour Forecast Could Put Compuware in Play
abstract: Compuware‘s poor financial results are inciting renewed speculation that the company could be a prime takeover target, TheDeal.com said Wednesday. Shares in the software maker plunged more than 20 percent after said it expects first-quarter sales of about $278 million, below analyst estimates of $303 million.

headline: Clips: ABC/AOL, NBC.com’s First Original Production, Halo 3
abstract: — ABC’s deal with AOL.com to distribute its fall shows, announced yesterday, is important because “AOL has a much bigger audience than ABC.com would have,” David Card, a senior analyst with Jupiter Research, tells Cox News. ABC is thinking like a studio, he says, trying to “distribute its programming as far as possible.”

headline: Former Merrill Broker Sentenced in Squawk-Box Case
abstract: A former Merrill Lynch broker was sentenced Tuesday in federal court in Brooklyn to a year and a day in prison for witness tampering and making false statements in connection with an alleged scheme to misuse information broadcast over brokerage “squawk boxes.”

headline: Is Fernando Alonso the compleat driver?
abstract: Lots of scandalous talk going on in the paddock in Monza today, but difficult to come to any conclusions about any of it. New evidence in the spy scandal, maybe provided by drivers under pressure from the FIA? An illegal gearbox in the McLaren in Hungary, because not tested before use?* Lots of stuff.

headline: Google Takes On Michael Moore
abstract: UPDATE: Google has responded again to the firestorm raised by this incident saying it shares the concerns Michael Moore raised in his movie.

headline: Virgin America Hunts Its Bugs
abstract: Virgin America talks about bugs and upgrades to its in-flight entertainment system

headline: Telecom Italia Agrees to Sell Stake in Brazil Telecom
abstract: A year after hiring J.P. Morgan Chase to sell its 38 percent stake in Solpart Participacoes, Telecom Italia has agreed to a $515 million deal. The stake will be sold to the Previ, Petros and Funcef pension funds, who are already shareholders in Solpart’s Brasil Telecom Participacoes, Brazil’s third-largest fixed-line telephone company.

headline: NBC Wraps Newspapers in Ads
abstract: Readers of The New York Times and The Los Angeles Times have seen some unusual pages in their papers recently: ads for various NBC properties that wrapped partially around various parts of the paper, partially obscuring the section fronts.

headline: Wesfarmers Sweetens Coles Offer to Save Deal
abstract: Australia’s Wesfarmers, whose takeover of the Coles Group is in jeopardy because of a slide in its stock, said shareholders in the supermarket chain can opt for more cash as it seeks to make the offer more attractive.

headline: Sandler O’Neill Hires Executive for Fixed Income
abstract: Sandler O’Neill & Partners, a boutique investment bank, said Tuesday that it had hired Raymond E. Chandonnet, the former head of bank strategy sales at J.P. Morgan Securities, as a managing director in fixed income sales. Mr. Chardonnet will serve as chief strategist in the balance sheet management group in Sandler O’Neill’s New York office

headline: Cadbury Considers a Spinoff Amid Sale Doubts
abstract: Cadbury Schweppes said Thursday morning it is prepared to spin off its North American soft drinks business if the proposed 7 billion pound ($14 billion) sale is scuppered by turmoil in credit markets. The group made the announcement as it unveiled a fall in first-half profits.

headline: As Losses Mount, WestLB Under Pressure to Merge
abstract: WestLB, the troubled German state-run bank, said Thursday that it had lost more than $820 million on speculative trades in global stock markets in the first half of 2007 – pushing it into a net loss for the period and renewing pressure for it to find a merger partner.

headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: Why Drill for Oil When You Can Sift Soil?
abstract: A tiny microbe that eats plants and makes ethanol has attracted millions of dollars in investments.

headline: Rio Tinto Shares Rise on Rumors of a Two-Pronged Bid
abstract: Shares of the mining giant Rio Tinto were up sharply Thursday on market speculation that it might be taken over by two rivals, BHP Billiton and Companhia Vale do Rio Doce.

headline: Russian Steel Magnate Buys Arsenal Stake
abstract: A Russian mining magnate, Alisher Usmanov, has acquired a stake in Arsenal, the British soccer club, from David Dein, the club’s former vice-chairman and a close ally of manager Arsene Wenger.

headline: Carlyle Enters Taiwanese Banking Market
abstract: Making its first foray into the Taiwanese banking market, the Carlyle Group has agreed to pay 21.5 billion new Taiwan dollars ($657 million) for a 35 percent stake in a Taiwanese lender, Ta Chong Bank, TheDeal.com reported. The purchase will make Carlyle the single biggest shareholder of the bank, which operates 52 branches in Taiwan.

headline: Sequoia Talks Jive into $15 Million Round
abstract: Jive Software said Monday that it had raised $15 million from Sequoia Capital in what marks the collaboration software product maker’s first round of outside capital to support expansion of its platform product.

headline: D.E. Shaw Cuts Stake in Clothing Retailer
abstract: D.E. Shaw has more than halved its stake in the clothing retailer The Children’s Place. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, D.E. Shaw shed hundreds of thousands of shares at the end of August, reducing its stake to about 4.1 percent from 9.7 percent.

headline: S.E.C. Keeps Eye on Conduits
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking at whether unwinding financing vehicles like conduits could strain the balance sheets of major investment banks, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Veoh’s Vexing Visitor Numbers
abstract: Video sharing site Veoh.com says that its number of visitors has risen more than two-fold since February. If some television network executives are correct, it may be because the company is less aggressive than rivals in keeping copyrighted content from its site.

headline: For Private Equity, Schumer’s Defense May Cut Two Ways
abstract: The private equity industry may have gained an inadvertent “frenemy” in Democratic senator Charles Schumer in its battle to keep Congress from raising taxes on the industry’s gains, The Financial Times’ Lex column says.

headline: South Africa’s Sasol to Give $2.5 Billion Stake to Black Investors
abstract: Sasol will give a 10 percent stake worth about 18.2 billion rand ($2.5 billion) to black investors in South Africa’s largest redistribution of wealth since the end of apartheid.

headline: Pop Goes the Buyout Bubble
abstract: Hear that sound? That was the private-equity bubble finally getting pricked on Thursday, as the market for debt — the jet fuel that had propelled it to dizzying heights — slammed shut.

headline: Apple Bites Back
abstract: Apple won’t carry NBC’s videos, so there.

headline: Dow Jones Deal May Not Pay Off, Analyst Says
abstract: From the beginning, many analysts and investors have suggested that Rupert Murdoch’s $5 billion offer for Dow Jones is, to use the technical term, crazy high. (A former financial adviser to the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones, has called it “absolutely, insanely high.”)

headline: Courts Rule Against Hedge Funds in Mittal-Arcelor Deal
abstract: Courts in the Netherlands and France refused to grant injunctions seeking to block Mittal Steel‘s proposed $41 billion acquisition of a rival steel maker, Arcelor.

headline: NBC Introduces a Social Network
abstract: But how many social networks will people join?

headline: Samsung’s Nanotech Washer Must Follow Bug-Spray Rules
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency will evaluate a washing machine made by Samsung under pesticide rules because it generates and mixes silver ions into loads of laundry to kill bacteria and other microbes.

headline: Lerach Expected to Plead Guilty in Milberg Weiss Suit
abstract: The securities lawyer William S. Lerach is expected to plead guilty Tuesday to a criminal conspiracy charge in connection with a class-action scheme involving his former firm, now known as Milberg Weiss, according to The New York Times.

headline: Apple Reactions: The Future of Wireless Audio and Video
abstract: The iPhone Touch may represent the future of media use: audio and video that can be played both from local storage and from a vast server with everything.

headline: Insider Trading Increasingly Hinges on Options Moves
abstract: While the Securities and Exchange Commission has filed at least 22 insider-trading lawsuits this year, market makers say the agency is just scratching the surface, Bloomberg News reported Monday

headline: Wary of Dow Jones, The F.T. Looks for a Partner
abstract: Pearson, the owner of The Financial Times, said Monday that it was talking to a number of potential partners about new ways to display the newspaper’s journalism as it weighed the effects of Rupert Murdoch’s bid for Dow Jones & Company, owner of The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Calculating a Private Equity Tax Hike
abstract: Efforts in Congress to more than double taxes on managers of private equity firms would generate little or no extra revenue to help pay for middle-class tax cuts that many lawmakers are seeking, a study finds. Buyout and venture capital firms would restructure their affairs to sidestep new tax laws, according to the study, by Michael Knoll, a law professor at the University of Pennsylvania.

headline: Should Procter & Gamble Clean House?
abstract: When Procter & Gamble bought Gillette for $57 billion, it picked up a lot more than just razors: The deal gave it Duracell batteries and Braun, whose products include coffeemakers and blenders. Less than two years later, Wall Street is wondering whether it may be time for P&G, a giant of the consumer products business, to tidy up a bit.

headline: Newmonth Mining Plans $1 Billion Debt Offering
abstract: Newmont Mining said it will offer $1 billion in convertible senior notes to help repay debt and complete major projects in Australia and Peru, The Denver Business Journal reported.

headline: MGIC, Radian End Merger Talks
abstract: MGIC Investment and the Radian Group have ended their merger talks, saying that “market conditions” had scuttled a deal that would have combined two of the three biggest mortgage insurers in the nation.

headline: Banks Ask for Slack in Microchip Firm’s Buyout, Report Says
abstract: The $1.4 billion private equity buyout of Singapore’s United Test & Assembly Center, a microchip tester, is likely to win shareholder approval on October 5, to the potential dismay of the deal’s bankers.

headline: AZN Pays $88 Million for Stake in Vietnamese Broker
abstract: The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group has acquired a 10 percent stake in Vietnam’s top stock broker, Saigon Securities for $88 million.

headline: Behind the Scenes of “iPhone: The Musical”
abstract: I had a lot of crazy fun making my video “iPhone: The Musical” last week–and a lot of fun watching the reaction online.

headline: What I Did on My Summer Vacation
abstract: Virgil Griffith’s Wikipedia entry will have to say how he developed his latest hack.

headline: Investors May Start Showering Money on Water Firms
abstract: Will water become the next big “clean tech” investment?

headline: Prada Denies Reports of Sale Talks
abstract: Prada is denying reports that it is in talks over a potential sale of the company to the billionaire Richard Caring. The Sunday Times, citing unnamed sources, said it was in negotiations with a “handful of potential buyers,” including at least two private equity firms. The Daily Telegraph reported Monday that Prada has put a 3 billion to 3.5 billion euro ($4.1 billion to $4.8 billion) price tag on the business.

headline: Intel Gains Havok for About $110 Million
abstract: Intel announced that it is acquiring Havok, the Irish developer of the widely used physics engine of the same name.

headline: Evergreen Settles Market-Timing Case
abstract: Evergreen Investment Management and its affiliates have agreed to pay $32.5 million to settle charges of improper market timing, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday.

headline: Investors Tell Tales of V.C. Hardball
abstract: Some top venture-capital firms eager to expand into new markets are twisting their investors’ arms to get them to go along, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Saint-Gobain Cements Deal for Maxit Mortars
abstract: Cie. de Saint-Gobain, Europe’s biggest supplier of building materials, agreed to buy the Maxit unit of HeidelbergCement for 2.13 billion euros ($2.94 billion) to double its production of industrial mortars.

headline: Bancroft Family Member Tries to Block News Corp.’s Dow Bid
abstract: A member of the Bancroft family is making a last-ditch attempt to block Rupert Murdoch’s News Corp. from buying Dow Jones, Reuters reported on Monday, confirming a story in The Wall Street Journal. Christopher Bancroft, whose family controls Dow, has recently approached hedge funds and private equity firms, in a move to acquire enough voting shares to give him the power to thwart a sale, the report said.

headline: Madison Dearborn Chief Builds Team for Cubs Bid
abstract: As news that a stake in YES Network may be on the block sparked talk Thursday of a possible sale of the Yankees, another auction of a highly-prized baseball team has been heating up.

headline: AOL Snaps Up Online Ad Firm Tacoda
abstract: The AOL unit of Time Warner said Tuesday it had agreed to buy Tacoda, an online advertising company that uses behavioral targeting techniques to track Web user habits. The deal is the latest acquisition by AOL to bolster its online advertising tools after its decision to move away from its Internet access business and instead offer consumers free services supported by ads.

headline: Silicon Valley Gears Up for Frothy Debutante Season
abstract: Silicon Valley’s annual coming-out season for tech start-ups is about to turn into a stampede.

headline: ABC Narrowly Bests NBC in Evening News Ratings
abstract: In March, as the first hints emerged of big changes in evening news viewership, Bill Carter and Jacques Steinberg wrote:

headline: In a Reversal, Hedge Fund Will Support Sale of Ceridian
abstract: The hedge fund manager William A. Ackman dropped his opposition to the sale of Ceridian, the payroll processor, after tangling with the company for months.

headline: Ask Tina Fey
abstract: Tina Fey, whose comedy “30 Rock” on NBC is poised for its second-season premiere, is taking questions from readers this week.

headline: Over to You, Wal-Mart
abstract: Viewers deserve to know when sponsors are paying to have their products promoted on television shows, two congressional committee chairmen declared in a letter to FCC chairman Kevin Martin yesterday.

headline: For Summer Associates, Wachtell Still Shines
abstract: There’s a crisp hint of autumn in the New York air, but David Lat of The New York Observer is thinking summer. Summer associates, that is.

headline: Dubai Aerospace Grounds Auckland Airport Bid
abstract: Dubai Aerospace Enterprises abandoned plans to buy control of Auckland International Airport, New Zealand’s largest airfield, clearing the way for a Canadian asset manager to acquire it.

headline: Trying Times for Law Students
abstract: Even as thousands of new students flood the halls of the nation’s law schools each year, the market for lawyers is tightening up, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: U.K. Hires Goldman to Advise on Northern Rock
abstract: The British government has appointed Goldman Sachs to advise it on Northern Rock, Reuters reported, as the stricken bank told politicians its business was sound.

headline: For Blackstone’s James, a Major Test
abstract: The Blackstone Group‘s No. 2 executive, Hamilton “Tony” James, may be facing the biggest challenge of his more than 30 years on Wall Street. Reuters offers a profile of Mr. James, the man in charge of day-to-day operations at the newly public private equity giant.

headline: Serentis Gets $20.6 Million in Series A Financing
abstract: Serentis, a specialty drug developer, has raised $20.6 million in a Series A financing round. TheDeal.com reports the round included MVM Life Science Partners, Apposite Capital and Novo A/S.

headline: For Citi’s Top Management, a Game of Musical Chairs
abstract: From DealBook colleague Eric Dash:

headline: Bear Chief’s Golf Outings Draw Mixed Reviews
abstract: On Sunday, The New York Times published an item in its “Suits” column observing that, as two hedge funds managed by Bear Stearns were sinking last month in what has become commonly referred to as a “crisis,” Bear Stearns chief executive James E. Cayne was playing multiple rounds of golf. A previous article in The Times reported that Richard Marin, the head of the Bear unit that ran the troubled funds, stole away from what he called a “crisis-hedge-fund-salvation-workaholic weekend” to see a movie.

headline: Bally Gets Nod for Plan to Exit Bankruptcy
abstract: A bankruptcy court has given Bally Total Fitness permission to move ahead with a reorganization plan that will make the hedge fund Harbinger Capital Partners the new owner of the chain.

headline: Mircosoft Closes $6 Billion for aQuantive
abstract: Microsoft has completed the largest purchase in its history, sealing its $6 billion takeover of the Internet advertising firm aQuantive.

headline: Ceres Gets $75 Million to Burn
abstract: After a decade of plant biotechnology development primarily in food and feed crops, Ceres has taken advantage of a surge in interest in biofuels to raise its largest investment round to date, landing $75 million in a deal led by Warburg Pincus.

headline: Kohlberg & Company to Buy a Unit of Solo Cup
abstract: Solo Cup, a privately held maker of plastic, paper and foam tableware products, said Monday that it had agreed to sell its Hoffmaster business for $170 million to funds led by the private equity firm Kohlberg & Company.

headline: Agensys Raises $43.1 Million in Latest Round
abstract: In a fourth round of funding, Agensys raised $41.3 million from Duquesne Capital Management and Jafco, among others, TheDeal.com said. Total funding for the 10-year-old cancer drug developer now stands at $119 million.

headline: China’s Language Demands May Hurt Wall Street’s Expansion Efforts
abstract: Goldman Sachs was unable to name its co-head of investment banking in Asia as chief executive of its Beijing joint venture because his knowledge of Chinese was too weak, Bloomberg News reported, citing people at the firm. Richard Ong, an ethnic Chinese born in Malaysia, didn’t write Chinese well enough to take a mandatory test for senior managers.

headline: A Pushback Against Lowball Buyouts
abstract: Not long ago Carl Icahn’s bid for Lear would have been a rapidly done deal. But recently, shareholders have become increasingly hostile toward managements and boards for accepting what they perceive to be lowball bids, and have been aggressively filing suits to block deals.

headline: Ex-Home Depot Chief to Lead Chrysler
abstract: Robert L. Nardelli, who was ousted as chief executive of Home Depot this year amid shareholder discontent over his enormous pay package, will soon take on one of the most prominent jobs in corporate America: revitalizing the troubled automaker Chrysler.

headline: A Modest Proposal: A Blackstone Self-Buyout
abstract: The classic target for a buyout firm like the Blackstone Group has a beaten-down stock price, low levels of debt and a solid business. Daniel Gross, offering up an apparently tongue-in-cheek proposal on Slate.com, suggests that Blackstone itself would fit the bill.

headline: Pershing Begins Proxy War With Ceridian
abstract: Pershing Square Capital Management, the hedge fund run by the activist investor William Ackman, has taken his war with Ceridian to a new level, waging a proxy battle to unseat the company’s entire board.

headline: Redstone Says Viacom Could Go Private — Someday
abstract: While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street’s belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

headline: Investors Flock to VMware on First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Confirms Talks With Chilean Bank
abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia confirmed Friday that it was in exclusive talks with a key shareholder of Chile’s Banco del Desarrollo after Chilean media reported this week that a sale seemed to be imminent.

headline: DreamWorks Animation Enlists Ex-Chief of Viacom
abstract: In a move that seems calculated to provoke Viacom, DreamWorks Animation SKG, the animation company controlled by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, on Tuesday announced that Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, was joining its board.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Two Texas Men with Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Texas attorney general, Greg Abbott, have accused two Texas men of hijacking personal computers to send mass e-mails and inflate prices on at least 13 stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Google to Acquire Postini for $625 Million
abstract: Google said on Monday it has agreed to buy Postini, a maker of Web-based security software, for $625 million, expanding its package of online applications to compete with Microsoft‘s Office suite of programs. Postini provides security and encryption services, protecting instant messaging, e-mail and other communications, to more than 35,000 businesses and 10 million users worldwide.

headline: Will Barclays’ Asian Moves Secure an ABN Win?
abstract: In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports 31 Percent Profit Rise
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday that second-quarter net earnings surged 31 percent on strong investment banking activity as well as trading credit and interest rate products. Lehman, the world’s largest brokerage, said net earnings were $2.1 billion compared with $1.6 billion in the year-earlier period. Merrill Lynch’s subprime mortgage-related activities did not sap overall results, a concern of investors heading into the quarter.

headline: Sal Oppenheim Takes Larger Stake in IKB
abstract: Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its “strategic partnership” with IKB.

headline: Should Kohlberg Kravis Pull Its I.P.O.?
abstract: Some analysts are hearing a slamming noise — the distinct sound of Henry Kravis’s fingers getting caught in a closing window.

headline: CBS Offers Spanish Language Simulcast of ‘Cane’
abstract: The series premiere of “Cane,” last night on CBS, utilized a little-known feature of television, at least to English language viewers: the Secondary Audio Program.

headline: What Is This Thing Called Private Equity?
abstract: How does the private equity industry make so much money? Ben Stein, the lawyer, writer, actor and economist, considers this question in his column in The New York Times, pondering whether buyout chiefs are experts at finding market inefficiencies or tricksters who profit from “smoke and mirrors.”

headline: Mortgage Crisis Forces Sale of German Bank
abstract: The eastern German state of Saxony was forced to sell a troubled state-run bank Sunday as the global liquidity crisis set off by the United States subprime mortgage problems claimed its first major European victim.

headline: Citi Uses Big Reach to Grab Deal Share
abstract: A frequent criticism of Citigroup is that the banking conglomerate is too sprawling and unwieldy. Hedge fund manager Thomas Brown recently called Citi a “supersized jackalope,” referring to the mythical animal with a jack rabbit’s body and an antelope’s antlers.

headline: Last Thoughts on Ringtones
abstract: There are three points I wished I could have added to my column the other day about ringtones, the great digital ripoff–points that have been made by many of my readers.

headline: Yahoo’s V.P. Huddle and Music Cuts
abstract: There may not be major changes afoot at the company, but the entertainment division gets a shakeup.

headline: Rio Tinto Eludes Debt Difficulties with Alcan Fundraising
abstract: Despite the difficulties companies have had recently in raising debt for buyouts, at least one acquiror has found little trouble in doing so. Britain’s Rio Tinto has raised $40 billion to fund its takeover of Alcan, the Canadian aluminum producer, The Financial Times reported Wednesday.

headline: Citigroup Agrees to N.J. Settlement
abstract: Citigroup agreed to pay $978,000 to settle a New Jersey investigation into accusations that it failed to supervise two brokers whose trading strategies cost clients, including many older customers, more than $3 million, state regulators said Monday.

headline: How a Discount Sets Up Price Expectations
abstract: Discounts can permanently condition consumers to expect the product for less, hurting sales when it bounces back to full price.

headline: Interview With Alexander Solzhenitsyn
abstract: Prominent Russian writer and Nobel Prize winner Alexander Solzhenitsyn on Russia’s turbulent history, Putin’s version of democracy and his attitude to life and death. SPIEGEL: Alexander Isayevich, when we came in we found you at work. It seems that even at the age of 88 you still feel this need to work, even though your health doesn’t allow you to walk around your home. What do you derive your strength from? Solzhenitsyn: I have always had that inner drive, since my birth. And I have always devoted myself gladly to work -- to work and to the struggle.

headline: Radio Listeners Seem to Buy Less Music
abstract: The MusicFirst Coalition has publicized a six-month-old study that suggests that radio play hurts record sales.

headline: Tip of the Week: Open-Source Computer Programs
abstract: If you’re on a budget and not afraid of working without telephone support, consider open-source software.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: “The Invasion,” one of many heirs to the 1956 science-fiction classic “Invasion of the Body Snatchers,” opens on Friday. Nicole Kidman (above) plays a psychiatrist trying to stay alive and find her son before the aliens get to her.

headline: Two Monitors, One PC
abstract: Is there a way to connect two monitors to a Windows XP computer so I can keep my e-mail window up in one and do the rest of my work on the other?

headline: Canada: Inflation Slowed In August
abstract: AMERICAS

headline: Japan: Land Prices Continue Rising
abstract: ASIA

headline:
Talk to The Times:
Editorial Page Editor Andrew Rosenthal
abstract: Andrew Rosenthal, the editorial page editor, answered readers' questions on Sept. 24-28, 2007.

headline: Polo Profit Gains 10%
abstract: Aug. 8 (Bloomberg) -- Polo Ralph Lauren Corp. (NYSE:RL) , the designer of Chaps and Club Monaco clothing, said first-quarter earnings rose more than analysts estimated. The shares fell after the company cut its annual forecast for the second time this year.

headline: Sotheby's Profit Rises 48%
abstract: Aug. 8 (Bloomberg) -- Sotheby's, the auction house whose shares have slipped on concerns that hedge funds may buy less art because of investment losses, said profit from continuing operations rose 48 percent, helped by strong London and New York sales including a Mark Rothko painting.

headline: Iran, Low on Gasoline, to Be Supplied by Venezuela
abstract: Venezuela agreed to sell Iran gasoline on Tuesday, less than a week after Iran unveiled a rationing program to limit its dependence on gasoline imports.

headline: Pakistan Prepares for Former Prime Ministers’ Return
abstract: Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, said there was a need for dialogue to ensure a smooth period of preparation for elections.

headline: Sales Plummet at Circuit City
abstract: Consumer electronics retailer Circuit City reported lower-than-expected earnings on Thursday after it cut prices on flat-panel TVs and computers.

headline: Philippine Toll in Islamist Attacks Is the Region’s Highest
abstract: A new Human Rights Watch report underscores the need for the Philippines to do more against terrorism, the group said.

headline: Second Powerful Quake Hits Indonesia
abstract: The second earthquake struck about 200 miles to the northwest of the first earthquake’s epicenter.

headline: Tell-All PCs and Phones Transforming Divorce
abstract: In the digital age, it’s growing increasingly difficult to hide dirty secrets from former spouses in divorce cases.

headline: Faith, Hopewood and Charity?
abstract: Campaign Spotlight.

headline: Report Finds Dire Humanitarian Crisis in Iraq
abstract: As many as four million Iraqis need immediate help getting food, a report from Oxfam International warns.

headline: Generic Anemia Drug Allowed
abstract: Novartis has become the first company to win approval for a copy of Johnson & Johnson’s Eprex anemia treatment, allowing it to offer cheaper versions to Europeans.

headline: Stepping Boldly Off the Curb, With a Wave and a Prayer
abstract: The traffic in Cairo, and the army of police officers who try to manage it, tell much about modern Egypt.

headline: Sales of Existing Homes Declined 4.3% in August
abstract: The annual sales rate fell to 5.50 million from 5.75 million in July, the steepest percentage decline since March.
